sentence: Thanks for acknowledging our novel perspective as well as giving the valuable comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: Below, we address the detailed comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: Particularly, we clarify some potential misunderstandings and provide new results to show state-of-the-art results.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: About the main concern on “novelty, improvement relative to the current state of the art implementations,  and non-linearity of G and D”:
label: nonarg

sentence: A1: As for novelty, we first thank you for acknowledging that understanding GANs from the control theory perspective is promising and enjoyable to read.
label: concur

sentence: Indeed, as agreed by R#2, this is a major novel contribution that provides a unified and promising framework to model the stability of GANs, which includes some recent developments (e.g., Negative Momentum and Reg-GAN, See Sec. 4.1 and Appendix A&C) and also provides us a possibility to explore advanced tools in control theory (e.g., nonlinear control and modern control theory [*3]) to improve both the stability and convergence speed of GANs.
label: dispute

sentence: Then, as some useful examples, in this paper, we particularly showed that the technique of negative feedback can be leveraged to stabilize GANs and developed NF-GAN, which was proven to be effective in our experiments.
label: dispute

sentence: Finally, we added new results in Table 1 in the revision, which shows that the same technique of negative feedback can further improve the state-of-the-art method of SN-GAN [*5].
label: concur

sentence: Specifically, we apply NF-GAN to SN-GAN [*5] and NF-GAN provides a significant improvement on the state-of-the-art inception score on CIFAR-10 (from 8.22 to 8.45).
label: concur

sentence: Such results indicate that our technique of NF-GAN can still benefit the state-of-the-art variants of GANs (e.g., SN-GAN).
label: nonarg

sentence: Overall, our perspective is novel and it indeed sets new state-of-the-art results as compared to the current variants of GANs.
label: dispute

sentence: As for the statement “the WGAN analysis does not take into account that G and D are non-linear”, this is a potential misunderstanding.
label: dispute

sentence: In fact, in the WGAN analysis, we do not put any constraints on the G and D networks, which can be any well-defined nonlinear models.
label: dispute

sentence: This confusion may arise from the linearity of the dynamics.
label: dispute

sentence: In Sec. 3.2
label: dispute

sentence: , as we model the dynamics of G and D in the functional space instead of the parameter space, they can both denoted as integral parts (See Eqn. (10)&(11)), thereby both are linear.
label: dispute

sentence: However, this doesn’t influence the nonlinearity of G and D with respect to the weights.
label: dispute

sentence: Technically, we provide an approximate solution to deal with such nonlinearity.
label: dispute

sentence: As discussed in Remark 3 and Section 7 of the revised paper, we also note that the recent analyses of GANs on the functional spaces [*4] can provide a promising solution to solve this approximation and we leave it as our future work.
label: concur

sentence: Q2: About “comparison with the baselines”:
label: nonarg

sentence: A2: For fairness, we tried our best to fairly compare all methods.
label: concur

sentence: See details in the Concern 1 of our post for common concerns.
label: nonarg

sentence: For the state-of-the-art results, we indeed provided a significant improvement on the inception score of CIFAR-10 (from 8.22 to 8.45) using SN-GAN’s architecture as suggested.
label: dispute

sentence: Q3: How does negative feedback (NF) influence the training of stable dynamics and further evaluation:
label: nonarg

sentence: A3: As stated above in our response to Q1, we added the new results of applying negative feedback to SN-GAN, which is a state-of-the-art variant of GANs with empirically stable performance.
label: concur

sentence: Our results (See Table 1 (bottom) in the revision) indeed show that NF can further improve to reach new state-of-the-art results.
label: nonarg

sentence: In general, as NF is essentially a penalty term that regularizes $D$ to the zero-function, we can expect it to be effective for most dynamics [*3].
label: concur

sentence: We also included the suggested related work (Balduzzi et al. 2018) in Section 5.
label: concur

sentence: Finally, as for the further evaluation (such as multiple seed runs and 2nd-momentum estimates), we agree it is interesting, but it is very demanding in computational resources, and we leave it for a systematic future investigation.
label: concur

sentence: In summary, this paper proposes a unified framework to model the dynamics of GANs which is a powerful tool to stabilize and improve GANs.
label: nonarg

sentence: The experimental results on SN-GANs demonstrate that NF-GAN can further improve the performance of stable GANs and provide an improvement to the state-of-the-art models.
label: nonarg

sentence: Finally, it is a promising direction to follow where further advanced control methods can benefit the training of GANs.
label: nonarg

sentence: [*1] Gidel, Gauthier, et al. "Negative Momentum for Improved Game Dynamics." The 22nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Statistics. 2019.
label: nonarg

sentence: [*2] Mescheder, Lars, Andreas Geiger, and Sebastian Nowozin. "Which Training Methods for GANs do actually Converge?." International Conference on Machine Learning. 2018.
label: nonarg

sentence: [*3] Khalil, Hassan K. "Nonlinear systems." Upper Saddle River (2002).
label: nonarg

sentence: [*4] Johnson, Rie, and Tong Zhang. "Composite Functional Gradient Learning of Generative Adversarial Models." International Conference on Machine Learning. 2018.
label: nonarg

sentence: [*5] Miyato, Takeru, et al. "Spectral Normalization for Generative Adversarial Networks." (2018).
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the positive assessment of our work.
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like start by stating that we did not mean to claim that the rate of convergence proved in this paper is better that than of Yan et al.
label: dispute

sentence: We have modified the Remarks to clarify the statements.
label: concur

sentence: In the stochastic gradient setting, the number of gradient evaluation is indeed $T^2$. This is consistent with the result in Bernstein et al. (2018).
label: nonarg

sentence: The main point we would like to make is that the bounds are very concise and exactly reduce to that of gradient descent/stochastic gradient descent in the special cases.
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank you for pointing out that the bounded variance assumption may also be restrictive and only satisfied on bounded domains.
label: nonarg

sentence: It is nonetheless a standard assumption made in the literature.
label: dispute

sentence: We have modified Remark 3.4 (and added Remark 3.5) to make this clear in the updated version.
label: concur

sentence: Response to other minor points:
label: nonarg

sentence: Our convergence analysis is done for non-convex objective functions (similar to that of Yan et al. and Bernstein et al.).
label: nonarg

sentence: In the non-convex setting, to the best of our knowledge, there are no theoretical results that show benefits of momentum methods over SGD.
label: nonarg

sentence: For experiments, we speculate that the reason is that the batch size used is too small for (Powered)SGDM to gain an advantage over (Powered)SGD.
label: nonarg

sentence: We plan to add SGD as a reference algorithm (as suggested by another reviewer).
label: concur

sentence: Once the experiments are complete, we should be able to see how SGDM compares with SGD in the experiments.
label: nonarg

sentence: This may take a while for the ImageNet experiments, but we promise to do so in the final version.
label: concur

sentence: We have fixed the other issues you raised in your other minor comments. If you have any further comments, please let us know.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for the time and effort spent reviewing our paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: We mostly agree with your characterization of our work, but we think there are two important points we perhaps did not sufficiently emphasize in our paper and that we would like to mention:
label: nonarg

sentence: (1) There are other existing tasks and algorithms that fall into the marginal policy gradients framework.
label: concur

sentence: For example, researchers and practitioners both almost always clip actions when using policy gradient algorithms for robotics control environments (read: MuJoCo tasks).
label: concur

sentence: Recently, a reduced variance method was introduced by Fujita and Maeda (2018) for clipped action spaces.
label: concur

sentence: Their algorithm is also a member of the marginal policy gradients family and our theoretical results for MPG significantly tighten the existing analysis of their algorithm.
label: concur

sentence: (2) To the best of our knowledge, our work is the first to apply such variance reduction techniques to RL.
label: dispute

sentence: To summarize, our work consists of two components: (a) a new algorithm for directional control and (b) a variance reduction framework that can be applied to directional action space and clipped action spaces.
label: nonarg

sentence: While directional action spaces are not very common at this time, clipped action spaces are extremely common.
label: nonarg

sentence: We also anticipate that in the future, many additional environments will be available that feature directional actions (many console or PC games, for example).
label: concur

sentence: For these reasons, we feel that our work is not incremental at all, and is actually quite novel.
label: dispute

sentence: We thank the reviewer for his comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We discuss the novelty aspects in our general response ( https://openreview.net/forum?id=HkMlGnC9KQ&noteId=S1eid00WaQ ) and will be happy to clarify this in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Further comments are addressed below.
label: nonarg

sentence: controlling the amount of deformations
label: nonarg

sentence: The stability bounds of B+M provide upper bounds on ||Phi(x') - Phi(x)|| (where x' is a deformation of x) based on quantities related to the corresponding diffeomorphism, i.e. the maximum norm and the maximum jacobian norm.
label: concur

sentence: For simple classes of deformations these can be computed precisely in terms of the parameters of the deformation, e.g. for translations, rotations, scaling or simple parametric warps.
label: concur

sentence: When bounding these away from zero by a certain constant, ||Phi(x') - Phi(x)|| is then included in a centered ball of the RKHS with a radius growing with this constant.
label: concur

sentence: This constant then acts as a regularization parameter, just like the size of additive perturbations in the case of adversarial perturbations, and can be tuned by cross-validation.
label: concur

sentence: ** tightness of the lower bounds
label: nonarg

sentence: This is something that we verify empirically in our experiments at the end of training by checking the values of spectral norms as a proxy of the upper bound, and looking at the gap with the lower bound.
label: concur

sentence: In particular, when using the ||f||_M penalty, lower and upper bounds seem to be controlled together in our experiments (Figure 2), making the bound useful, in contrast to PGD, for which spectral norms grow uncontrolled when the lower bound decreases.
label: concur

sentence: We will further clarify this in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: eqn (8), (12): thanks for pointing these out, we will fix this in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for your comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: With respect to your concern over scalability, the need to input the actions and observations of all agents in the value function (i.e. centralized value function) limits scalability only during training time, and it is a necessary measure to reduce the non-stationarity of multi-agent environments, as discussed in previous work [1].
label: dispute

sentence: We would also like to re-emphasize the fact that our final trained policies are decentralized and do not require any information exchange between agents.
label: dispute

sentence: This trait makes our approach (and other centralized-critic/decentralized-policy approaches) useful in situations where one can train in a simulation where communication is less taxing, but deploy in the real world, where communication may be more challenging.
label: dispute

sentence: We also compared to other methods demonstrating the better scalability of our approach, cf. Table 2.
label: dispute

sentence: Your thinking of ‘semantically probable’ exchange of information is interesting.
label: dispute

sentence: We note that it is possible to compress each agent’s actions/observations before they are sent to a central critic.
label: dispute

sentence: Our setup naturally allows for this.
label: dispute

sentence: Consider a case with high-dimensional image observations.
label: dispute

sentence: In our approach, each agent needs to embed these observations (along with their actions) before sharing with other agents.
label: dispute

sentence: In a situation where information exchange between agents is expensive, even during training, we can select a sufficiently small embedding space such that performance and efficiency are balanced.
label: dispute

sentence: This notion of compressing embeddings prior to sharing across agents does not fit as naturally into the competing methods.
label: dispute

sentence: Our experiments were especially designed to have two contrasting environments, so that we can illustrate two different aspects of multi-agent RL where we felt like the current approaches have not been able to address at the same time.
label: dispute

sentence: Thus, it is by design that different baselines perform differently on them, as every approach has its own strengths and weaknesses.
label: dispute

sentence: Our experiments demonstrate that our approach handles both environments well, which none of the baselines is able to do.
label: dispute

sentence: Our experiments on Cooperative Treasure Collection demonstrate that the general structure of our attention model (even without considering dynamic attention as in our uniform attention baseline) is able to handle large observation spaces (and relatively larger numbers of agents) better than existing approaches which concatenate observations and actions from all agents together.
label: dispute

sentence: Furthermore, our experiments on Rover-Tower demonstrate that the general model structure alone is not sufficient in all tasks, specifically those with separately coupled rewards for groups of agents, and dynamic attention becomes necessary.
label: dispute

sentence: We have added a new section 6.3  to the supplement that includes visualizations of the attention mechanism both over the course of training and within episodes.
label: concur

sentence: Our code is available online and a link will be included in the paper once the anonymized review period is over.
label: concur

sentence: [1] Ryan Lowe, Yi Wu, Aviv Tamar, Jean Harb, OpenAI Pieter Abbeel, and Igor Mordatch. Multi-agent actor-critic for mixed cooperative-competitive environments. In Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, pp. 6382–6393, 2017.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for the thoughtful review and positive assessment. We are glad to see that you appreciate the genuine flavor of causality in our paper and support our paper’s acceptance.
label: concur

sentence: We agree that a formal exposition introducing an NLP/deep learning audience to the basics of interventions and counterfactuals and expressing a toy DAG to explain the spurious associations between the review sentiment and the manifestation in text of other attributes of the review, including but not limited to the genre, actors, budget, etc. We are actively working on preparing this exposition and while it is not yet in the draft we plan to have it prepared in advance of the camera-ready version.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for pointing out that we should have been more thorough in explaining that while genre is a clear example of such a spurious association, it is far from the only one captured in Figure 4.
label: concur

sentence: Indeed, many other words, including “will”, “my”, “has”, “especially”, “life”, “works”, “both”, “it”, “its”, “lives”, “gives”, “own”, “jesus”, “cannot”, “even”, “instead”, “minutes”, “your”, “effort”, “script”, “seems”, and “something”, appear to be spuriously associated with sentiment and are captured by the original-only and revised-only classifiers as highly-weighted features.
label: concur

sentence: , Notably all of these features fall out from the highly-weighted features when our classifier is trained on counterfactually-augmented data.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding the sensitivity of BERT models, Table 9 shows the ability of a model explicitly trained to differentiate between the original and the revised data.
label: concur

sentence: This is to shed some insight on how much the two differ (on account of our intervention).
label: concur

sentence: Because the two indeed are different, we expect that a model should be able to differentiate them to some degree.
label: concur

sentence: We note that a model class’s ability to differentiate between the original and revised data when explicitly trained to do so may not necessarily be correlated with how susceptible that model is to breaking when evaluated out of sample.
label: concur

sentence: We’re grateful for your comments on exposition and will continue to address these points as we improve the draft.
label: nonarg

sentence: We appreciate your time and comments on the work.
label: nonarg

sentence: We are really thankful for the positive feedback. Here we give detailed answers to the Reviewer's concerns.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1) - "... in Table 2, AnyBurl ... yields better Hits@10 values than Neural-LP-N, but the corresponding bold in the results is conveniently omitted."
label: nonarg

sentence: Thanks for pointing this out! We will make the presentation of the results consistent by highlighting the respective number.
label: concur

sentence: 2) - "... the expressiveness of the learned rules can be somehow limited,..."
label: nonarg

sentence: We remark that our framework supports rules with negation, comparison among numerical attributes and classification operators, where linear functions over attributes can be expressed.
label: nonarg

sentence: Such rules capture a fragment of answer set programs, where a limited form of aggregation [Faber et al., 2011] and restricted external computation functions [Eiter et al., 2012] are allowed.
label: nonarg

sentence: While these rules might not cover all possible knowledge constructs, they are still valuable and rather expressive for encoding correlations among numerical and relational features.
label: nonarg

sentence: Moreover, to the best of our knowledge they have not been directly supported by previous works on rule learning.
label: nonarg

sentence: 3) - "Missing references - authors may want to consider citing https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.06187 ..."
label: nonarg

sentence: Thanks for referring us to this important work! We will certainly add this reference to the paper.
label: concur

sentence: We thank you for your thoughtful review. We are happy to learn that you believe it is an interesting direction that holds potential for high impact.
label: nonarg

sentence: Re: simpler methods (like clustering, BoW etc.) might work equally well
label: nonarg

sentence: To assess transfer learning potential reliably, we require both the X and y for the target task (i.e supervision).
label: concur

sentence: Consider the case where the target task is sentiment analysis, and one of the candidate tasks is finding sentence length (SentLen).
label: concur

sentence: For the sake of the argument, let us assume that the X for both sentiment analysis and sentence length is exactly the same set of movie reviews.
label: concur

sentence: In such a case, unsupervised metrics like clustering, BoW etc. would indicate maximum transfer potential, whereas the actual transfer potential would be close to zero (assuming the lengths of reviews aren’t correlated with the sentiment).
label: concur

sentence: This is a fundamental problem of measures that look directly at the input data X without considering the nature of the labels y.
label: concur

sentence: For the sake of completeness, we will compare our methods with the suggested baselines in the camera ready/future versions of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Re: not clear if the classifier weight difference is well defined
label: concur

sentence: > You are right in noting that the classifier weights might capture dissimilar yet useful features for two similar tasks, and hence the classifier weight difference might under-predict the transfer potential.
label: concur

sentence: We discuss this issue in the paper (section 4.1), which is why we avoid the set overlap metric.
label: dispute

sentence: Owing to similar concerns, we recommend using CFS information transfer metric over classifier weight difference (which is also supported by results in Table 2 and Figure 3).
label: concur

sentence: Re: thoughts on how this could be applied outside the context of sentence representations and classification
label: nonarg

sentence: > It is easy to adopt our approach to study the information encoded in the encoders for other problems involving structured prediction (say POS Tagging).
label: concur

sentence: Instead of using a decoder that takes in all the dimensions of the encoded input token, one could iteratively select dimensions that provide the highest gains in decoding the right target sequence (say POS tags).
label: concur

sentence: Our formulation is very general, and it could potentially also be applied to other modalities like images for tasks like image classification and captioning.
label: concur

sentence: We would like to thank you for reviewing our paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: [Principled Guidance] The design of guidances is heuristic, but as illustrated in Figure 2 and in Table 2, they are easy to design and are effective.
label: dispute

sentence: Further, we added our unsupervised analyses to show that the method works even without explicit guidance on all tested datasets.
label: dispute

sentence: In this paper, we propose the idea of guidance itself and show that it is imposing a desired semantics on the latent space without having labeled data.
label: concur

sentence: In our future work, we plan to investigate more principled ways of deciding guidances.
label: concur

sentence: We now address this point in our "Discussion" section.
label: concur

sentence: [Experiments Section] We have significantly updated qualitative and quantitative results in our "Experiments" section and now compare our methods against Beta-VAE, DIP-VAE, and InfoGAN.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the detailed review.
label: nonarg

sentence: Below we address the main concerns.
label: nonarg

sentence: “I think the paper needs some changes in written style mainly, to make it friendlier to newcomers to the area... For instance, the omission of a results discussion section or a conclusion are clearly not reader friendly”
label: nonarg

sentence: >> We discussed the results of the experiments in pages 7-8. We will revise to make this discussion easier to find.
label: concur

sentence: “What would have been nicer would be to perform some sort of ablation study, where the authors studied how the representational capacity of the network changed as a result of them introducing the universal linear transmission layer.”
label: concur

sentence: >> We refer the reviewer to Figure 2 where one can see that the PointNet model underperforms across various tasks compared to PointNetST that is identical to PointNet except the addition of a single linear transmission layer.
label: nonarg

sentence: Furthermore, PointNetQT, PointNetSeg, and DeepSets can be seen as different versions of PointNet variations.
label: concur

sentence: “A direct theoretical and experimental comparison between PointNet and PointNetST would have been useful for me to understand the impact of the change that the authors introduce..”
label: nonarg

sentence: >> In Theorem 1 we state that PointNet is not equivariant universal, but PointNet with a single transmission (PointNetST)  layer is.
label: nonarg

sentence: In the experiments section we compare these two models on three different learning tasks.
label: concur

sentence: “Where is the conclusion section?”
label: nonarg

sentence: >>We felt it is unnecessary but see we were wrong, we will add one.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for the comments and suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: The technical comments are addressed below:
label: nonarg

sentence: Extending result to other target functions:
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree that the problem might be significantly more difficult for different target functions, and would like to make the following remarks:
label: nonarg

sentence: Note that in our bias-variance decomposition, only the bias term depends on the target function.
label: nonarg

sentence: In other words, our result on the variance (including Theorem 4) would still be valid for other targets, such as two-layer neural network.
label: nonarg

sentence: One caveat is that for general target function, the output needs to be properly scaled since our current analysis in Section 5 relies on linearizing the network.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2. When the target function is a multiple-neuron neural network, deriving the bias term can be challenging.
label: nonarg

sentence: However, we note that under the same setup, the bias may be obtained when the teacher is a slightly more general single-index model, i.e. $y=\psi(\beta^\top x)$ with Lipschitz link function $\psi$, equivalent to a single-neuron network.
label: nonarg

sentence: For instance, the bias under vanishing initialization is the same as that of least squares regression on the input, which can be solved under isotropic prior on $\beta$ via decomposing the activation function similar to Appendix C.5.
label: nonarg

sentence: Parameter count:
label: nonarg

sentence: To clarify our statement in the discussion section, our current result requires $n,d,h$ to grow at the same rate, and thus $n = O(dh)$ is beyond the regime we consider.
label: concur

sentence: This is also true for previous works on double-descent in random feature model [Hastie et al. (2019)][Mei and Montanari (2019)].
label: concur

sentence: When $h \ll n$, it is not clear if the same analysis still applies (for instance approximating the network with a kernel model), and thus the instability of the inverse may not be the complete explanation of double-descent (if it appears).
label: concur

sentence: Characterizing the generalization in this regime would be an interesting direction.
label: concur

sentence: Training both layers:
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for the suggestion; we have included training both layers simultaneously as a future direction.
label: concur

sentence: We would like to briefly mention that under certain model parameterization and initialization, gradient flow on both layers may reduce to one of the three models we analyzed (see [Williams et al. (2019)]).
label: nonarg

sentence: More generally, our current result may be extended to cases where the dynamics of training both layers can be linearized (for instance initialization in the "kernel regime"), for which the learned model can be written down in closed-form.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for the thoughtful comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We are glad that you found our topic interesting and appreciated our theoretical analysis and experimental results.
label: nonarg

sentence: We address other comments below:
label: nonarg

sentence: [Results are only given for the Zipfian distribution]
label: nonarg

sentence: Many real-world data naturally follow the Zipf’s Law, as we showed in Figure 5.1 and Figure 5.3 for internet traffic and search query data.
label: concur

sentence: Thus, our theoretical analysis assumes item frequencies follow the Zipfian distribution.
label: concur

sentence: While our analysis makes this assumption, our algorithm does not have any assumption on the frequency distribution.
label: concur

sentence: [Assuming query distribution is the same as data distribution]
label: nonarg

sentence: As the reviewer pointed out, the query distribution we use is a natural choice.
label: concur

sentence: There might be other types of query distributions, such as the one pointed out by the reviewer.
label: concur

sentence: Intuitively, our overall approach that separates heavy hitters from the rest should still be beneficial to such query distribution.
label: concur

sentence: [Algorithm design]
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree that our algorithms are relatively simple.
label: concur

sentence: We believe this is a feature not a bug: as we showed in Sec. 4.1, our algorithm does not need to be more complex.
label: concur

sentence: Specifically, our Learned Count-Min algorithm achieves the same asymptotic error as the “Ideal Count-Min”, which is allowed to optimize the whole hash function for the specific given input (Theorem 7.14 and Theorem 8.4 in Table 4.1).
label: concur

sentence: The proof of this statement demonstrates that identifying heavy hitters and placing them in unique bins is an (asymptotically) optimal strategy.
label: concur

sentence: (In fact, our first attempt at solving the problem was a much more complex algorithm which optimized the allocation of elements to the buckets (i.e., the whole hash function h) to minimize the error.
label: concur

sentence: This turned out to be unnecessary, as per the above argument.)
label: concur

sentence: [Novelty compared to Mitzenmacher’ 18]
label: nonarg

sentence: Our paper, as well as the works of Kraska et al ’18, Mitzenmacher ’18,  Lykouris &
label: concur

sentence: Vassilvitskii ’18, Purohit et al, NIPS’18, belong to a growing class of studies that use a machine learning oracle to improve the performance of algorithms.
label: concur

sentence: All such papers use a learned oracle of some form.
label: concur

sentence: The key differences are in what the oracle does, how it is used, and what can be proved about it.
label: concur

sentence: In Kraska’18 and Mitzenmacher’18, the oracle tries to directly solve the main problem, which is: “is the element in the set?” An analogous approach in our case would be to train an oracle that directly outputs the frequency of each element.
label: concur

sentence: However, instead of trying to directly solve the main problem (estimate the frequency of each element), our oracle is a subroutine that tries to predict the best resource allocation --i.e., it tries to answer the question of which elements should be given their own buckets and which should share with others.
label: concur

sentence: There are other differences.
label: concur

sentence: For example, the main goal of our algorithm is to reduce collisions between heavy items, as such collisions greatly increase errors.
label: concur

sentence: This motivates our design to split heavy and light items using the learned model, and apply separate algorithms for each type.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast, in existence indices, all collisions count equally.
label: concur

sentence: Finally, our theoretical analysis is different from M'18 due to the intrinsic differences between the two problems, as outlined in the previous paragraph.
label: concur

sentence: [The analysis is relatively straightforward]
label: nonarg

sentence: There are three main theorems in our paper: Theorem 8.4, Theorem 7.11 and 7.14.
label: concur

sentence: Our proofs of Theorem 7.11 and 7.14 are technically involved, even if the techniques are relatively standard.
label: concur

sentence: On the other hand, the proof of Theorem 8.4 uses entirely different techniques.
label: concur

sentence: In particular, it provides a characterization of the hash function optimized for a particular input.
label: concur

sentence: [The machine learned Oracle is assumed to be flawless at identifying the Heavy Hitters]
label: nonarg

sentence: Actually, this is not the case.
label: dispute

sentence: The analysis in the paper already takes into account errors in the machine learning oracle.
label: dispute

sentence: Please see the 2nd paragraph of Sec. 4.1 and Lemma 7.15.
label: dispute

sentence: In summary, our results hold even if the learned oracle makes prediction errors with probability O(1/ln(n)).
label: dispute

sentence: We will revise the text to make it clearer.
label: concur

sentence: We would like to thank you for reviewing our paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: [Unguided Case]
label: nonarg

sentence: Please refer to our general comment above on why our unguided case performs better now.
label: concur

sentence: The main usefulness of our guided approach is to directly capture some of the desired variations in the data.
label: concur

sentence: This is now clearer on our quantitative and visual results in the “Experiments” section.
label: concur

sentence: [Heuristic Guidance]
label: nonarg

sentence: The main premise behind guiding our siamese networks is to find very simple, yet effective ways to capture some of the variation in the data, through weak supervision.
label: concur

sentence: For more complex semantics, we discuss the possibility of using a pre-trained network as guidance.
label: concur

sentence: Please refer to our “Discussion” section for more details.
label: concur

sentence: [Differentiable Guidance]
label: nonarg

sentence: The transformations need to be differentiable in order to backpropagate the gradients into our generator.
label: concur

sentence: This is now pointed out and discussed in our "Discussion" section.
label: concur

sentence: Although this limits the function families, we can still use differentiable relaxations of more complicated functions.
label: concur

sentence: [Gaussian Prior on Latents] In our new experiments, we used uniform distributions to model the generative factors.
label: concur

sentence: We had experiments with categorical variables, however, we faced training stability issues with them.
label: concur

sentence: We now point this out in our "Discussion" section.
label: concur

sentence: We appreciate the Reviewer's comments, which help us to improve the paper.

sentence: In the following we reply to the main concerns of the reviewer.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1 - "... how general this approach would be? ...if rules contain quantifiers, how would this be extended?"
label: nonarg

sentence: The extendibility of the Neural LP framework is a very important and relevant question, which we also mentioned explicitly as a possible future work direction.
label: concur

sentence: In the rules that we support in our framework all variables are universally quantified.
label: concur

sentence: While learning rules with existential quantifiers in rule heads is a difficult endeavor in general, even for classical relational learners, the Neural LP framework in principle can be extended to support them as follows: For every relation p, we can create a fresh diagonal Boolean matrix $M_{\exists p}$, which has 1 at the position (i,i) iff there exists an entity j, such that p(i,j) is in the KG (similar as for classification operators discussed on p. 5).
label: concur

sentence: Incorporating these matrices into the framework and filtering rules that have the respective relations in the head should allow us to extract the target rules.
label: concur

sentence: Yet analysing how well such approach performs in practice is still an open problem, which we leave for future work.
label: concur

sentence: In any case, we will discuss the extendability of the framework in the paper.
label: concur

label: nonarg

label: nonarg

label: concur

sentence: This was a typo and we have corrected this phrase.
label: concur

sentence: 4. "What is 'an exact upper bound'?"
label: nonarg

sentence: We mean that it is a true upper bound instead of just being a stochastic estimate of an upper bound (while, on the other hand, Weng et al’s approach is stochastic estimate of a lower bound).
label: concur

sentence: However, we agree that the “exact” is superfluous and have removed it.
label: concur

sentence: 5. "I am not an expert but to me 'the density of adversarial examples' calls for further
label: nonarg

sentence: explanation."
label: nonarg

sentence: We think perhaps “the prevalence of adversarial examples” would be a better phrase and have corrected this.
label: concur

sentence: We mean that the input model density is integrated over for our metric to calculate the volume of counterexamples in a subset of the input domain, relative the overall volume of that input domain.
label: concur

sentence: 6. "From page 3 onwards: I was truly confused by the use of [x] throughout the text
label: nonarg

sentence: (e.g. in Equation (4))
label: nonarg

label: nonarg

sentence: another instance of it."

label: nonarg

sentence: verification. Is it actually the case that this angle has never been explored so far?"
label: nonarg

sentence: As far as we are aware this is correct: we have not been able to find any prior work which aims to estimate the statistical prevalence of counterexamples.

sentence: 8. "In page 6, what is meant by 'more perceptually similar to the datapoint'?"
label: nonarg

sentence: We mean that the minimal adversarial distortion for models on CIFAR-10 is known to typically be much smaller than for MNIST.
label: concur

sentence: The result of this is that an adversarial example on MNIST will often have visual salt-and-pepper noise, whereas an adversarial example for CIFAR-10 typically is indistinguishable to the naked eye from its unperturbed datapoint.

sentence: Replica exchange Langevin diffusion is widely used in classic MCMC over the years.
label: concur

sentence: Our work also uses this methodology in the setting of nonconvex optimization problem, which arises in many machine learning applications such as training neural networks.
label: nonarg

sentence: There are also many interesting questions in this direction, for example, how to choose the best temperature based on the structure of specific problems.
label: nonarg

sentence: That is why we still submit it for ICLR.

sentence: As for the comments on math side.
label: nonarg

sentence: First, when a->infty, the exchange process should be defined in another way.
label: concur

sentence: Our current definition, which swapping particles with some rate, is only valid for finite a.
label: concur

sentence: This extension is not totally trivial and in Dupuis&et. al's work, some results are established.
label: concur

sentence: In our paper, we only discuss finite swap rate.
label: concur

sentence: This brings convenience for the discussion of discretization error.
label: concur

sentence: Otherwise, we need to use a different approach to analyze.
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, we point out that in discretization, the swapping intensity a should be smaller than the step size.
label: concur

sentence: This also reflects the nontrivial connection between infinity swapping and discretization.
label: concur

sentence: Second, the kappa in (3.10) is related to the Poincare inequality and it is also a lower estimate of the spectral gap of Markov process.
label: concur

sentence: Kappa is can be defined as the solution of a variational problem involved Dirichlet form.
label: concur

sentence: However, although our result shows that swapping boosts the Dirichlet form, we still cannot obtain an analytical formula of kappa depending on a, since the variational problem makes this relation extremely complicated.
label: concur

sentence: Even in the field of pure math, it is still very hard to obtain an explicit formula of kappa for a general Markov process.
label: concur

sentence: However, for this special case, we will keep trying to solve it in the future.
label: concur

sentence: 1) - "... the current proposed method can only deal with one form of numerical predicate, which is numerical comparison."
label: nonarg

sentence: Apart from simple numerical comparison we are also able to deal with complex classification operators that aggregate numerical attributes using linear functions, where the threshold value is selected in a systematic fashion, (see Classification Operators) as well as negated atoms (see Negated Operators on p. 6).
label: dispute

sentence: We note that such rules are indeed limited to some extent, but they still capture a rather expressive fragment of answer set programs with restricted forms of external computations
label: dispute

sentence: [Eiter et al., 2012].
label: dispute

sentence: Below we present examplar rules learned by our framework, which are not restricted to numerical comparisons.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2a) - "The paper does not do a great job of convincing the reader that the problem it is trying to solve is an important matter, or the proposed method is indeed effective in some applications."
label: nonarg

sentence: With the rapid development of industrial and scientific knowledge graphs, we believe (and agree with the Reviewer #2) that learning rules that involve multiple modalities is an important and relevant problem.
label: dispute

sentence: Indeed, such rules can not only be used for data cleaning and completion, but they are also themselves extremely valuable assets carrying human-understandable structures that support both symbolic and subsymbolic representations and inference.
label: dispute

sentence: 2b) -  "The authors should try to find a real-world domain which can really demonstrate the effectiveness of the method."
label: nonarg

sentence: To the best of our knowledge Freebase and DBPedia are the only standard KGs with numerical values [Garcia-Duran et al., 2018] used for the evaluation in state-of-the-art works.
label: dispute

sentence: This is the reason why we have selected and used them for our experiments.
label: dispute

sentence: The impact of our approach might appear to be rather modest, since these KGs still have only a limited amount of numerical information.
label: dispute

sentence: Therefore, to demonstrate the power of our approach further, we have also performed evaluation on the synthetic datasets.
label: dispute

sentence: We would be happy to learn about other datasets suitable for our experiments.
label: nonarg

sentence: 3) - "The experiment section lacks more detailed analysis which can intuitively explain how well the proposed method performs on the benchmarks.
label: nonarg

sentence: A good place to start with is to visualize (print out) the learned numerical rules and see if they make any sense."
label: nonarg

sentence: According to the Reviewer's comment we will extend Section 5 on experimental results by showing more detailed analysis.
label: concur

sentence: In particular, we will present the following examples of the learned rules from the considered (real-world and synthetic) datasets:
label: nonarg

sentence: - FB15K:
label: nonarg

sentence: disease_has_risk_factors(X,Z) :- f(X), symptom_of_disease(X,Y), disease_has_risk_factors(Y,Z)
label: nonarg

sentence: The rule states that symptoms with certain properties (described by the function f) typically provoke risk factors inherited from diseases which have these symptoms.
label: nonarg

sentence: Here, the function f is the sigmoid over a linear combination of numerical properties of X.
label: nonarg

sentence: - DBPedia:
label: nonarg

sentence: defends(X,Z) :- primeMinister(Z,Y), militaryBranch(Y,X), f(Y)
label: nonarg

sentence: This rule states that prime ministers of countries with certain numerical properties (described by the function f), are supported by military branches of the given country.
label: nonarg

sentence: The function f is the sigmoid over a linear combination of numerical properties of Y.
label: nonarg

sentence: - Numerical1:
label: nonarg

sentence: prefer(X,Y) :- isNeighbourTo(X,Y), hasOrder(X,Z1), hasOrder(Y,Z2), Z1>Z2, max{Z2:hasOrder(Y,Z2)}
label: nonarg

sentence: This rule with a comparison operator states that a person X prefers neighbours with the maximal order that is less than X's.
label: nonarg

sentence: - Numerical2:
label: nonarg

sentence: prefer(X,Y) :- isNeignborTo(X,Y), hasBalance(Y,Z1), borrowed(Y,Z2), f(Y)
label: nonarg

sentence: This rule states that neighbours with the largest difference between the balance and the borrowed amount are preferred.
label: nonarg

sentence: More precisely, here f selects among all X those entities, for which the difference between the balance and the borrowed amount is maximal.
label: nonarg

sentence: The primary goal of the projections is to project all embeddings into the model dimension d so that we can have variable sized embeddings.
label: dispute

sentence: Our goal was not to make the model model expressive.
label: dispute

sentence: Compared to the rest of the model, these projections add very little overhead compared to the rest of the model.
label: dispute

sentence: Doing without them is an interesting future direction though!
label: concur

sentence: We appreciate the reviewer’s positive comments about our work.
label: nonarg

sentence: Regarding the convergence and speed of training, we would like to stress that all hyperparameters for training were kept the same as those for training the default model architecture, other than those we explicitly mentioned as being tuned (e.g. learning rate for the speech experiment).
label: concur

sentence: In particular, for all experiments, the number of epochs is the same for both the baseline approach and the K-matrix approach.
label: dispute

sentence: Additionally, for the speech preprocessing and ShuffleNet experiments, we compare the total wall-clock training time of our K-matrix approach to that of the baseline approach, in both cases finding that the training time required by our approach is at most 20% longer than that of the baseline approach.
label: concur

sentence: In our updated revision, we also include the training time comparison for the DynamicConv model in Appendix B.4.2 (in this case, the modified model with K-matrices actually trains slightly faster than the baseline).
label: concur

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that a training plot can help provide a better understanding of how our proposed approach performs, and therefore have included an example plot (for the ShuffleNet experiment) in our updated revision (in Appendix B.2.3).
label: concur

sentence: Regarding empirical comparisons to dense matrices, in Table 5 (Appendix B.1.2), we compare the use of K-matrices in the raw-features speech model with several other classes of matrices, including dense matrices.
label: concur

sentence: We find that, while using a trainable dense matrix slightly outperforms just using the fixed FFT (0.3% drop in test phoneme error rate), using a K-matrix instead of a dense matrix yields a further improvement of 0.8% in the phoneme error rate.
label: concur

sentence: Another empirical comparison of K-matrices and dense matrices is in Section 3.3, in which we replace the linear layers in the decoder of a DynamicConv model with K-matrices; these linear layers are by default dense (fully-connected) matrices.
label: concur

sentence: Theoretically, in Lemma E.3 we show that arbitrary dense matrices are contained in the BB* hierarchy – in particular, that any n x n matrix is in (BB*)^{2n-2}, which implies that its K-matrix representation requires at most (4n log n)*(2n-2) = O(n^2 log n) parameters and thus is tight up to a logarithmic factor in n.
label: concur

sentence: Hello,
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for reviewing our paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: Regarding your comments about the triviality of our paper,
label: nonarg

sentence: We undertook an extensive initial phase of experiments where we discovered non-trivial contributions for achieving SOTA performance and fast convergence.
label: dispute

sentence: In particular:
label: nonarg

sentence: - To the best of our knowledge, our specific implementation of entity pre-training is novel.
label: dispute

sentence: Our technique can be ported to other neural, multi-task setups with a strong dependence between tasks (e.g. where a model must learn to perform some task before attempting to learn one or more dependent tasks jointly).
label: dispute

sentence: For example, we have already begun porting this scheme to a neural cross-lingual summarization project of ours.
label: dispute

sentence: Entity pre-training accounted for a 0.63% increase in our ablation experiment.
label: dispute

sentence: On the CoNLL04 test set, it accounts for a 1.26% boost in performance, which is large relative to historic improvement on this corpus [1].
label: dispute

sentence: - As opposed to previous models (e.g. [2], [3]) we were able to drop all recurrent architectures, which reduced training times substantially.
label: dispute

sentence: Our work is one of the first architectures for joint NER and RE to do this.
label: dispute

sentence: Because previous papers do not report their training times, we contacted the authors of a comparable method [4] for their training times and found that our method converged between 3-35X times faster for the ACE04, ADE, and CoNLL04 corpora (keeping in mind that we did not train on the same hardware).
label: dispute

sentence: The large range in our estimate is because [4] trained for a wide range (60-200) of epochs.
label: dispute

sentence: Our model serves as a strong baseline for future studies on joint NER and RE architectures and provides guidance on how to best integrate a pre-trained language model into such an architecture.
label: dispute

sentence: For the ADE corpus in particular, we advance SOTA RE performance by >10%, which is substantially larger than improvements have been historically [5].
label: dispute

sentence: It is also complementary to [6] (published in ACL this year), by demonstrating similar performance without the need for templated queries, which, as pointed out in our introduction, may become a limiting factor where domain expertise is required to craft such questions (e.g., for biomedical or clinical corpora).
label: dispute

sentence: Regarding your comments on a System Demonstration submission to ACL,
label: nonarg

sentence: Our paper is a methodological advancement, not a system, tool, or demonstration [7] and is not suitable for submission to System Demonstrations at ACL.

sentence: [Q] I feel the discussion on loss was rushed, and I gained no insight on what the authors thought was a prominent difference between the three losses studied.
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] The theoretical differences between these losses were studied in detail in the corresponding publications.
label: dispute

sentence: From the practical side, it’s unclear which statistical divergence to optimize, in particular whether to pick (i) an f-divergence such as Chi-squared implemented by LS-GAN, or (ii) an integral probability metric such as Wasserstein distance, or (iii) a loss function which doesn’t correspond to any statistical divergence, such as NS-GAN.
label: dispute

sentence: Hence, we wanted to provide some insight on how do these perform within different setups, not necessarily the ones used in the original publications.
label: dispute

sentence: To this end we uncover that on the considered data sets it's hard to outperform the non-saturating loss combined with regularization and normalization.
label: dispute

sentence: Apart from this, the empirical evidence doesn’t allow us to say more and we will clarify this in the manuscript.
label: dispute

sentence: [Q] For architectures to be a main pillar of the paper, I feel that this area could have been explored in greater detail.
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] We agree with this assessment and we are indeed focusing on regularization and normalization.
label: concur

sentence: Our main question here was whether swapping Resnet with SNDCGAN leads to the same insights which is indeed the case.
label: concur

sentence: On the other hand, architectures are such a rich area enabling various design choices that they possibly merit a paper on their own.
label: concur

sentence: We will clarify the precise goal of the architecture exploration in this work.
label: concur

sentence: This being said, one major question we wanted to understand is which Resnet tricks from the literature (all 7 of them) are meaningful in practice and we present an ablation in the Section D of the appendix to conclude that the only relevant one is the number of channels which makes sense as it drastically changes the number of trainable parameters.
label: concur

sentence: Thanks for your valuable comments. Below we address the detailed comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: Connection to the Jacobian matrix:
label: nonarg

sentence: A1: Thanks for the interesting suggestion.
label: nonarg

sentence: Indeed, the proposed regularizer can be interpreted as certain constraints on the Jacobian at the equilibrium point.
label: concur

sentence: Since at the equilibrium, $D(x)=0$ for all x, indicating that the equilibrium is a global optimal point of the negative feedback regularization $L = \lambda \int D^2(x)dx$. Therefore, the Hessian matrix $J = \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial \phi^2}$ is positive-semidefinite.
label: concur

sentence: Otherwise, $\phi$ is a stationary point instead of the global optimal point of the regularization term.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, introducing the $L$ is equivalent to adding a negative-semidefinite matrix to the jacobian matrix of the original dynamics, which do help to stabilize the dynamics.
label: concur

sentence: We added the related discussion in Appendix E in the revision.
label: concur

sentence: Q2: The linear assumption on the dynamics:
label: nonarg

sentence: A2: Yes. The Laplacian transformation and the following discussions in Sec. 2.2 rely on linear dynamics, but it does not put any restriction on defining the discriminator as a nonlinear neural network.
label: concur

sentence: In Section 3, we can see that in the function space, the discriminator $D(x)$ and the generated samples $G(z)$ can be considered as integral parts which are also linear dynamics.
label: concur

sentence: The two non-linear operations are clearly denoted in Fig. 2(right), and we make an approximation to ignore these two non-linear operations which is widely adopted in control theory [*1].
label: concur

sentence: A3: Actually, Eqn. (7) comes from Eqn. (6).
label: concur

sentence: Letting $e = c - \theta$, and taking Laplacian transformation on both side of Eqn. (6), we have $s\mathcal{F}(D(t, x)) = x \mathcal{F}(c-\theta)$, which induces Eqn. (7).
label: concur

sentence: We made this clearer in the revision.
label: concur

sentence: Q4: The input and output of dynamics:
label: nonarg

sentence: A4: For a dynamic, both the input and the output are functions of time $t$. We take $D$ as an example.
label: concur

sentence: Since the dynamics of $D$ is equivalent to the integral part, the output of $D$ can be formulated as $D(t, x) = \int_0^{t} g(u, x)du$, where $g$ is also a function of time t. In this setting, we say that the input of the dynamic is $g(t, x)$ and the output is $D(t, x)$, for all $x$. In Eqn. (10), we ignore the $x$ to emphasize that we modeling $D$ in the time-space.
label: concur

sentence: We added an example for a better presentation in Sec. 3.1 in the revision.
label: concur

sentence: Q5: The stability of previous methods:
label: nonarg

sentence: A5: Indeed, many existing methods can *generate realistic images*, which, however, does not necessarily imply that these methods *are stable*. For example, in Fig. 4 (left), the inception score of SGAN and LS-GAN is high at the beginning but finally diverges after a period.
label: dispute

sentence: The early stopping in GAN's training is widely adopted otherwise the image quality will decrease, which indicates that these methods are not actually stable.
label: dispute

sentence: We agree that it is essential to justify how the reconstruction error works as a measure of privacy in this paper.
label: concur

sentence: In the revision, we have added the following justification on privacy quantification in Section 2, Section 4 and Section 5.
label: concur

sentence: We also note that the proposed reconstructive adversarial network (RAN), is not an extension of GAN but only borrows GAN’s thoughts on adversarial training several neural networks, for the data privacy-uniquely problem.
label: dispute

sentence: First, there is no single standard definition of data privacy-preserving problems and corresponding adversary attacks.
label: dispute

sentence: And a fundamental problem in it is the natural tradeoff between privacy and utility, which is affected by different data privacy-preserving methods.
label: dispute

sentence: Our key contribution in this paper is the RAN framework and the training algorithm, which can accommodate different choices of privacy attackers and privacy quantification.
label: dispute

sentence: Second, finding the right measurement for privacy is an open problem in itself.
label: dispute

sentence: To evaluate RAN, one has to pick some quantifications.
label: dispute

sentence: In the present paper, we chose the “reconstructive error” as the quantification of privacy because it is the most intuitive one to measure the risk of disclosing sensitive background information in the raw data for the given perturbed data (Encoder output).
label: concur

sentence: Third, in the future, we will evaluate RAN using other quantifications of privacy as well in a definitely defined application.
label: concur

sentence: For example, we could measure the privacy by the hidden failure, i.e., the ratio between the background patterns that were discovered based on RAN’s Encoder output, and the sensitive patterns founded from the raw data, in the object recognition application.
label: concur

sentence: -- “This work only considers problems for which the optimal input distribution is known, but is motivated by the fact that it could be applied to problems for which the optimal distribution is unknown and thus being able to discover new algorithms. It is hard to support this motivation when no experiments are done in its favor.”
label: nonarg

sentence: The long-term agenda / research program is indeed two-fold:
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. Investigate whether known optimal worst-case algorithms can be reproduced without any domain knowledge (i.e., “Can ML learn Algorithms”).
label: nonarg

sentence: This is the case in which the optimal distribution of inputs is also known.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2. Discover new/better worst-case algorithms for problems with the aid of ML, when neither a good algorithms or input distribution is known.
label: nonarg

sentence: #2 is a long-term goal, and not tackled in this paper, but we believe #1 (tackled in this paper) is itself of strong interest (and difficult) -- would ML be able to discover the same “pen-and-paper” algorithms that computer scientists invented?
label: dispute

sentence: The problems we study (ski-rental and Adwords) fall into the first category of problems.
label: dispute

sentence: Note that the algorithms in the two cases are very different in structure.
label: dispute

sentence: Further, please note that even though the optimal distribution of input is known in these two problems, we do not use it at all in training.
label: dispute

sentence: Indeed, this is the main point of this paper -- the previous work of Kong et al. used these distributions to train the algorithm network (and hence that technique still needed the prior theoretical “pen-and-paper” work), while this work starts with ZERO knowledge.
label: dispute

sentence: We follow this approach even in case #1 when the optimal input distribution is known exactly because we have the ultimate goal #2 in mind, that is, we want to design a framework that can eventually also work without knowledge of optimal input distribution (but that goal is outside the scope of this paper).
label: dispute

sentence: -- “No comparison has been made between their approach and other previous approaches.
label: nonarg

sentence: We only know that the proposed approach finds near-optimal solutions with a difference of 0.01 competitive ratio.
label: nonarg

sentence: It is thus very hard to know if this new approach brings any improvement to previous work.”
label: nonarg

sentence: We believe there is some misunderstanding here as to the contribution.
label: dispute

sentence: As such, there are no previous approaches to “learn algorithms” (besides Kong et al.).
label: dispute

sentence: To be more explicit (in case we didn’t understand the comment)
label: dispute

sentence: , previous work for algorithmic problems could fall into a few buckets:
label: dispute

sentence: (1) The original algorithms papers which found optimal worst case algorithms [Karlin et al. 1986, Mehta et al. 2007].
label: nonarg

sentence: These give the analytical benchmarks.
label: nonarg

sentence: E.g., [Mehta et al. 2007] proposes the algorithm to solve Adwords, and proves that it achieves the optimal CR of 1-1/e ~ 0.63 (i.e., no matter what the online input sequence is, you get >= 1-1/e of the optimal solution in hindsight if you knew the instance offline).
label: nonarg

sentence: Thus the difference of 0.01 CR is a direct comparison to that work.
label: dispute

sentence: (2) One may imagine there could be some kind of optimization (IP / LP) technique or some ML technique to solve specific instances of the problem (a specific instance of Adwords e.g.).
label: dispute

sentence: But this is in fact not a feasible possibility, for two reasons: (a) Our problems are online problems where the full instance itself is not known in advance, and (b) we are looking for worst case competitive algorithms, i.e., a policy that does well no matter how the instance unfolds in the future.
label: dispute

sentence: Thus there can not be previous work to compare in such a bucket.
label: dispute

sentence: (3) Kong et al., 2018 is the closest previous work since it shows how to learn algorithms in the online setting.
label: dispute

sentence: As mentioned above, the critical difference is that our paper learns the algorithms without any prior knowledge of the worst input distribution, but evolves both the distribution and the algorithm jointly (with some parallels to GANs, AlphaZero, self-play, etc. as we have stated).
label: dispute

sentence: Quantitatively, the CR results are equally good; our main objective is to see if the learned algorithm is close in policy to the theoretical algorithm, and whether we are reasonably close to the optimal CR.
label: dispute

sentence: Thank you for the valuable and encouraging feedback! Below, please see our replies.
label: nonarg

sentence: >> What are the key limitations of AutoLoss? Did we observe some undesirable behavior of the learned optimization schedule, especially when transfer between different datasets or different models ?
label: nonarg

sentence: More discussions on these questions can be very helpful to further understand the proposed method.
label: nonarg

sentence: These are indeed good questions.
label: nonarg

sentence: We list several limitations we discovered during the development of AutoLoss:
label: nonarg

sentence: - Bounded transferability
label: nonarg

sentence: We observe AutoLoss has bounded transferability -- while we successfully transfer a controller across different CNNs, we can hardly transfer a controller trained for CNNs to RNNs.
label: concur

sentence: This is slightly different from some related AutoML works, such as in [1], where auto-learned neural optimizers are able to produce decent results on even different families of neural networks.
label: concur

sentence: We hypothesize that the optimization behaviors or trajectories of CNNs and RNNs are very different, hence the function mappings from status features to actions are different.
label: concur

sentence: We leave it as a future work to study where the clear boundary is.
label: concur

sentence: - Design white-box features to capture optimization status
label: nonarg

sentence: Another limitation of AutoLoss is the necessity of designing the feature vector X, which might require some prior knowledge on the task of interest, such as being aware of a rough range of the possible values of validation metrics, etc.
label: concur

sentence: In fact, We initially experimented with directly feeding blackbox features (e.g. raw vectors of parameters, gradients, momentum, etc.) into controller, but found they empirically contributed little to the prediction, and sometimes hindered transferability (as different models have their parameter or gradient values at different scales).
label: concur

sentence: - Non-differentiable optimization
label: nonarg

sentence: Meta-learning discrete schedules involves non-differentiable optimization, which is by nature difficult.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, a lot of techniques in addition to vanilla REINFORCE are required to stabilize the training.
label: concur

sentence: Please also see our answer to the next question for more details.
label: concur

sentence: As a potential future work, we will seek for continuous representations of the update schedules and end-to-end training methodologies, as arisen in recent works [2].
label: concur

sentence: We haved add the above discussion to the latest version as Appendix A.9.
label: concur

sentence: >> As the problem is formulated as an RL problem, which is well-known for its difficulty in training, did we encounter similar issues? More details in the implementation can be very helpful for reproducibility.
label: nonarg

sentence: >> Any plan for open source?
label: nonarg

sentence: We acknowledge the difficulties of training controllers using vanilla REINFORCE.
label: concur

sentence: During our development of the training algorithm (See Eq.2, the “discussion” section in Sec.4, and Appendix A.1), we found the vanilla form of REINFORCE algorithm leads to unstable training.
label: concur

sentence: We therefore have made many improvements and adaptations by either referring to existing literature, or depending on the specific tasks.
label: concur

sentence: They include:
label: concur

sentence: - Substitute from the reward a baseline term, which is a moving average (see section 3, Eq.2)
label: concur

sentence: - Reward clipping (see section 3, under Eq.2)
label: concur

sentence: - Use different values of T for different tasks (see “discussion” in section 4)
label: concur

sentence: - Use improved training algorithms (e.g. PPO) for more challenging tasks, and slightly adjust reward generation schemes (see “discussion” in section 4, and Appendix A.1).
label: concur

sentence: We have also revised the submission to disclose more details on how we make these improvements.
label: concur

sentence: We will make all code and models trained in this paper available for reproducibility.
label: concur
