sentence: We thank Reviewer 4 for stating that “the proposed method has a good compression ratio while maintaining competitive accuracy”.
label: nonarg

sentence: We provide clarification for the two main questions of the Reviewer below.
label: concur

sentence: Novelty of the paper
label: concur

sentence: As we state in our introduction, using codebooks to compress networks is not new, as well as using a weighted k-means technique.
label: concur

sentence: However, as we state in the paper: “The closest work we are aware of is the one by Choi et al. (2016), but the authors use a different objective (their weighted term is derived from second-order information) along with a different quantization technique (scalar quantization).
label: concur

sentence: Our method targets a better in-domain reconstruction, as depicted by Figure 1”.
label: concur

sentence: Note that we already cite two of the suggested references by Reviewer 4, namely “Towards the limit of network quantization” and “ThiNet: A filter level pruning method for deep neural network compression” in our work.
label: concur

sentence: We will further clarify our positioning in an updated version of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Compression ratio
label: concur

sentence: We provide an example of the computation of compression ratio in Section 4.1, paragraph “Metrics”.
label: concur

sentence: Let us detail it further here.
label: concur

sentence: The memory footprint of a compressed layer is split between the indexing cost (one index per block indicating the centroid used to encode the block) and the cost of storing the centroids.
label: concur

sentence: Say we quantize a layer of size 128 × 128 × 3 × 3 with 256 centroids and a block size of 9.
label: concur

sentence: Then, each block of size 9 is indexed by an integer between 0 and 255: such integer can be stored using 8 bits or 1 byte (as 2^8 = 256).
label: concur

sentence: Thus, as we have 128 x 128 blocks, the indexing cost is 128 x 128 x 1 byte = 16,384 bytes = 16 kB.
label: concur

sentence: Finally, we have to store 256 centroids of dimension 9 in fp16, which represents 256 x 9 floats (fp16) = 256 x 9 x 2 = 4,608 bits = 4.5 kB.
label: concur

sentence: The size of the compressed model is the sum of the sizes of the compressed layers.
label: concur

sentence: Finally, we deduce the overall compression ratio which is the size of the compressed model divided by the size of the non-compressed model.
label: concur

sentence: Thanks for your efforts in reviewing our paper and the valuable comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We attempt to address your concerns in the following.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. Response to the "Weaknesses" part and the comparison with GBDT
label: nonarg

sentence: As stated in the response to review 1, our goal is not inventing a model to beat GBDT but developing a model to cover the scenarios not suitable for GBDT such as some applications need online updating.
label: dispute

sentence: "The next contender" model in your comment is the GBDT, which indeed works well for tabular data.
label: dispute

sentence: However, GBDT suffers from two shortages, as stated in Section 2 and the responses to reviewer 3.
label: dispute

sentence: These 2 shortages make GBDT very hard to be used in many real-world scenarios.
label: dispute

sentence: For example, in an online recommender system, we need to update the model frequently to achieve the satisfying real-time performance.
label: dispute

sentence: In this case, GBDT will be very inefficient as it needs to be re-trained from scratch.
label: dispute

sentence: In contrast, NN can be learned by mini-batch fashion and therefore can learn from streaming data naturally.
label: dispute

sentence: The proposed TabNN can overcome these shortages and achieve comparable accuracy with GBDT.
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, compared with previous NN based solutions for tabular data, TabNN outperforms them significantly.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, TabNN is a better general solution for tabular data as it can cover more scenarios.
label: concur

sentence: 2. Difference between "implicit feature combinations" and "explicit feature combinations"
label: nonarg

sentence: The main difference lies in whether the feature combination information is explicitly introduced into model structure or not.
label: concur

sentence: For example, in FCNN, as all features are connected to the neurons in the next layer, there are no feature combination information in the model structure.
label: concur

sentence: Although the feature combination information are not explicitly provided, one neuron in FCNN can learn a linear combination of its input features.
label: concur

sentence: Thus, we say there are "implicit feature combinations" in FCNN.
label: concur

sentence: In TabNN, we leverage GBDT to find feature combinations and then construct model structure according to them.
label: concur

sentence: Thus, we say there are "explicit feature combinations" in TabNN.
label: concur

sentence: "Implicit feature combinations" is not efficient as it introduces much more trainable parameters, and has a risk of over-fitting.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast, "explicit feature combinations" let model focus on the more important feature combinations and is more efficient.
label: concur

sentence: The successful CNN model also uses "explicit feature combinations", as it only combines the local pixels.
label: concur

sentence: 3. About "encourage parameter sharing".
label: nonarg

sentence: Yes, we use parameter sharing in the one cluster of feature groups.
label: concur

sentence: We will clarify this in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: 4. Benefits brought by the "Structural Knowledge"
label: nonarg

sentence: We had compared the benefit brought by the 'Structural Knowledge' in the experiment.
label: concur

sentence: The difference between TabNN (S) and TabNN (R), as shown in Table 3, implies that that the structural knowledge from GBDT yields a large contribution to the performance of TabNN.
label: concur

sentence: The "Structural Knowledge" is in TabNN by default. We will clarify this in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: * the fact that the random projections preserved the inner product (centered at zero) was probably not desirable.
label: nonarg

sentence: It might be more fruitful if these linear combinations were learned or sub-senses of words
label: nonarg

sentence: Preserving the inner product means that the distribution of the features is not biased, if we keep adding words to the dictionary, the performance would degrade gracefully with the amount of compression.
label: dispute

sentence: Perhaps a non-orthonormal basis would also work if the network compensates for the different distortions in the inner products.
label: dispute

sentence: You are correct in assuming that other discrete building blocks could be more fruitful, but, we chose language modelling as a setting, not a task (see general response) as such, the building block chosen was the word. We could have chosen sub-words, or characters but the goal here is not the get the best possible language model but to understand a property of the mechanism.
label: dispute

sentence: An interesting idea would be to actually use other information and encode it as random projections (e.g. syntactic dependency patterns).
label: nonarg

sentence: The amount of possible patterns is simply too large to be enumerated and as such the random projections would serve as unique "fingerprints" for unique "dependency patterns" that would be used as inputs.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. I do not get the point of bringing up NCE...
label: nonarg

sentence: Approximations like NCE (in conjunction with random projections) would allow us to remove the restriction in the output layer.
label: concur

sentence: We want to imply that our proposal is not incompatible with NCE, but we did not yet explore it so, to make the paper more self-contained it is probably best to leave this out.
label: concur

sentence: 2. In Figure 3, the baseline got different perplexity between 3(a) and 3(b).
label: nonarg

sentence: we were trying to cram different experiments (with different regularization) in the same figure which is understandably confusing and needs to be corrected.
label: concur

sentence: 3. Shouldn't random indexing produce non-uniform numbers of non-zero entries depending on alpha? Why did you have an exact number of non-zero entries, s, in the experiments?
label: nonarg

sentence: yes but not necessarily. Alpha can be used to control the expected proportion of non-zero entries, but as long as the probability of a sparse configuration is random uniform, our mechanism guarantees that any sampled index is almost orthogonal to any other sampled index, so it's easier achieve the same while guaranteeing the sparsity in the inputs.
label: concur

sentence: Thanks for the detailed and thoughtful review.
label: nonarg

sentence: We are glad that you think of this paper as a timely contribution addressing an important problem that must be addressed in order to build more robust NLP systems.
label: concur

sentence: We agree with your point that it would be great to have a practical takeaway guiding practitioners for what to do in practice.
label: concur

sentence: We believe that the first step here is to characterize the problem coherently and that having laid this groundwork, one immediate next step is, as you suggest, to develop a more practical solution that requires a less expensive/onerous annotation effort.
label: concur

sentence: The key contribution of our paper is to provide a clear characterization of a variety of concerns in the language of interventions and to demonstrate that indeed, they can be addressed by acquiring interventional data.
label: concur

sentence: The knowledge that (i) NLP models trained on counterfactually augmented data suffer less from these problems and (ii) transport better out of sample (see new results in the updated draft, per R3’s suggestion) validates this.
label: concur

sentence: As you mentioned, our solution requires significant expenditure (both financial and human capital)
label: concur

sentence: compared to simply labeling data
label: concur

sentence: As a follow-up, for existing datasets, our next steps include investigating how to make these adjustments in a cost-effective way.
label: concur

sentence: In preliminary work, we have been investigating how to use humans in the loop more effectively.
label: concur

sentence: One approach involves using generative models to propose candidate substitutions and relying on humans only accept or reject the revisions (vs having to write them from scratch).
label: concur

sentence: Our experience with crowdsourcing suggests that this feedback would be significantly cheaper to collect (provided that a reasonable fraction of suggestions were appropriate).
label: concur

sentence: We additionally note that for some tasks, such as NLI, creating new datasets already requires annotators to synthesize examples de novo and the fractional increase for soliciting counterfactually-augmented data might not be as onerous as compared to tasks where the default is to rely on annotators only for tags.
label: concur

sentence: We are also appreciative of your constructive suggestions to improve the paper, and have taken several steps to improve the draft.
label: concur

sentence: These include updating the draft to include (i) a detailed analysis of edits performed on SNLI, (ii) results on various datasets using an ELMo based classifier; (iii) concerning your question about larger Bi-LSTMs, we had tried a large Bi-LSTM but it overfit badly.
label: concur

sentence: We have updated the draft to include this detail.
label: concur

sentence: Thanks also for catching several typographic errors. We have addressed them in the new draft.
label: concur

sentence: I think it is misleading to call it a convolution, as (a) it is not a convolution mathematically, and (b) fast convolution techniques (Fourier, Winograd) cannot be applied, so claims to greater efficiency may be misleading.
label: nonarg

sentence: R)We believe as future work our algorithm can be combined with Winograd techniques for optimization.
label: dispute

sentence: For instance winograd is designed to use a batch of images to convolve with a kernel, here an image convolves with a “batch of kernels”.
label: dispute

sentence: There is no reason why those two techniques can be merged.
label: dispute

sentence: In our implementation we perform a set of convolutions with the input image where FFT can be applied too.
label: dispute

sentence: Thanks for your effort in providing this detailed and useful review!
label: nonarg

sentence: We present our clarification in the following:
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: the feasibility of using neural networks to learn cumulative quantities:
label: nonarg

sentence: A: In each iteration, only a small subset of information sets are sampled, which may lead to the neural networks forgetting values for those unobserved information sets.
label: dispute

sentence: To avoid such catastrophic forgetting, we used the neural network parameters from previous iterations as initialization, which gives an online learning/adaptation to the update.
label: dispute

sentence: Furthermore, due to the generalization ability of the neural networks, even samples from a small number of information sets are used to update the new neural networks, we find that the newly updated neural networks can produce very good value for the cumulative regret and the strategy mixture.
label: dispute

sentence: (we give related discussion in section 3.1 and add much more experimental results in Figure 5, further details please see the revised paper.)
label: concur

sentence: Q2: It does not seem necessary to predict cumulative mixture policies (ASN network)?
label: nonarg

sentence: A: As you say, any information nodes I_i would be sampled proportionally to \pi^{\sigma^t}_i(I_i), which is the same probability as in the definition of the mixture policy (Eq.4).
label: dispute

sentence: Actually, if we have a large enough buffer to save all the sampled nodes, it’s easy to inference the mixture policy accordingly.
label: dispute

sentence: However, in the large game, this large memory is expensive and impossible.
label: dispute

sentence: Another method called reservoir sampling was used in NSFP to address a similar problem.
label: dispute

sentence: We borrow this idea to our method, however, the achieved mixture policy cannot converge to a low exploitability.
label: dispute

sentence: Actually, the third possible solution could employ the checkpoint of each current strategy, and mixture this current strategy accordingly.
label: dispute

sentence: Q3: It would help to have a discussion about how to implement (7), for example do you use a target network to keep the target value R_t+r_t fixed for several steps?
label: nonarg

sentence: A: The optimization problem for the double neural networks is different from that in DQN, where the target network is fixed for several steps and only one step of gradient descent is performed.
label: concur

sentence: In our setting, both RSN and ASN perform several steps of gradient descent with stochastic mini-batch samples.
label: concur

sentence: [R1: In Table 1, for ImageNet, Shadow Attack does not always generate adversarial examples that have on average larger certified radii than the natural parallel, at least for sigma=0.5 and 1.0. Could the authors explain the reason?]
label: nonarg

sentence: During attack/crafting, we need to make an adversarial example that gets misclassified even after perturbations drawn from a Gaussian distribution centered at zero with scale sigma.
label: concur

sentence: During evaluation, while the augmentations are drawn from a similar distribution, the realized random variables are not identical to those used for crafting the adversarial perturbation.
label: concur

sentence: In ImageNet, where the dimensionality is high (224X224X3) and for larger sigmas, to have a relatively dense and representative sampling, we need to sample a lot more perturbations during adversarial example crafting.
label: concur

sentence: However, in our experiments, we could only sample up to 400 instances per example (the maximum batch-size that could fit on our machine with 4 GPUs is 400).
label: concur

sentence: This results in having a sparse sample when the standard deviation is higher.
label: concur

sentence: One can potentially improve these results by using larger batch-sizes (i.e., sampling more) or a more powerful GPU or even a TPU, however we do not have the resources for such experiments at this time.
label: concur

sentence: [R1: In Table 2, it is not clear to me what is the point for comparing errors of the natural images (which measures the misclassification rate of a natural image) and that of the adversarial images (which measures successful attacks rate), and why this comparison helps to support the claim that the attack results in a stronger certificates.
label: nonarg

sentence: In my opinion, to support the above claim, shouldn’t the authors provide a similar table as Table 1, directly comparing the certified radii of the natural images and adversarial images?]
label: nonarg

sentence: In the original submission, we tried to produce tables that look like the tables in papers that we compare
label: concur

sentence: to
label: concur

sentence: The randomized smoothing paper reports certified radii and also accuracy (1-error) under various perturbation bounds.
label: concur

sentence: However, the CROWN-IBP paper and the improved randomized smoothing paper based on adversarial training of smoothed classifiers (SmoothAdv) only report *error rates* using a fixed distance to the decision boundary.
label: concur

sentence: This is done because, unlike the Randomized Smoothing method, the radii are not directly calculated in the CROWN-IBP method and cannot be accessed directly;  CROWN-IBP takes a fixed radius chosen by the user, and either produces or fails to produce a certificate for that radius.
label: concur

sentence: This is in contrast to randomized smoothing, which outputs different radii for different images (a larger radius means a stronger certificate).
label: concur

sentence: In regards to why we compare the errors on natural images and those of our adversarial images:
label: nonarg

sentence: Please see the (updated) last paragraph of Section 5, which explains this comparison in detail.
label: concur

sentence: In short -  we are comparing the rate at which natural images certify to the rate at which adversarial images certify.
label: nonarg

sentence: For the case of large perturbations, we find that our adversarial image produce certificates more often than natural images!
label: nonarg

sentence: For small perturbations, our attack still produces certificates reasonably often, although not quite as frequently as natural images.
label: nonarg

sentence: This shows that certificates alone cannot be used to reliably discern between natural images, and adversarial images produced by the proposed shadow attack.
label: nonarg

sentence: [R1: From Figure 9, we see the certificate radii of the natural have at least two peaks. Though on average the certificate radii of the adversarial attacks is higher than that of the natural images, it is smaller than the right peak. Could the authors elaborate more of the results?]
label: nonarg

sentence: This happens because, for CIFAR-10, the smoothed classifier is very “confident” on a subset of the validation images which correspond to that right peak.
label: concur

sentence: Here, our use of “confidence” should not be confused with the confidence of a network (output of the softmax layer).
label: concur

sentence: For the purpose of the certified radii, the “confidence” we are interested in is related to the prediction of the network on the Gaussian perturbed images (i.e., a very high “confident” example is an example where all of the perturbed images get the same label).
label: concur

label: nonarg

sentence: For convenience, we have copied that response here: In our model, BERT is more than a source of contextual word embeddings as we fine-tune all of its ~110M parameters during training.
label: nonarg

sentence: Simply replacing BERT with distributed embeddings and a character-CNN or LSTM wouldn’t allow us to determine the effect of contextualized embeddings because we would simultaneously be removing the majority of our model’s trainable parameters.
label: dispute

sentence: Nevertheless, we performed the suggested ablation by swapping BERT for GloVe embeddings (300 dimensional) and found that NER performance dropped from 89.46% to 40.33% and RE performance fell from 66.83% to 14.44% on the test set of the ConLL04 corpus (note that we had to increase the learning rate by 10X to get the model to converge).
label: concur

sentence: If you were to somehow control for this drop in model capacity, say by adding in an LSTM network, the ablated model would closely match this paper [1], whom we outperform by ~3% overall on the CoNLL04 corpus.
label: nonarg

sentence: This paper is not cited in Table 1 as they report macro-averaged F1 scores, while most other papers (including the current state-of-the-art [2]) report micro-averaged F1 scores, as we did.
label: nonarg

sentence: Finally, it is well known that contextual embeddings outperform distributed embeddings on a wide range of NLP tasks, including NER [3].
label: nonarg

sentence: The aim of our study wasn’t to compare contextual vs. distributed embeddings but on how to successfully integrate BERT into a state-of-the-art joint NER and RE architecture.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2. Thank you for this suggestion.

sentence: Please also see our high-level clarification above which we believe can help in better interpretation of our contribution.
label: nonarg

sentence: Some specific responses below:
label: nonarg

sentence: Reviewer #1 is absolutely right -- we don’t know yet how to scale this to more difficult combinatorial problems.
label: concur

sentence: But let’s clarify that statement a bit more:
label: nonarg

sentence: The ski-rental problem is often the first problem studied when teaching online algorithms, but it is certainly far from a “toy problem” when we wish to learn an algorithm from scratch.
label: dispute

sentence: We apologize if we painted an incorrect picture by calling it a “simple example” and a “staple introductory problem”.
label: concur

sentence: It is easy to describe in that it has a single hidden parameter (the length of the ski season) and a single revealed parameter (the cost of buying).
label: dispute

sentence: It is a staple introductory problem because it is elegant and illuminates the essential difficulties in designing online algorithms: there is a nearly-trivial factor-2 competitive algorithm (rent until you’ve spent $B, then buy, so even if the ski season ends the next day, you’ve not spent more than twice the least possible amount), but the 1-1/e competitive ratio algorithm is quite creative and subtle, and serves as an introduction to the richness of the field of online algorithms.
label: dispute

sentence: In fact, the Karlin et al. (1986) paper also introduced the notion of competitive analysis of online algorithms, and  is probably the most-cited paper in this field.
label: dispute

sentence: In some sense, this poses us the ideal challenge: can ML approaches discover creative and subtle “solutions” (in our case, an algorithm)?
label: dispute

sentence: On a more technical note, please note that our “machinery” of solving the two-player game is needed to discover an algorithm for the ski rental problem: if we don’t allow the players to alternate and reach an equilibrium, for any fixed distribution on the ski rental instances (B, K), there is a deterministic algorithm that is optimal (among all online algorithms), and the worst-case performance of that (or any) deterministic algorithm is *provably* limited by a factor of 2 (i.e., there exists some distribution on instances where it will fail badly).
label: concur

sentence: Also refer to our discussion on this in the high-level clarification at the top.
label: nonarg

sentence: The AdWords problem considered is actually a difficult combinatorial problem, and is an archetypal online combinatorial optimization problem that captures the class of problems solvable by one of the most powerful techniques in this area -- primal-dual algorithms, which have led to the state-of-the-art approximation algorithms for numerous hard online (and offline) optimization problems.
label: dispute

sentence: In particular, it generalizes bipartite matching, historically one of the most significant combinatorial optimization problems (led to the development of the classic Hungarian method, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_algorithm).
label: dispute

sentence: We did water down our ambition in a few ways:
label: nonarg

sentence: Instead of producing an algorithm that works for inputs of all sizes, we focus on the case of 9x3 (three advertisers, nine slots) -- a fixed finite size!
label: concur

sentence: This choice was arrived at based on the following criteria: what can we learn in a few hours of computation that’s still *well beyond* what can be achieved through exhaustive search (for an algorithm).
label: concur

sentence: Think of our task roughly as learning to play a very hard game on a 9x3 board -- we would, of course, love to learn how to play the same game on arbitrary size boards, but the fact is that the game is mighty hard even at this “board size” (since in each round, one player plays a 0-1 assignment to each cell in the board, and the other player picks a subset of the columns, in fact a weight vector on the columns).
label: dispute

sentence: Instead of producing an algorithm that works for the 0-1 version of the problem, we produce an algorithm that works for the fractional version of the problem.
label: dispute

sentence: This is, once again, motivated by making something work with modest amount of computation.
label: dispute

sentence: Our explorations indicated that producing an algorithm for the 0-1 version needs reinforcement learning, and producing an algorithm that works on all 9x3 instances using this approach would still take several days of computation.
label: dispute

sentence: On calling it Yao’s Principle: as Reviewer #1 correctly noted, this is an application of the classic von Neumann minimax principle to the “game” between an “algorithm player” and an “input player”.
label: concur

sentence: We call it Yao’s principle primarily in accordance with tradition in theoretical CS (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yao%27s_principle and also https://blog.computationalcomplexity.org/2006/10/favorite-theorems-yao-principle.html, where it is noted that “Yao observed [the result]” and commentators note that it’s called Yao’s principle because this observation has significant consequences for many central problems in TCS).
label: concur

sentence: We are happy to add text to reflect this.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for your reviews and comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We address your questions as follows.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. Scalability of the proposed solution
label: nonarg

sentence: From our current results, you may see that our approach has a decent scalability -- even though we doubled the subtasks and also introduced additional dependency in Crafting compared to Resource Collection, it does not need much more episodes for converging to optimal policies, where our agent-wise exploration plays an important role.
label: concur

sentence: Generally speaking, deploying more present workers coupled with our agent-wise exploration should significantly improve the learning efficiency and overcome the challenges introduced from more substasks or a larger dependency graph.
label: concur

sentence: In addition, the computational complexity is linear in terms of the number of agents, so our approach is also scalable when there are more agents.
label: concur

sentence: 2. What is the reason for using rule-based agents in all the experiments?
label: nonarg

sentence: We have actually used RL agents as well (Appendix C.3), and it showed that our approach also works when workers are RL agents.
label: dispute

sentence: In the main results, we focus on rule-based agents because it is computationally demanding to train a large population of RL agents, and our focus was not about the worker policies but rather how the manager assesses the workers’ mental states and encourages an optimal collaboration accordingly.
label: concur

sentence: In this paper, using a cheap rule-based implementation with randomness has demonstrated the effect of different components of our approach.
label: concur

sentence: 3. Are the authors willing to release the code?
label: nonarg

sentence: Yes, we do plan to open source our implementation.
label: concur

sentence: Specifically, the game environment and the worker agents were implemented in Python and it runs at a speed of more than 300 steps per second.
label: concur

sentence: We used PyTorch as the framework for implementing all the network modules.
label: concur

sentence: Typically it took < 10 hours to get a converged result by our approach on a single Nvidia Tesla V100 GPU.
label: concur

sentence: 4. Typos
label: nonarg

sentence: Thanks for pointing out these typos. We will fix them in the next revision.
label: concur

sentence: We have fixed the footnote and capitalization problems.
label: concur

sentence: However, as we have elaborated in the text below Eq.2, to reduce the variance and stabilize the training, we have made the following adaptations referring to previous works [1,2]:
label: concur

label: concur

label: concur

sentence: Moreover, AutoLoss is not restricted to REINFORCE, but open to any off-the-shelf policy optimization method, e.g. for large-scale tasks such as NMT, we introduce PPO to replace REINFORCE, and adjust the reward generation scheme accordingly (see the paragraph “Discussion”).
label: concur

sentence: We’ve also revised Appendix A.1 to cover details of how PPO is incorporated.
label: concur

sentence: Empirically, with random parameter initialization most experiments manage to converge and give fairly good controllers.
label: concur

sentence: Almost all main results are averaged over multiple runs as explicitly indicated in the main text and the table or figure captions (e.g. see captions of Table.1 and Fig.2).
label: concur

sentence: See Fig.2 and Fig.3(R) where vertical bars indicate variances.
label: concur

sentence: We have also updated Table.1 to show the variance.
label: concur

sentence: We will release all code and trained models for reproducibility.

sentence: We’d like to clarify that we have *not* claimed that “AutoLoss can resolve mode collapse in GANs”.
label: dispute

sentence: AutoLoss improves the performance of GANs by enabling an adaptive optimization schedule than a pre-fixed one.

sentence: Our point is better and faster convergence of the model training.

sentence: >> Comment #5
label: concur

sentence: We respectfully disagree with this comment.
label: dispute

sentence: The NMT experiments aim to verify that AutoLoss can guide the multi-task optimization toward faster and better convergence on the target task, i.e. our interest is to see how the optimization goes instead of how the MT performs.
label: dispute

sentence: Held-out PPL is the direct indicator of the quality of convergence, while BLEU evaluates the MT performance.
label: dispute

sentence: Hence we believe PPL suffices as a metric to evaluate the performance of AutoLoss.

sentence: With regard to the structural choices of the attention model, our decision was based on a survey of attention-based methods used across various applications and their suitability for our problem setting.
label: concur

sentence: Our mechanism was designed such that, given a set of independent embeddings, each item in the set can be used to both extract a weighted sum of the other items as well as contribute to the weighted sums that other items extract.
label: concur

sentence: When applied to multi-agent value-function approximation, each item can belong to an agent and the separate weighted sums can be used to estimate each agent’s expected return.
label: concur

sentence: Some other choices of attention mechanisms such as RNN-based ones (widely used in NLP), while interesting, do not naturally extend to our setting as our inputs (ie embeddings from agents) do not form a natural temporal order.
label: concur

sentence: We have updated our draft to provide more insight into our choices.

sentence: While our approach does not significantly outperform the best individual baseline in each environment, it consistently performs near the top in all environments --- other methods falter in at least one of the two settings.

sentence: Our experiments on Cooperative Treasure Collection demonstrate that the general structure of our attention model (even without considering dynamic attention as in our uniform attention baseline) is able to handle large observation spaces (and relatively larger numbers of agents) better than existing approaches which concatenate observations and actions from all agents together.

sentence: Furthermore, our experiments on Rover-Tower demonstrate that the general model structure alone is not sufficient in all tasks, specifically those with separately coupled rewards for groups of agents, and dynamic attention becomes necessary.

sentence: Quantization time
label: nonarg

sentence: As we state in our paper, quantizing a ResNet-50 (quantization + finetuning steps) takes about one day on one Volta V100 GPU.
label: concur

sentence: The time of quantization is around 1 to 2 hours, the rest being dedicated to finetuning.
label: concur

sentence: Thus, the time dedicated to quantization is relatively short, especially compared with the fine-tuning and even more with the initial network training.
label: concur

sentence: This is because we optimized our EM implementation in at least two ways as detailed below.
label: concur

sentence: -	The E-step is performed on the GPU (see file src/quantization/distance.py, lines 61-75) with automatic chunking.
label: concur

sentence: This means that the code chunks the centroids and the weight matrices into blocks, performs the distance computation on those blocks and aggregates the results.
label: concur

sentence: This falls within the map/reduce paradigm.
label: concur

sentence: Note that the blocks are automatically calculated to be the largest that fit into the GPU, such that the utilization of the GPU is maximized, so as to minimize the compute time.
label: concur

sentence: -	The M-step involves calculating a solution of a least squares problem (see footnote 2 in our paper).
label: concur

sentence: The bottleneck for this is to calculate the pseudo-inverse of the activations x. However, we fix x when iterating our EM algorithm, therefore we can factor the computation of the pseudo inverse of x before alternating between the E and the M steps (see file src/quantization/solver.py and in particular the docstring).
label: concur

sentence: We provided pointers to the files in the code anonymously shared on OpenReview.

sentence: We thank the reviewer for his/her positive evaluation of our paper and for raising many very useful points which helped us getting to a clearer picture of our contribution.
label: nonarg

sentence: A few of these points deserve discussion beyond the changes made in the paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: Due to a mistake on page 2, we got the reviewer confused believing we are using importance sampling while we are using importance mixing instead.
label: dispute

sentence: This has been fixed.
label: concur

sentence: The reviewer mentions it may be possible to construct counter-examples where the gradient updates will prevent convergence.
label: nonarg

sentence: This is a very important point.
label: dispute

sentence: There are many RL problems (see e.g. Continuous Mountain Car, Colas et al. at ICML 2018) where at some point the gradient computed by the critic is deceptive, i.e. it drives the policy parameters into a wrong direction.
label: dispute

sentence: In that case, applying that gradient to CEM actors as we do in CEM-RL is counter-productive.
label: concur

sentence: But the fact that we only apply this gradient to half the population makes it that CEM-RL should nevertheless overcome this issue:  the actors which did not receive a gradient step will be selected and the population will continue improving.
label: dispute

sentence: However, admittedly, in this very specific context, CEM-RL is behaving as a CEM with only half a population, thus it is less efficient than the standard CEM.
label: concur

sentence: Besides, ERL even better resists than our approach to the same issue: if the actor generated by DDPG does not perform better than the evolutionary population due to a deceptive gradient issue, then this actor is just ignored, and the evolutionary part behaves as usual, without any loss in performance.
label: concur

sentence: This deceptive gradient issue certainly explains why CEM is the best approach on Swimmer.
label: concur

sentence: Finally, it may also happen that the RL part does not bring benefit just because the current critic is wrong and provides an inadequate gradient, in a non-deceptive gradient case.
label: concur

sentence: All the above points have now been made much clear in the new version of the paper, in particular we added an appendix dedicated to the swimmer benchmark.
label: concur

sentence: The reviewer also raises doubts about the fact that the method of Khadka & Tumer (2018) cannot be extended to use CEM.
label: nonarg

sentence: After second thoughts, this is absolutely right.
label: concur

sentence: As the reviewer says, in both this work and Khadka & Tumer, the RL updates lead to policies that may differ a lot from the search distribution and there is no guarantee in this work that the TD3 updates result in policies close to the starting point.
label: concur

sentence: But if the RL actor shows good enough performance, this does not prevent from computing a new covariance matrix which includes it.
label: dispute

sentence: The corresponding ellipsoid in the search space may be very large, leading to a widespread next generation, but the process should tend to converge again towards a population of actors where evolutionary and RL actors are closer to each other.
label: dispute

sentence: A result of these second thoughts is that one could definitely build an ERL algorithm where the evolutionary part is replaced by CEM.
label: concur

sentence: We corrected the paper according to this new insight.
label: concur

sentence: Unfortunately we did not find enough time to implement and test this algorithm during the rebuttal stage, but we now mention this possibility as an interesting avenue for future work.
label: concur

sentence: Despite the very interesting points above, the reviewer is wrong when saying that the main distinction between our approach and the ERL approach is that only in ours the information flow is from ES to RL and vice-versa.
label: dispute

sentence: Actually, in ERL, if the RL actor added to the population performs well, it will steer the whole evolutionary population to the right direction just by generating offsprings, so RL and ES also benefit from each other.
label: dispute

sentence: A lot of our effort during the rebuttal stage has been focused on better highlighting the often subtle differences between ERL and our approach.
label: nonarg

sentence: For doing so, we replaced Figure 1 with a figure directly contrasting CEM-RL to ERL.
label: concur

sentence: We also added Figure 6 which better highlights the properties of the algorithms and we performed several additional studies described either in the main text or in appendices.
label: concur

sentence: The next point of the reviewer is that a good deal of the strong performance of our method and RL may just be due to the fact that we are using multiple actors, thus benefiting from an "ensemble method" effect already mentioned in several papers such as Osband et al., 2016 for DQN.
label: nonarg

sentence: This point is absolutely valid.
label: concur

sentence: The reviewer thus suggests a relevant control which would be to keep a population (ensemble) of policies, but only update using RL while sharing experience across all actors.
label: nonarg

sentence: This would isolate the ensemble effect from the evolutionary search effect.
label: nonarg

sentence: We performed the suggested control.
label: concur

sentence: The resulting algorithm is a multiple-actor version of TD3.
label: concur

sentence: Results show that CEM-TD3 actually outperforms this multiple-actor TD3, thus the CEM part actually brings performance improvement.
label: concur

sentence: About replacing the ReLU non-linearity in DDPG and TD3 prior work with tanh, we spotted that we could get much better results on several environments with the latter.
label: concur

sentence: This explanation is now clearly mentioned in the paper, and motivates a future work direction which consists in using "neural architecture search" for RL problems, the performance of algorithms being a lot dependent on such architecture details.
label: concur

sentence: Finally, to keep our paper shorter than the hard page limit for ICLR while addressing all the reviewers points, we had to move several studies into appendices, starting with the importance mixing study.
label: concur

sentence: We are grateful for your time and comment on the work.
label: nonarg

sentence: We start by further explaining the contributions in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Our main contribution is the combination of MARL with HRL to enable the decentralized learning of controllers that can navigate and seek goals in a robotic humanoid simulation.
label: concur

sentence: The unique combination of methods allows us to learn these sophisticated controllers with far less data than methods without hierarchy (cite openAI Emergent Tool Use from Multi-Agent Interaction).
label: concur

sentence: Second, we also consider the environment in the paper another contribution.
label: concur

sentence: Few multi-agent environments simulate dynamics, and none have articulated humanoid robots that observer their world using egocentric vision.
label: concur

sentence: We plan to release this environment with the work to allow other researchers to pursue and make progress on important complex tasks.
label: concur

sentence: Many multi-agent problems have been studies using simple robot models (point-mass, etc), where more complex and realistic models have used the problem because significantly more challenging.
label: concur

sentence: However, often, an assumption can be made that the robots in the environment share similar morphology.
label: concur

sentence: We propose a method that uses a form of goal-conditioned RL to learn task agnostic low-level policies that can simplify the share control structure across robots.
label: concur

sentence: In most HRL methods, the lower level can be viewed as part of the environment, yet this restructuring of the environment enables faster and more capable learning.
label: concur

sentence: Here we clarify some of the proposed advantages of the method.
label: concur

sentence: First, the use of HRL enables temporal correlation in action exploration that helps reduce the non-stationarity challenge.
label: concur

sentence: The advantage of this temporal correlation is shown empirically in Figures 2 and 3 where the PPO policies do not improve on learning the tasks.
label: concur

sentence: This property can be understood to reduce the variance in the policy gradient.
label: concur

sentence: Instead of having the policy sample an action every step instead, the low-level policy is triggered for $k$ timesteps with a goal proposal.
label: concur

sentence: For these $k$ timesteps, no noise is added to the low-level policy outputs.
label: concur

sentence: Similarly, this $k$-step structured exploration enables learning.
label: concur

sentence: If we think of the policy as a type of VAE that is learning an encoder (high-level) that is trying to learn a good latent goal (z) that will result in the low-level performing the desired sequence of actions.
label: concur

sentence: The HRL structure is reducing the dimensionality of the control problem given a low-level designed to perform diverse behaviour wrt to the goal (cite Heess and DIAYN).
label: concur

sentence: Last, the partial parameter sharing appears to make the learning problem easier.
label: concur

sentence: We know it is challenging to learn Q functions, which implies that the centralized methods that use Q functions will not scale well.
label: concur

sentence: We compare our method to MADDPG, a popular centralized method that works by treating the problem as a single agent problem with complete information.
label: concur

sentence: In our case, this method results in a significant increase in network parameters for the Q function, which leads to poor learning performance, as can be seen in Figures 2 and 3.
label: concur

sentence: Our particular configuration allows our method to be decentralized, making the individual network for each agent more straightforward.
label: concur

sentence: We are also interested in generalization to different numbers of agents after training, which is also problematic for centralized methods.
label: concur

sentence: In short, decentralized learning will allow for more general methods, and HRL enables the learning of sophisticated controllers.
label: concur

sentence: - In general, you have to introduce the notation much more carefully.
label: nonarg

sentence: Your audience should not be expected to be experts in hashing for this venue!! 'C[1,...,B]' is informal abusive notation.
label: nonarg

sentence: You should clearly state using both mathematical notation AND using sentences what each symbol means.
label: nonarg

sentence: As stated, C[1...B] is a one-dimensional array.
label: concur

sentence: Equivalently, it is a B-dimensional vector.
label: concur

sentence: We refer to C as an “array” as opposed to “vector” for the sake of consistency with prior work on frequency estimation, and to avoid nested subscripts.
label: concur

sentence: C[b] indeed denotes the b-th element/bin of C. Regarding the notation h: U -> [B] : we use [B] to denote the set {1...B}. We define it in Section 7, but we should have defined it earlier.
label: concur

sentence: The formula h: U->[B] indeed denotes a function h that maps elements of U to {1...B}.
label: concur

sentence: - Still it is unclear where 'fj' comes from. You need to state in words eg "C[b] contains the accumulation of all fj's such that h(j)=b; i.e. for each sequence j \in U, if the hash function h maps the sequence to bin b (ie $h(j)=b$), then we include the *corresponding frequency* in the sum."
label: nonarg

sentence: We hope that after the earlier clarifications, the equation C[b] = sum_{j:h(j)=b} f_j  is more clear now.
label: concur

sentence: - What I don't understand is how fj is dependent on h. When you say "at the end of the stream", you mean that given S, we are analyzing the frequency of a series of sequences {i_1,...,i_N}?
label: nonarg

sentence: f_j does not depend on h, only on the input sequence S. Since an element j can occur anywhere in S, the equation C[b] = sum_{j:h(j)=b} f_j  holds only after the algorithm scans the whole sequence S.
label: concur

sentence: - The term "sketch" is used in Algorithm1, like 10, before 'sketch' is defined!!
label: nonarg

sentence: As explained in the description, items not stored in unique buckets “are fed to the remaining B − Br buckets using a conventional frequency estimation algorithm SketchAlg”.
label: concur

sentence: The word “sketch” in Algorithm 1 refers to the storage used by SketchAlg.
label: concur

sentence: To avoid confusion, we will shorten line 10 to “feed i to SketchAlg”.
label: concur

sentence: Thanks again, Reviewer #3, for your thought-provoking critique.
label: nonarg

sentence: We respond to your other comments below.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1.  “In particular, Section 4 is a series of empirical analyses, based on one dataset pair….However, only 1 dataset pair is experimented -- there should be more to ensure the findings generalize, since Sections 3 and 4 rely completely on empirical analysis.”
label: nonarg

sentence: See general responses #1 and #3.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2.  “It is good that Section 5 has some theoretical analysis. But I personally find it very disturbing to base it on a 2nd order approximation of a probability density function of images when modeling something as intricate as models that generate images. At least this limitation should be pointed out in the paper…
label: nonarg

sentence: .Section 5 is based on a 2nd order expansion on the $log p(x)$ given by a deep network -- I shouldn't be the judge of this, but from a realistic perspective this does not mean much.”
label: nonarg

sentence: See general response #2.
label: nonarg

sentence: We emphasize that we are not trying to approximate the density function, only approximate the difference and characterize its sign.
label: dispute

sentence: Moreover, the special structure of CV-Glow makes these derivative-based approximations better behaved and more tractable than an expansion of a generic deep neural network.
label: dispute

sentence: 3.  “Some parts of the paper feel long-winded and aimless….In general, the paper is clear and easy to understand given enough reading time, but feels at times long-winded.
label: nonarg

sentence: Section 2 background takes too much space.
label: nonarg

sentence: Section 3 too much redundancy
label: nonarg

sentence: -- it just explains that SVHN has a higher likelihood when trained on CIFAR, and a few variations of the same experiment.”
label: nonarg

sentence: We will attempt to make the writing more concise.
label: concur

sentence: But we believe that most, if not all, of Section 2 is necessary in order to make the paper self-contained and accessible to someone who has never before seen invertible generative models.
label: dispute

sentence: While we are fastidious in our experimental description in Section 3, we think it is necessary since this is the foundational section of the paper.
label: dispute

sentence: 4.  “I don't think Glow necessarily is encouraged to increase sensitivity to perturbations.
label: nonarg

sentence: The bijection needs to map training images to a high-density region of the Gaussian, and that aspect would make the model think twice before making the volume term too large.”
label: nonarg

sentence: We are not saying that the model will totally disregard the latent density and attempt to scale the input to very large or infinite values.
label: dispute

sentence: Our point is made in the context of volume term which is only one of the terms in the change-of-variable objective.
label: dispute

sentence: The log volume term in the change-of-variable objective is maximizing the very quantity (the Jacobian’s diagonal terms) that the cited work on derivative-based regularization penalties has sought to minimize.
label: dispute

sentence: The maximization of the derivatives in the objective directly implies increased sensitivity to perturbations.
label: dispute

sentence: 5.  “Figure 6(a) [Figure 5(a) in revised draft] clearly suggests that the data mean for SVHN and CIFAR are very different, instead of similar.”
label: nonarg

sentence: We are not sure how you are drawing this conclusion; perhaps from the scale of the x-axis?
label: nonarg

sentence: The histogram in Figure 6 (a) (original draft) has an x-axis covering the interval [0.4, 0.55], meaning the maximal difference between a mean in *any pair of dimensions* is 0.15.
label: dispute

sentence: Scaling back to pixel units, 0.15 * 255 = 38.25, meaning that 38.25 pixels is the maximum difference in means.
label: dispute

sentence: While this is not a difference of zero, we don’t see how you could say this “clearly suggests” that the means are “very different.”  In the latest draft, this figure---now Fig 5 (a)---has an x-axis that spans from 0-255.
label: concur

sentence: Hopefully the overlap in the means in now conspicuous.
label: concur

sentence: “However, there are papers empirically analyzing novelty detection using generative model -- should analyze or at least cite: Vít Škvára et al. Are generative deep models for novelty detection truly better? at first glance, their AUROC is never under 0.5, indicating that this phenomenon did not appear in their experiments although a lot of inlier-novelty pairs are tried.”
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for pointing us to this work.
label: nonarg

sentence: We cite it in the revised draft.
label: concur

sentence: It looks like they test on UCI data sets of dimensionality less than 200, and therefore their results speak to a much different data regime than the one we are studying.
label: dispute

sentence: 7.  “A part of the paper's contribution (section 5 conclusion) seem to overlap with others' work.
label: nonarg

sentence: The section concludes that if the second dataset has small variances, it will get higher likelihood. But this is too similar to the cited findings on page 6 (models assign high likelihood to constant images).”
label: nonarg

sentence: While we do also analyze constant images, we believe that our results for multiple data set pairs (FashionMNIST-MNIST, CIFAR10-SVHN, CelebA-SVHN, ImageNet-CIFAR10/CIFAR100/SVHN) and for multiple deep generative models (flow-based models, VAE, PixelCNN) is novel.
label: dispute

sentence: Our conclusions are arrived at through focused experimentation and a novel analytical expression applied to CV-Glow.
label: dispute

sentence: Thank you for your comments!
label: nonarg

sentence: * In our method, "``more informative" means "``less deficient".
label: dispute

sentence: We have added a figure tracing the mutual information between representation and output I(Z;Y) vs. the minimality term I(Z;X) for different values of beta (see Figure 2, lower right panel), when training with our loss function.
label: concur

sentence: This is the usual information bottleneck curve.
label: concur

sentence: The deficiency bottleneck curve (Figure 2, upper right panel) traces the corresponding sufficiency term J(Z;Y) (which is just the entropy of the labels minus our loss) vs. I(Z;X) for different values of beta.
label: nonarg

sentence: The text now makes this more explicit (see p.7, first paragraph).
label: concur

sentence: Note that for M=1, J(Z;Y) = I(Z;Y).
label: nonarg

sentence: We can see that when training with our loss, we achieve approximately the same level of sufficiency (measured in terms of I(Z;Y)) while consistently achieving more compression (note the log ordinate for I(Z;X) in the lower left panel in Fig. 2) for a wide range of beta values.
label: nonarg

sentence: * We included two new figures plotting the representation for MNIST (p. 19, Figure 7) and Fashion-MNIST (p. 19, Figure 8) in Appendix E.3 for an unsupervised version of the VDB objective (p. 18, equation 38).
label: concur

sentence: We would like to thank the reviewer for the positive feedback.
label: nonarg

sentence: We reply to the the two questions below.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: The learning procedure is confusing. It is highly recommended to provide the pseudocode of the proposed method.
label: nonarg

sentence: R1: We will provide the pseudocode in the future versions of the paper:
label: concur

sentence: Training:
label: nonarg

sentence: X_L : clean set
label: nonarg

sentence: C_L : class set
label: nonarg

sentence: X_Z : noisy set
label: nonarg

sentence: # For each class name
label: nonarg

sentence: For c in C_L:
label: nonarg

sentence: #Take the clean examples belonging to this class
label: nonarg

sentence: X_L^c : subset of X_L with label c
label: nonarg

sentence: #Only consider noisy examples with the class name in the text
label: nonarg

sentence: X_Z^c = filter_by_text(X_Z)
label: nonarg

sentence: # Build the graph for this class, and learn the GCN for cleaning
label: nonarg

sentence: A^c = build_graph(X_Z^c)
label: nonarg

sentence: M^c = GCN_model(X_L^c, X_Z^c, A^c)
label: nonarg

sentence: #Clean examples always get weight 1
label: nonarg

sentence: for i in X_L^c:
label: nonarg

sentence: #Noisy examples get the learned weight
label: nonarg

sentence: for i in X_Z^c:
label: nonarg

sentence: r_i = assign_relevance(M^c(X_Z^c(i))
label: nonarg

sentence: #Add the noisy examples to the list of training images for this class
label: nonarg

sentence: X_L^c = concatenate(X_L^c, X_z^c)
label: nonarg

sentence: #Learn a classifier jointly for all classes.
label: nonarg

sentence: Use the relevance weights for noisy examples when learning the classifier
label: nonarg

sentence: W = train_classifier(X_L^c, r)
label: nonarg

sentence: Testing
label: nonarg

sentence: Given test image Q
label: nonarg

sentence: v = extract_feature(Q)
label: nonarg

sentence: scores = W^T v
label: nonarg

sentence: prediction = argmax(scores)
label: nonarg

sentence: Q2: Since there are many tasks and each task has a large-scale data, I'm afraid that the running time will explode. How to deal with this issue?
label: nonarg

sentence: R2: The complexity is linear in the number of classes, since classes are processed independently.
label: concur

sentence: Furthermore, text filtering is applied before cleaning, which reduces the number of images to be considered for a given class.
label: concur

sentence: Please also see the response R1 to reviewer1.
label: concur

sentence: We appreciate your valuable comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: As you have said, these methods are popular in practice and achieve good performance.
label: nonarg

sentence: However, most of them are done in the setting of MCMC, and people rarely use them in nonconvex optimization.
label: nonarg

sentence: One contribution of this paper is to apply these techniques to optimization problems.
label: nonarg

sentence: Our paper also tries to understand the acceleration effect of replica exchange.
label: nonarg

sentence: We quantify it in both LDP and the convergence of chi^2 divergence.
label: nonarg

sentence: Although in Dupuis’s work, he also quantifies the acceleration effect via LDP, the LDP theory we use in this paper is different from that.
label: dispute

sentence: Specifically, his approach is based on the LDP variational theory, and ours is based on the theory of Donsker-Varadhan.
label: dispute

sentence: As a result, our rate function has different form from his.
label: dispute

sentence: In our paper, we also analyze the acceleration in the convergence of chi^2 divergence.
label: dispute

sentence: It is a new perspective and not discussed by Dupuis.
label: dispute

sentence: We emphasize that LDP and chi^2 divergence are two different approached to quantify convergence.
label: dispute

sentence: They have different meanings.
label: dispute

sentence: The first one characterizes the decay rate of the probability that the empirical measures deviate from the stationary measure and the second one characterizes the decay rate of the discrepancy between the transit distributions and limiting distribution.
label: dispute

sentence: Although the theory of LDP and convergence of chi^2 divergence for a general Markov process are well established and standard, to the best of our knowledge, our paper is the first to apply these tools in this specific problem.
label: dispute

sentence: In our paper, one contribution is that we demonstrate the acceleration effect of replica exchange mathematically.
label: dispute

sentence: We first show that the LDP rate function is boosted by replica exchange.
label: dispute

sentence: Dupuis’s work includes similar results but in a different form.
label: dispute

sentence: We also show that the derivative of chi^2 divergence is boosted.
label: dispute

sentence: Specifically, we demonstrate that a strict positive term caused by the replica exchange is added, if the density ratio between current distribution and limiting distribution is not symmetric.
label: dispute

sentence: We say that a function is symmetric if we swap the positions of variables, the function value does not change.
label: dispute

sentence: In this case, the derivative of chi^2 divergence is strictly boosted, and hence, the convergence is accelerated strictly.
label: dispute

sentence: It reflects the benefits of replica exchange.
label: dispute

sentence: To the best of our knowledge, this phenomenon has never been observed by previous literature, including Dupuis’s paper.
label: dispute

sentence: We think it is interesting and useful.
label: dispute

sentence: Another contribution of our paper is the discretization algorithm.
label: dispute

sentence: In practice, it is impossible to simulate the continuous process directly, and discretization is necessary.
label: dispute

sentence: To the best of our knowledge, no one has discussed the discretization of replica exchange Langevin diffusion before.
label: dispute

sentence: Our paper is the first one to analyze the discretization theoretically.
label: dispute

sentence: In this paper, we establish the linear convergence rate for the discretization error, which is highly trivial since the process has state-dependent jumps.
label: dispute

sentence: This result, combined with the acceleration effect, justifies the empirical success of the replica exchange Langevin diffusion in practice.
label: dispute

sentence: Thank you for the time and effort spent reviewing our paper, and for the detailed suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: Below we repeat the questions/comments from the review and respond to each in turn.
label: nonarg

sentence: “The paper positions itself generally as dealing with arbitrary transformations T, but really is about angular transformations (e.g. Definition 3.1).
label: nonarg

sentence: The generalization is relatively straightforward and was not too surprising given the APG theory.
label: concur

sentence: The paper would gain in clarity if its scope was narrowed.”
label: nonarg

sentence: Our MPG framework not only supports the angular transformation but also covers the recently proposed clipped transformation in CAPG [Fujita and Maeda, 2018].
label: dispute

sentence: The theoretical result is tighter than the one in [Fujita and Maeda, 2018], and it supports general transformations instead of only clipped actions.
label: dispute

sentence: "I am not convinced that the measure theoretic perspective is always necessary to convey the insights, although I appreciate the desire for technical correctness." / "Generally speaking it seems like a lot of technicalities for a relatively simple result: marginalizing a distribution onto a lower-dimensional surface."
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree that the measure theoretic approach is not always necessary (indeed for angular actions, it is not needed), but it is necessary for a very common scenario -- clipped actions.
label: dispute

sentence: Researchers and practitioners both almost always clip actions when using policy gradient algorithms for robotics control environments (read: MuJoCo tasks).
label: dispute

sentence: Recently, a reduced variance method was introduced by Fujita and Maeda (2018) for clipped action spaces.
label: dispute

sentence: Their algorithm is also a member of the marginal policy gradients family and our theoretical results for MPG significantly tighten the existing analysis of that algorithm.
label: dispute

sentence: "It's hard for me to judge of the experimental results of section 5.3, given that there are no other benchmarks or provided reference paper. As a whole, I see APG as providing a minor benefit over PG."
label: nonarg

sentence: For the results in Section 5.3, the issue is that currently, there are no benchmark environments for directional control.
label: dispute

sentence: We anticipate that in the future this may change (e.g. console and PC games often have directional controls).
label: dispute

sentence: “What does E_{pi|s} refer to in Eqn 4.1?”
label: nonarg

sentence: The expectation is taken with respect to the policy \pi conditioned on the current state s (s here is arbitrary, but fixed).
label: concur

sentence: Stated differently, we are taking the expectation with respect to the distribution $\pi(\cdot | s,\theta)$.
label: concur

sentence: “Can you clarify what it means for the map T to be a sufficient statistic for theta? (Theorem 4.6)”
label: nonarg

sentence: We have now removed this part of the statement because we are no longer absolutely certain of its correctness, and because it is not used anywhere else in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: “Experiment 5.1: Why would we expect APG with a 2d Gaussian to perform better than a 1d Gaussian on the angle?”
label: nonarg

sentence: Because using a 1D Gaussian requires either (1) clipping the angle to [0,2\pi) before execution in the environment and making updates using the clipped output or (2) using the sampled angle for updates and perform the clipping in the environment.
label: concur

sentence: In the first case, this approach is asymmetric in that does not place similar probability on $\mu_{\theta}(s) - \epsilon$ and $\mu_{\theta}(s) + \epsilon$ for $\mu_{\theta}(s)$ near to $0$ and $2\pi$. In the second case, this requires approximating a periodic function.
label: concur

sentence: We include both these reasons at the start of Section 3.
label: concur

sentence: Lastly, thank you for the concrete suggestions:
label: nonarg

sentence: "Def 4.4: "a notion of Fisher information" -- maybe "variant" is better than "notion", which implies there are different kinds of Fisher information
label: nonarg

sentence: Def 3.1 mu is overloaded: parameter or measure?
label: nonarg

sentence: 4.4, law of total variation -- define "
label: nonarg

sentence: We have addressed these and uploaded a new draft to reflect the changes.
label: concur

sentence: For the last suggestion, we currently define the law of total variance(variation) in the preliminaries so we did not repeat the definition in Section 4.4.
label: dispute

sentence: We now write "law of total variance" instead of "law of total variation" to avoid any ambiguity.
label: concur

sentence: Pipelined backpropagation is similar to model parallelism but it addresses the resource underutilization issue in model parallelism.
label: dispute

sentence: Our pipelined method might look like async-SGD on surface.
label: dispute

sentence: However, async-SGD (e.g. Dean et al., pointed out by Reviewer 4) utilizes data parallelism (as indicated in Dean el al.) and a parameter server to keep track of model parameters (weights).
label: dispute

sentence: In contrast, our pipelined method does not use any parameter server.
label: dispute

sentence: Furthermore, each accelerator obtains a replica of a full model in asycn-SGD training while each accelerator contains only a part of the model in our pipelined method, on the assumption that the full model does not fit into the memory of a single accelerator.
label: dispute

sentence: The accuracy drops for some models in a pure pipelined training.
label: concur

sentence: However, hybrid training is able to bring the accuracy of most networks studied in our paper up to a comparable level of the non-pipelined baseline as shown in the evaluation section of our paper.
label: concur

sentence: Our pipelined method is different from data parallelism in the following way (for a 2-GPU example).
label: concur

sentence: For data parallelism, a model is duplicated and placed onto 2 GPUs, each GPU containing a full copy of the model.
label: concur

sentence: On the other hand, for pipelined parallelism, a model is divided into two partitions (on the assumption that it cannot fit in a single device): one is mapped onto GPU 0 while the other is mapped onto GPU 1, each GPU obtaining only a part of the model.
label: concur

sentence: Communication between these two partitions is necessary to enable activation and gradient transfers.
label: concur

sentence: Regardless of the parallelization techniques, the maximum speedup of a 2-GPU system is 2X compared to a 1-GPU system.
label: concur

sentence: To obtain a close to perfect speedup of 2X, the communication overhead must be almost non-existent and the workload needs to be perfectly balanced between the 2 GPUs.
label: concur

sentence: In our implementation, we obtained a speedup of 1.81X for ResNet-362, which is equivalent to 90% utilization of each GPU.
label: concur

sentence: Thus, our sentence the reviewer refers to.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for pointing out the accuracy of ResNet-20 (similar to Reviewer 1).
label: nonarg

sentence: Again, we think the exact inference accuracy of the model is somewhat orthogonal to our study.
label: concur

sentence: It is the trend of the decline in inference accuracy with pipelining is what we study.
label: concur

sentence: This trend exists with both our hyperparameters and those at, for example, https://github.com/akamaster/pytorch_resnet_cifar10.
label: concur

sentence: The use of these set of hyperparameters, obtains an inference accuracy of 91.65% (better than the accuracy stated in the original ResNet paper) for ResNet-20 non-pipelined baseline and 91.21% for pipelined version.
label: concur

sentence: We are not aware of any reports of an accuracy of ResNet-20 at 92% (perhaps this is approximate).
label: dispute

sentence: Please kindly let us know a pointer.
label: nonarg

sentence: It is relatively easy to update our results in the paper with new hyperparameters.
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank a lot for the comments with cares and insights, which are helpful for improving the quality and readability of our writing.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have addressed all the comments as follows:
label: nonarg

sentence: Response #1: In the revision, we have added the following justification and explanations on privacy quantification in Section 2, 4 and 5.
label: dispute

sentence: First, there is no single standard definition of data privacy-preserving problems and corresponding adversary attacks.
label: dispute

sentence: And a fundamental problem in it is the natural tradeoff between privacy and utility, which is affected by different data privacy-preserving methods.
label: dispute

sentence: Our key contribution in this paper is the RAN framework and the training algorithm, which can accommodate different choices of privacy attackers and privacy quantification.
label: dispute

sentence: Second, finding the right measurement for privacy is an open problem in itself.
label: dispute

sentence: To evaluate RAN, one has to pick some quantifications.
label: dispute

sentence: In the present paper, we chose the “reconstructive error” as the quantification of privacy because it is the most intuitive one to measure the risk of disclosing sensitive background information in the raw data for the given perturbed data (Encoder output).
label: dispute

sentence: Third, in the future, we will evaluate RAN using other quantifications of privacy as well in a definitely defined application.
label: dispute

sentence: For example, we could measure the privacy by the hidden failure, i.e., the ratio between the background patterns that were discovered based on RAN’s Encoder output, and the sensitive patterns founded from the raw data, in the object recognition application.
label: dispute

sentence: Response #2: Great help.
label: nonarg

sentence: In the revision, we have added more experiments (with more \lambda settings in RAN) to plot the full Pareto Front of three baselines and RAN, and revised the explanations in Section 3.1.
label: concur

sentence: And we also noted that the parameter \lambda can be fine-tuned, e.g., exponentially varied, to read a better tradeoff.
label: concur

sentence: Response #3: Thanks for pointing out the problems in Eq. 1.
label: nonarg

sentence: The utility is evaluated as the accuracy of a Classifier, i.e., the probability Yi=Yi’, which is a commonly used metric .
label: concur

sentence: And we adopted some randomness, e.g., dropout, in the parametric discriminative models (Encoder and Classifier).
label: concur

sentence: Response #4: We have added more clarifications on the privacy definition in Section 2.1.
label: concur

sentence: In particular, the privacy of Max Min |Ii-Ii’|^2 is defined for each data rather than a dataset, which is different from any anonymization based data privacy-preserving techniques.
label: concur

sentence: Response #5: Although we can plug in any adversary architecture (Decoder) and privacy quantification in RAN, this paper adopts the worst possible Decoder to mirror the Encoder’s architecture.
label: concur

sentence: That is, we assume a powerful adversary that knows the Encoder in the training.
label: concur

sentence: “An exactly reversed model” stands for a layer-by-layer deconvolutional model (Decoder) with known Encoder’s convolution filter number and size, pooling size and each layer’s connection relationship.
label: concur

sentence: In the revision, we have added above clarification in section 2.3.
label: concur

sentence: Response #6: Thanks for the comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We call Eq. 3 and Eq.4 adversarial, as explained in out intuition, they need not be opposite all the time.
label: concur

sentence: And we agree that the resulting model is highly affected by the setting of hyper-parameters n and k. In particular, we have compared the settings of k=1, k=2, k=3, and k=4 for each task and finally select the best overall value k=3.
label: concur

sentence: As for the number of epoch n, it depends on the usual practices of developers for an acceptable converged result.
label: concur

sentence: In our experiments, we use n=10,000 for MNIST, UbiSound and Har with batch size=128, and adopt n=20,000 for CIFAR-10 and ImageNet with batch size=256 and batch size=512, respectively.
label: concur

sentence: In fact, we have already conducted exhaustive micro-benchmark experiments to determine the current design of RAN.
label: concur

sentence: For example, we adopt different options of model architectures, nine weight updating schemes on when and what order to update Encoder, Decoder and Classifier,  and several settings of the important hyper-parameters (e.g., “n” and “k”) to select the empirically optimized one.
label: concur

sentence: However, we didn’t present the micro-benchmark results in this paper due to the space limit.
label: concur

sentence: In the revision, we have added more explanations on the selection of n and k in Section 2.4.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for your detailed reviews and constructive suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have added the suggested baselines in the revision.
label: concur

sentence: Here are our responses to your questions and comments:
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. Equation 1 typo?
label: nonarg

sentence: It is not a typo.
label: dispute

sentence: Our reward function is different from existing curiosity reward.
label: dispute

sentence: We are using the change of the real time m^t and m^{t-1} as the reward for inciting behavioral change from the demonstrator.
label: dispute

sentence: We have shown more analysis and visualization to explain why this works in the new revision (Appendix B.2 & B.3).
label: concur

sentence: Our “self-supervised” baseline is actually using the prediction loss as reward, and it has a worse performance compared to ours.
label: concur

sentence: 2. Baseline missing: Random actions from expert
label: nonarg

sentence: Figure 5 shows the results where 10% actions from the demonstrator are purely random.
label: concur

sentence: With the randomness, our approach is still be able to find meaningful probing policy.
label: concur

sentence: We have also evaluated the success rate when we use the policy learned from the suboptimal demonstration (10% random actions).
label: concur

sentence: As reported in the updated Table 1, this policy is comparable to the one learned from optimal demonstrations, and it still outperforms baselines which are all trained from optimal demonstrations.
label: concur

sentence: 3. Baseline missing: Simple RNN policies that communicate hidden states
label: nonarg

sentence: We have evaluated this baseline in the revision (i.e., the “2-LSTM” baseline).
label: concur

sentence: The network architecture is illustrated in Figure 16.
label: concur

sentence: It indeed performs much worse than our full model.
label: concur

sentence: 4. Ablation study for the importance of fusion
label: nonarg

sentence: We have added the result of this baseline (i.e., the “ours w/o fusion” baseline), where we concatenate the state feature and the latent vector m^t together.
label: concur

sentence: The results have validated the importance of using the attention-based fusion layer.
label: concur

sentence: 5. Generalizability argument
label: nonarg

sentence: Our main idea is to show as many configurations as possible to the learner by learning a good probing policy.
label: dispute

sentence: Since the probing always starts from a single setting, there is indeed a limit in terms of how different the new settings could be.
label: dispute

sentence: E.g., in Maze Navigation, it is impossible for the learner to change the room layout drastically in the time limit, so the learned policy won’t make sense in a very different room layout (e.g., 8 rooms instead of 4 rooms).
label: dispute

sentence: To obtain a better generalization, we may need to use a better imitation learning approach to replace the current one (behavioral cloning), and possibly using multiple starting configurations.
label: dispute

sentence: But we think that it is somewhat orthogonal to our main contribution.
label: dispute

sentence: The objective of our approach is to discover more diverse settings/configurations and consequently improve whatever imitation learning approach we actually use.
label: dispute

sentence: Thank you for your review, below we answer the points that were questioned.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. We did not do experiments with such generator architecture.

sentence: 2. Indeed we believe that the use of the ensemble of random window discriminators was the main factor behind the performance we obtained.

sentence: As can be seen in Table 1.

sentence: , (a) already brings a huge improvement (from ~1.9 to ~3.4 MOS).
label: concur

sentence: (b) and (c) also seem to be important; we have considered fixing the window size or using only conditional RWDs, but all of such trials turned out considerably worse.
