sentence: Q2. Whole sequence reconstruction results:
label: nonarg

sentence: Our current implementation only allows up to 5 images in a single 2015 TITANX GPU with 12GB memories.
label: concur

sentence: This is because we implemented the whole pipeline using tensorflow in python, which is memory inefficient, especially during training.
label: concur

sentence: Each image takes about 2.3GB memory on average, and most of the memory is consumed by the CNN features and matrix operation.
label: concur

sentence: But it is straightforward to concatenate multiple 5-frame segments to reconstruct a complete sequence, which is demonstrated in the comparison with CodeSLAM in Figure 7 of the revised version.
label: concur

sentence: It is also straightforward to implement our BA-Layer in CUDA directly to reduce the memory consumption of matrix operation and push the number of frames.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you very much for the feedback.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have updated the paper and included a new section (4.3) showing how pGAN attacks bypass 4 different defence mechanisms, including outlier detection (as in Paudice et al. 2018a), the PCA-based defence in Rubinstein et al. 2009 (Antidote), Sever (Diakonikolas et al ICML 2019), and label sanitization
label: concur

sentence: (Paudice et al. 2018b)
label: concur

sentence: From the reviewer’s comments we noticed that, perhaps, the submitted paper, may not have sufficiently clearly explained that the approach is already targeting defences based on outlier detection and in particular that proposed in Paudice et al. 2018a.
label: concur

sentence: We already assume that the defender is in control of a fraction of trusted (clean) data points to train the outlier detector, which is a strong assumption in favour of the defender.
label: nonarg

sentence: To make this point clearer, we have also updated Figure 2 in the paper, showing the performance of pGAN for alpha = 0, i.e. when no detectability constraints are considered.
label: concur

sentence: In the Figure, we can observe that both for MNIST and FMNIST the outlier detection is capable of detecting many poisoning points and the effect of the attack is reduced compared with the results for alpha = 0.1.
label: nonarg

sentence: Different outlier-detection-based defences have already been proposed in the literature, such as Steinhardt et al. 2017 (“Certified defenses for data poisoning attacks”), Koh et al. 2018 (“Stronger data poisoning attacks break data sanitization defenses”) or Paudice et al. 2018a, to cite some.
label: nonarg

sentence: In our experiments we chose the scheme proposed by Paudice et al. 2018a, as it assumes a stronger model for the defender (as mentioned before), which, in our opinion helps to validate the effectiveness of pGAN to craft successful poisoning attacks even in cases where the defender is in control of a fraction of trusted (clean) data points.
label: nonarg

sentence: Label sanitization (as proposed in Paudice et al. 2018b) completely fails to defend against pGAN attack, as shown in Figure 8 (right).
label: nonarg

sentence: As pGAN produces poisoning points that are correlated, the KNN-based algorithm proposed to do the relabelling is not capable of detecting the poisoning points.
label: nonarg

sentence: Moreover, some of the genuine points from the target class are incorrectly relabelled, making the problem even worse.
label: nonarg

sentence: The PCA-based defence proposed by Rubinstein et al. 2009 (Antidote) is also not capable of mitigating pGAN attack.
label: nonarg

sentence: The detectability constraints included in our model prevents this defence to detect the generated poisoning points.
label: nonarg

sentence: In the supplement we have included an analysis of the sensitivity of this algorithm to the threshold to discard training points.
label: nonarg

sentence: We can observe that the error increases as we increase this threshold.
label: nonarg

sentence: The “Sever” defence (Diakonikolas et al. 2019 ICML) is also not robust against pGAN attack.
label: nonarg

sentence: In Figure 8 (left) we can observe that the defence performs worse than the outlier detector and that, when the algorithm is not under attack, the performance slightly decreases, as the algorithm is removing genuine data points that are significant for the training process.
label: nonarg

sentence: For FMNIST, Sever outperforms the outlier detector when the number of poisoning points is reduced, although the degradation of the algorithm as we increase the fraction of poisoning points is faster compared to the outlier detector and the PCA-based defence.
label: nonarg

sentence: In the supplement we included the sensitivity analysis w.r.t. the parameter that controls the fraction of points to be discarded.
label: nonarg

sentence: We can observe that, in this case, the difference in performance is not significant for the different values explored for this threshold.
label: nonarg

sentence: In summary, the revised paper (see the new version uploaded) now provides a comprehensive comparison of different defence mechanisms and shows the effectiveness of pGAN to bypass all of them.
label: nonarg

sentence: First in Figure 2 we show the effect of the attack for different values of alpha tested against the outlier-detection-based defence.
label: nonarg

sentence: Then, we have provided an empirical evaluation of pGAN against 4 different defence mechanisms both in MNIST and FMNIST, showing how our attack bypasses all of these defences.
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank the reviewer for this valuable comment, which has certainly helped us to improve the paper.

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the comments and appreciate that the reviewer likes our idea of including optimization in the network. But our contribution is beyond adopting Levenberg-Marquardt instead of Gauss-Newton.
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to clarify several things to address the reviewer's concerns:
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1. The advantages of Levenberg-Marquardt over Gauss-Newton is unclear (the main reason for rejection):
label: nonarg

sentence: Firstly, we want to clarify that our contribution is beyond improving the Gauss-Newton optimization to Levenberg-Marquardt.
label: dispute

sentence: More importantly, our contribution is the combination of conventional multi-view geometry (i.e. joint optimization of depth and camera poses) and end-to-end deep learning (I.e. depth basis generator learning and feature learning).
label: dispute

sentence: This contribution is achieved by our differentiable LM optimization that allows end-to-end training.
label: dispute

sentence: Secondly, we agree with the reviewer that comparing with the Gauss-Newton algorithm will be interesting and have updated such a comparison in Appendix B in the revised version according to the reviewer’s suggestions:
label: concur

sentence: 1. We retrained the whole pipeline with Gauss-Newton, to make sure the features are learned specifically for Gauss-Newton.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2. We compared with various constant lambda values to see how the performance varies along with lambda.
label: nonarg

sentence: Note that we also fine-tune the network to make sure the features fit different lambda.
label: nonarg

sentence: In Table 4 of the revised version (Appendix B), our method outperforms the Gauss-Newton algorithm in the last column.
label: concur

sentence: This is because the objective function to be optimized is non-convex, and the vanilla Gauss-Newton method might get stuck at saddle point or local minimum.
label: concur

sentence: This is why the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm is the standard choice for conventional bundle adjustment.
label: concur

sentence: In Figure 6 of the revised version (Appendix B), our method also consistently performs better than different constant lambda values.
label: concur

sentence: This is because the value of lambda should be adapted to different data and optimization iterations.
label: concur

sentence: There is no ‘optimal’ constant lambda for all data and iterations.
label: concur

sentence: Comparison with CodeSLAM:
label: other

sentence: We have included that in Figure 7 of the revised version (Appendix E).
label: concur

sentence: Since there is no public code for CodeSLAM, we cite its results directly from the CodeSLAM paper.
label: concur

sentence: Q3. The state vector Chi is not defined for the proposed method.
label: nonarg

sentence: The Chi is defined in Section 3 as the vector containing all camera poses and point depths.
label: concur

sentence: Since our method also solves for these unknowns as in classic methods, we did not redefine the Chi.
label: concur

sentence: But in the revised version we have recapped the definition of Chi when introducing our method at the beginning of Section 4.
label: concur

sentence: Q4. Should the paper be called Bundle Adjustment?:
label: nonarg

sentence: The term ‘Bundle Adjustment’ is originally used to refer to the joint optimization of 3D scene points and camera poses by minimizing the reprojection error.
label: dispute

sentence: The keyword Bundle comes from the fact that a bundle of camera view rays pass through each of the 3D scene points.
label: dispute

sentence: Multiple recent works, e.g. [Engel et al., 2017,Delaunoy and Pollefeys, 2014], have generalized it to “photometric BA” where scene points and camera poses are optimized together by minimizing the photometric error.
label: dispute

sentence: Our method is along this line.
label: dispute

sentence: But we further improve the photometric error to featuremetric error.
label: dispute

sentence: Each 3D scene point is still constrained by a bundle of camera view rays, though the error function has been changed.
label: dispute

sentence: So we believe it is justified to call this method feature-metric BA.
label: dispute

sentence: But we agree with the reviewer that the word ‘reprojection’ is misleading when we introduce our feature-metric BA and the photometric BA.
label: concur

sentence: So we use the word ‘align’ as the reviewer suggested and use ‘reprojection’ only for the geometric BA.
label: concur

sentence: Q5. Is B the same for all scenes?:
label: nonarg

sentence: In the revised version, We added Figure 8 to visualize of the term B in Equation 7 (Page 6) for different scenes.
label: concur

sentence: We can clearly see that it is scene dependent.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q6.Typos:
label: nonarg

sentence: We have fixed all the typos as suggested in the revised version.
label: concur

sentence: We summarize the main contributions of the paper as follows:
label: nonarg

sentence: - In the theoretical part, we provided more concise convergence rate analysis for stochastic momentum methods in the non-convex setting.
label: nonarg

sentence: This was made possible by a sharp estimate of the accumulated momentum terms (Lemma B1).
label: nonarg

sentence: We believe this is an important but under-explored topic (Yan et al., 2018).
label: nonarg

sentence: - In the experimental part, we empirically showed that the proposed optimisation algorithms have potential to solve realistic problems.
label: nonarg

sentence: We are not claiming these variants will outperform all other methods in all training cases, but we sincerely believe that the results are promising.
label: nonarg

sentence: In particular, we have demonstrated their potential benefits of mitigating gradient vanishing and combining other techniques for accelerating optimization.
label: nonarg

sentence: We do admit the gap between our theoretical analysis and experiments in the sense that the analysis does not account for the initial acceleration observed in many experiments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We think this is a very interesting question for future research and hope that this paper can motivate further research in this area.
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree with your intuition that this may have something to do with $\gamma\in (0,1)$ boosting the gradients.
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to thank the reviewer for the positive feedback.
label: nonarg

sentence: We reply to the the two questions below.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: For the motivation of this method, why would the graph be constructed within each class? If there is a correlation between different classes, how could the model use such class-wise correlation to clean the label?
label: nonarg

sentence: R1: The most general graph would be constructed based on image and text similarities combined.
label: concur

sentence: Here, we pre-filter with text similarity, i.e., label names, and then build the graph based on visual similarities.
label: concur

sentence: This permits (a) to significantly reduce the size of the graph and hence the complexity and (b) to reduce the noise during the cleaning task.
label: concur

sentence: We agree that operating on the more complex graph could be the subject of future research, but a significantly different method would be required and the gain of the correlation is not granted.
label: concur

sentence: Q2: Maybe I missed it, but how is the relevance score / predicted label determined for testing data given the graphs constructed in each class of training data?
label: nonarg

sentence: R2: There is no relevance score assigned to the test data.
label: concur

sentence: Relevance scores are only used during training.
label: concur

sentence: In particular, we build per-class graphs using the training data, assign each training example a relevance score (Section 4), and train a classifier using the training data and the corresponding relevance scores (Section 5).
label: concur

sentence: Now given a test image, a prediction is simply made by the classifier; no data or relevance scores are used.
label: concur

sentence: See also pseudo-code in response R1 to reviewer 3.
label: concur

sentence: Thanks for your comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: Below we address the detailed comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: In particular, we clarify the potential misunderstanding on the linearity of the discriminator and added new state-of-the-art results by applying negative feedback to SN-GAN.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: About novelty and analysis:
label: nonarg

sentence: A1: As agreed by both Reviewer #2 and Reviewer #3, in this paper, our contributions are twofold: (1) a unified and promising framework to model the stability of GANs using control theory, (2) we propose to use the negative feedback to stabilize GANs.
label: nonarg

sentence: First, using control theory, the dynamics of GANs can be modeled as transfer functions with Laplacian transformation, and various existing methods (e.g., Negative Momentum and Reg-GAN) can be considered as certain controllers that are widely used in control theory.
label: nonarg

sentence: Moreover, through control theory, the stability of GANs can be easily inferred from the poles of the transfer function, instead of analyzing the complicated jacobian matrix of the dynamics as discussed in Sec. 4.1 and Appendix A&C. We argue that our method is distinct from existing method, which is well-discussed in our response to Q4.
label: nonarg

sentence: Second, our perspective also provides a promising direction that can further benefit the training dynamics of GANs using advanced control methods (e.g., nonlinear control and  modern control theory [*2]) to improve both the stability and the convergence speed of GAN.
label: nonarg

sentence: As a concrete example, we propose to use the most widely-used negative feedback control method to stabilize GAN's dynamics and the empirical results demonstrate the effectiveness of NF-GAN as shown in Sec. 4&6.
label: nonarg

sentence: Exploring advanced control methods is our important future work.
label: nonarg

sentence: We updated the empirical results on the state-of-the-art model in the revision, where we applied our proposed NF-GAN to the SN-GAN [*6].
label: nonarg

sentence: We can see that NF-GAN can successfully address the potential unstable issues of SN-GAN and achieve state-of-the-art inception score on CIFAR-10.
label: nonarg

sentence: More details can be found in our response to the common concern and our revised paper.
label: concur

sentence: Q2: Linear discriminator and extending the analysis to realistic settings:
label: nonarg

sentence: A2: Thanks.
label: nonarg

sentence: We indeed extended the analysis of Dirac GAN to the more realistic setting in Sec. 3.2, where the discriminator is NOT linear.
label: nonarg

sentence: In this part, we analyzed the dynamics of WGAN in the function space following [*1], i.e., we directly modeled $D(t, x)$ and $G(t, z)$ for all $x$ and $z$. It avoids the nonlinearity issue caused by the neural network, and both G and D are linear dynamics, at least locally around the equilibrium, as discussed in Sec. 3.2 and Appendix D in the revision.
label: concur

sentence: Fig. 2 (right) provides a diagram of the unregularized WGAN.
label: concur

sentence: In practice, we use the gradient descent method in the parameter space to approximate the dynamics in the functional space to efficiently solve the optimization problem.
label: nonarg

sentence: Recent advances in modeling GAN in the functional space [*5] provide powerful tools to bridge the gap and we leave it as our future work.
label: nonarg

sentence: We updated the discussion in Sec. 3.2 in the revision to make this clearer.
label: concur

sentence: Q3: The Lip constraints on the discriminator:
label: nonarg

sentence: A3: Actually, our method also applies to WGAN with Lipschitz constraints (vanilla WGAN).
label: dispute

sentence: Existing work [*3] states that vanilla WGAN diverges and we provide theoretical and empirical evidence that our method helps vanilla WGAN converge.
label: dispute

sentence: Theoretically, to address this comment, we added Theorem 1 (See in the Appendix D) that states the dynamics of $D$ with Lipschitz constraint follows Eqn. (10) *around the equilibrium*. Therefore, the stability analysis and our proposed method in Sec. 4 still applies to vanilla WGAN because control theory mainly focuses on the stability *around the equilibrium* [*2].
label: concur

sentence: Empirically, as suggested by R#3, we built a vanilla WGAN baseline using the SN-GAN [*6] framework, whose Lipschitz constraints are satisfied through spectral normalizations.
label: nonarg

sentence: We compared SN-GAN (WGAN loss) and NF-SN-GAN (WGAN loss) and obtained a significant improvement on both the stability and the final results (IS from 3.29 to 8.28, See details in our post for common concerns).
label: nonarg

sentence: It demonstrates that our method helps vanilla WGAN converge, which is consistent with our theoretical analysis.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q4: Related work:
label: nonarg

sentence: A4: Thanks for pointing out the related work. In fact, our method is distinct from these methods.
label: concur

sentence: For the first paper (i.e., Gradient descent GAN optimization is locally stable) analyzed the stability of GANs using the Jacobian matrix and adopted a regularization term to stabilize GANs similarly to [*4].
label: concur

sentence: Instead, we adopted a different method to model the dynamics from control theory.
label: concur

sentence: The difference has been discussed in Sec. 1 and Sec. 5
label: concur

sentence: For the second paper, the authors used the Lyapunov function, which is different from our framework, to analyze the stability of GANs.
label: concur

sentence: Besides, their method fails to scale-up to large datasets such as CIFAR-10 because of computational issues.
label: concur

sentence: Q5: Empirical results:
label: nonarg

sentence: A5: Theoretically, Reg-GAN is also a stable training method for GANs but it is computationally less efficient than NF-GAN (ours), as illustrated in Fig. 4.
label: concur

sentence: Empirically, we can achieve better results compared to Reg-GAN as illustrated in Table 1 (top).
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, we also also advanced the state-of-the-art results based on practical GANs (SN-GAN).
label: concur

sentence: The inception score on CIFAR-10 is improved from 8.22 to 8.45.
label: concur

sentence: See details in Table 1 (bottom) in the revision and our post about common concerns.
label: concur

sentence: [*1] Johnson, Rie, and Tong Zhang. "Composite Functional Gradient Learning of Generative Adversarial Models." International Conference on Machine Learning. 2018.
label: nonarg

sentence: [*2] Khalil, Hassan K. "Nonlinear systems." Upper Saddle River (2002).
label: nonarg

sentence: [*3] Mescheder, Lars, Andreas Geiger, and Sebastian Nowozin. "Which Training Methods for GANs do actually Converge?." International Conference on Machine Learning. 2018.
label: nonarg

sentence: [*4] Mescheder, Lars, Sebastian Nowozin, and Andreas Geiger. "The numerics of gans." Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems. 2017.
label: nonarg

sentence: [*5] Johnson, Rie, and Tong Zhang. "Composite Functional Gradient Learning of Generative Adversarial Models." International Conference on Machine Learning. 2018.
label: nonarg

sentence: [*6] Miyato, Takeru, et al. "Spectral Normalization for Generative Adversarial Networks." (2018).
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank the reviewer for his comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We address the comments about novelty in our general response ( https://openreview.net/forum?id=HkMlGnC9KQ&noteId=S1eid00WaQ ), for instance concerning the relationship to previous work, and the regularization penalty ||f||_M we propose.
label: concur

sentence: More detailed comments are addressed below.
label: nonarg

sentence: weakness of adversarial training
label: nonarg

sentence: As noted in our general response, our ||f||_M regularization approach empirically yields models with a more useful certified generalization guarantee in the presence of adversaries on Cifar10, while PGD adversarial training would likely require local verification of robustness around each test example, and we are not aware of useful guarantees on adversarial generalization for such models.
label: concur

sentence: We agree that this aspect is not clear in the current submission, and we will improve it in the next version.
label: concur

sentence: * relationship with traditional RKHS regularization
label: nonarg

sentence: There is indeed no question that kernel methods/RKHSs have been widely used for regularization of non-linear functions, for over 20 years now, however these methods typically rely on solving convex optimization problems using the kernel trick, or various kernel approximations (such as random Fourier features).
label: concur

sentence: Separately, defining RKHSs that contain neural networks has indeed been the study of previous work, such as Bietti and Mairal (2018) or Zhang et al. (2016; 2017), however these only study theoretical properties of the kernel mapping and the RKHS norm, or derive convex learning procedures to replace training neural networks.
label: concur

sentence: Our approach is quite different, in that we leverage these insights to obtain practical regularization strategies for generic neural networks.
label: concur

sentence: ** new regularization methods
label: nonarg

sentence: In addition to the ||f||_M lower bound penalty discussed in our general response, we note that combined approaches based on lower bound + upper bound methods are also novel to the best of our knowledge, and in particular we found combining robust optimization techniques with spectral norm constraints to be quite successful in many of the small data scenarios considered (see Table 1).
label: concur

sentence: We will happily clarify some of these points in an updated version of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for your careful reading and comments!
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: We are evaluating the proposed metrics on more recent GAN-based models you suggested and will update the results once the results become available.
label: concur

sentence: Q2: The main contribution is listed as follows:
label: concur

sentence: 1. A pilot study of mode collapse existence in GAN.

sentence: Thank you again for your careful reading and kindly identifying the typos in our paper! We will fix these typos and meticulously proofread our article.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the comments with cares and insights, which are helpful for improving the quality and readability of our paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: We are glad that you support our paper.
label: concur

sentence: We have addressed all the comments as follows:
label: nonarg

sentence: Response #1: In the revision, we had added a new experiment to zoom in on two categories for clearer utility visualization.
label: concur

sentence: In particular, we show the DNN’s deep features and RAN’s Encoder output to illustrate how they push the features to cluster with the “car with/without road” & “sailboat with/without water” images in the feature space.
label: nonarg

sentence: Response #2: We agree that we should provide more details about the decoders.
label: concur

sentence: Generally, we set the Decoder to mirror the Encoder's architecture.
label: concur

sentence: That is, we assume a powerful adversary that knows the Encoder in training.
label: concur

sentence: Because the Encoders are different for different tasks, the Encoders are different too.
label: concur

sentence: In particular, we select the architecture of Encoder plus Classifier to be LeNet for MNIST, Ubisound and Har, to be AlexNet for CIFAR-10, and to be VGG-16 for ImageNet.
label: concur

sentence: The architectures of Encoder in four cases are different, so the Decoder is varied as well.
label: concur

sentence: In the revision, we have added above explanations about Decoder in Section 2.3 and in experiment settings of Section 3.
label: concur

sentence: Response #3: We agree that the description of three baselines should be more precise, especially the DNN and DNN(resized) baseline.
label: concur

sentence: In the revision, we have added explanations on the difference/similarity between DNN (resized) and DNN baselines. And explain why we include them as baselines to compare RAN against in Section 3.1.
label: concur

sentence: Response #4: We have added more explanations in Section 3.1 about how “the proposed algorithm works as an implicit regularization leading to better classification accuracy than the original model which completely ignores privacy”.
label: concur

sentence: As shown in Figure 3, the utility of RAN’s Encoder output is higher than that of DNN.
label: concur

sentence: Here the DNN model stands for the non-private feature extractor followed by a non-private classifier.
label: concur

sentence: Response #5: We agree that it is necessary to conduct experiments to compare RAN’s performance concerning privacy and accuracy with/without a different kind of layers so that we can back up the argument mentioned in Section 2.2.
label: concur

sentence: On the one hand, we have already conducted exhaustive micro-benchmark experiments to determine the current design of RAN.
label: concur

sentence: For example, we select different model architectures (layers and building blocks), weight updating schemes of different parts (when and how to update Encoder, Decoder and Classifier) and settings of some important hyper-parameters (the setup of “n” epochs and “k” steps, learning rate) to select the empirically optimized one.
label: concur

sentence: However, we only present the most important results in this paper due to the space limit.
label: dispute

sentence: On the other hand, for all the arguments in Section 2.2, we have added the citation to support them.
label: concur

sentence: Response #6: We agree that it is important to justify how the reconstruction error works as a measure of privacy in this paper.
label: concur

sentence: In the revision, we have added the following explanation and justification on privacy quantification in Section 1, Section 2, Section 4 and Section 5.
label: concur

sentence: First, there is no single standard definition of data privacy-preserving and corresponding adversary attacks.
label: dispute

sentence: And a fundamental problem is the natural privacy-utility tradeoff which is affected by different data privacy-preserving methods.
label: dispute

sentence: We note that our principal contribution in this paper is the RAN framework and the training algorithm, which can accommodate different choices of privacy attacker and privacy quantification.
label: concur

sentence: Second, finding the right measurement for privacy is an open problem in itself.
label: concur

sentence: To evaluate RAN, one has to pick some quantifications.
label: concur

sentence: In the present paper, we chose the “reconstructive error” because it is the most intuitive one to measure the risk of original data disclosure given perturbed data (Encoder output).
label: concur

sentence: Third, in the future, we will evaluate RAN using other quantifications of privacy as well in a defined application.
label: concur

sentence: For example, we could measure the privacy by the hidden failure, i.e., the ratio between the background patterns that were discovered based on RAN’s Encoder output, and the sensitive patterns founded from the raw data, in an object recognition task.
label: concur

sentence: Response #7: Thanks for pointing out the citation problem in Section 3.1.
label: concur

sentence: In the revision, we have added explanation and cited more articles about several attacks for how the raw data can cause privacy risks in Section 1.
label: concur

sentence: For example, underlying correlation detection, re-identification and other malicious mining.
label: concur

sentence: As for the “Noisy Data” method, we have added the citation on differential privacy in Section 3.1.
label: concur

sentence: Response #8: We have re-plotted Figure 3 and Figure 4 to improve the readability.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for your careful reading and comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: Missing assumptions about the black-box calibration approaches
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank R1 and R2 for endorsing the merit of our proposed black-box calibration.
label: nonarg

sentence: The black-box calibration assumes no read/write to model weights or availability training data, but access to the sampling of random seed.
label: concur

sentence: The black-box calibration is useful for both model user and API owner.
label: concur

sentence: Model owner: We suppose that the dense mode happens to be close to a specific training image, thus violating privacy.
label: concur

sentence: The model owner would like to calibrate the model to alleviate the mode collapse.
label: concur

sentence: In such a situation, training data may no longer be accessible since it contains private information, e.g. human faces or person images.
label: concur

sentence: Retraining consumes much time and energy, especially for complex models trained on a huge dataset.
label: concur

sentence: Besides, we empirically validate that the dense mode is not caused by imbalanced data or randomness during initialization/optimization.
label: concur

sentence: So retraining won't work for dense-mode alleviation.
label: concur

sentence: Our proposed black-box calibration has an advantage over retraining with minimum time and energy cost and no touching training data.
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, the calibration can target any dense mode for alleviation.
label: concur

sentence: API owner: For enterprise users having access to the face image generation service via cloud API, they are given the ping service for a huge number of times or not even restricted.
label: concur

sentence: Black-box calibration enables the API owner to customize the model's sampling process to meet the users' needs.
label: concur

sentence: Q2: Missing key experiments that will provide more motivation that 1. face identity can be used as a proxy for face image diversity; 2. applying our proposed metric to the training datasets should show no gap between $\mathcal{R}_{obs}$ and $\mathcal{R}_{ref}$:
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. Face identity as a proxy for face image diversity
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to clarify that we are not using the identity label as a proxy.
label: dispute

sentence: Instead, we are using the embedding features obtained from the neural network trained on the face recognition task.
label: dispute

sentence: We claim that the embedding features have rich semantics of all kinds of facial attributes, e.g. age, gender, race and so on.
label: nonarg

sentence: The rich semantics of the face embedding feature can be validated by its strong transferability on other visual tasks, e.g. gender/race classification and age regression.
label: nonarg

sentence: Prior studies [Savchenko, Andrey V, "Efficient facial representations for age, gender and identity recognition in organizing photo albums using multi-output ConvNet" (2019)] have shown that transfer learning using neural networks pretrained on face recognition can produce highly effective results for gender recognition and age estimation.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2. Applying our metric on the training set of FFHQ
label: nonarg

sentence: FFHQ is a public face dataset contains $56,138$ images, without repeating identities.
label: nonarg

sentence: We first randomly pick $1k$ images to form the S set and sort the S set according to the number of neighbors within distance 0.3.
label: nonarg

sentence: We choose the sample at percentile $0.01\%, 0.1\%, 1\%, 10\%, 20\%, 30\%, 40\%, 50\%, 60\%, 70\%, 80\%, 90\%$. We conduct the neighboring analysis on these selected samples.
label: nonarg

sentence: We still observe a gap between $\mathcal{R}_{obs}$ and $\mathcal{R}_{ref}$, which demonstrates that FFHQ dataset has dense mode, even without repeating identities.
label: nonarg

sentence: Furthermore, we would like to clarify that our metric is proposed to measure the collapse of GAN's learned distribution.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have empirically shown in the paper that the mode collapse still occurs despite balanced training data.
label: concur

sentence: You can check the details in the appendix of the paper, the paragraph of "Applying Our Proposed Metric on FFHQ".
label: concur

sentence: Q3: Minor improvements
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. Proof or citation for the flaws of FID
label: nonarg

sentence: There is a recently published survey paper that can back our claim. It is [Ali Borji, "Pros and Cons of GAN Evaluation Measures" (Arxiv 18)]
label: concur

sentence: 2. The contradiction between the two statements
label: nonarg

sentence: We use the word "loss of diversity" since IS's measuring of diversity is limited.
label: dispute

sentence: E.g., on ImageNet with 1000 classes, it can not rule out the case when then generator simply repeating the same image for each different class.
label: dispute

sentence: 3. We take your advice and will address this piece of work as a "pilot study" in the final version.
label: concur

sentence: We thank reviewer3 for the comprehensive review.
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to address each of the reviewer's concerns individually. (This will include some discussions above only seen by authors, reviewers, area chairs and program chairs.)
label: nonarg

sentence: # Is the approach really limited?
label: nonarg

sentence: It is true that that the transformation that removes the desired information must be known before hand which is the main assumption in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Other conceivable transformations are (i) removal of colour information by converting image to grey scale, (ii) removal of orientation information with random rotation and positional shift, (iii) removal of temporal correlation using shuffling in a time-series data and etc.
label: concur

sentence: We hope that that this paper could ignite a discussion around what transformation can be created to impose prior knowledge into the model.
label: concur

sentence: These prior transformation could be something that we observed in biology, for example, we observe global-local information disentanglement in our perception.
label: concur

sentence: Is there other hard-coded disentanglement in biology?
label: concur

sentence: This is rather an interesting problem in our opinion.
label: concur

sentence: Can this method learn more factor than just two?
label: nonarg

sentence: It is conceivable that there could be more than one information of interests that get destroyed in a transformation.
label: nonarg

sentence: For example, one latent factor could model middle-range correlations if the transformation remove long-range correlations through shuffling process and short-range correlations get destroyed through a blurring process (e.g. local smoothing transformation).
label: concur

sentence: Another two factors could represent long-rang and short-range correlations.
label: concur

sentence: What if the desired factors are not clearly disjoint and collectively exhaustive?
label: nonarg

sentence: This is an interesting question.
label: concur

sentence: We do not think that our current approach can disentangle continuous features.
label: concur

sentence: In a future work, there could be an auxiliary task method that can create continuous latent variables.
label: concur

sentence: We hope that this paper create interesting open problems for future research.
label: concur

sentence: # More ablations or experiments with comparable settings would be desirable.
label: nonarg

sentence: In our experiments, we found that the disentanglement of global and local information is very robust to different values of beta.
label: concur

sentence: In experiment 1.2 we use beta=1.0 which is the same as using the original VAE objective.
label: concur

sentence: However, beta does affect the quality of the generative samples (blurriness).
label: concur

sentence: For experiment 1.1, different beta produce similar disentanglement results, we use beta=20 to produce the figures as it created nicest looking samples.
label: concur

sentence: We uses beta=40 for all clustering experiments which had been searched from beta=\{1, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60\} for the best digit identity clustering results.
label: concur

sentence: Thanks to reviewer3, we incorporated this information into the revision.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding the clustering result, we believe that the resulting accuracy number cannot be used to compare the quality of the clustering methods.
label: dispute

sentence: We observe that the global structure contains more information than just digit identity.
label: dispute

sentence: It also contains information such as whether or not there are distracting digits in the image.
label: dispute

sentence: We are not concern with improving upon baseline but rather to confirm that our method can disentangle global-local information and the further analysis have shown that the grouping corresponds to more than just the digit identity.
label: dispute

sentence: The use of 30 clusters helps us identify the grouping of other types of global information in addition to the digit identity.
label: dispute

sentence: Therefore, the identity clustering performance does not directly translate into the ability to disentangle local and global variables.
label: dispute

sentence: # Related work
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to thank reviewer 3 for suggesting the related works that we have missed. These were incorporated in the revision.
label: concur

sentence: As discussed in the comments above (visible only to authors and area chairs), there is an overhead regarding grouping of data into batches in DC-IGN approach.
label: concur

sentence: We agree that DC-IGN could potentially perform the same task as our model or more.
label: concur

sentence: However, our method can reduce the effort of needing to group the data or use labelled data by instead thinking more about prior knowledge (transformation function) of the entire dataset.
label: dispute

sentence: The contributions of this paper are
label: nonarg

sentence: (i) Suggest that there is another method of imposing prior knowledge into algorithmic design of the latent variable model.
label: nonarg

sentence: We believe this can be categorised as a self-supervised learning approach (a kind of unsupervised learning) which have not been explored much in the context of the latent variable model.
label: nonarg

sentence: (ii) Show that it can be used to disentangle global and local information through experiments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their insightful and constructive feedback.
label: nonarg

sentence: Re: (W1 & W2) Adversely affected by rotations
label: concur

sentence: While the CFS is not invariant to rotations, it is a surprising, and empirically noteworthy, finding that all 4 different ways of producing representations consistently encode a dozen tasks very succinctly.
label: concur

sentence: This is in line with some early work that observed that certain characteristic properties like length [1][2], sentiment [3], presence/absence of brackets [4] are encoded in a single dimension in the space.
label: concur

sentence: Some of these findings can be attributed to the additive property of the cell state of the LSTMs c_t = f_t c_{t-1} + h_t {c’}_{t}, which is free from matrix rotations.
label: concur

sentence: As previously noted, this empirically also results in single cells of the LSTM being interpretable.
label: concur

sentence: To just give one example, LSTM cell state can increment by a fixed amount at every time step and can count the number of tokens reliably (i.e the string length) [1][4].
label: concur

sentence: Re: (W3) Baselines for transfer learning:
label: concur

sentence: > The random baseline (i.e a random ordering of candidate task) is compared in figure 3 (and all the plots in the appendix), where we plot the accuracy boost using the best task till now in the produced recommendation of candidate tasks using different methods.
label: concur

sentence: We can clearly see that the random ordering is much worse compared to informed metrics that use representations.
label: concur

sentence: Upon your suggestion, we would also add this random baseline in table 2 as well.
label: concur

sentence: Re: (W4) Metrics for ranking of transfer don't make sense (and some are missing).
label: concur

sentence: How is precision and NDCG calculated
label: concur

sentence: > To compute the gold set, we first train a neural network for each of the candidate tasks and then use the pre-trained sentence encoder (part of the network) from the candidate task to fine-tune on the target task.
label: concur

sentence: The ranked list (in the decreasing utility of transfer learning gain) is then considered the ‘gold’ set.
label: concur

sentence: We further compare our recommendations of candidate tasks generated using CFS and classifier weight difference methods against the gold ranked list.
label: concur

sentence: Precision@K, Reciprocal Rank and NDCG are among the popular information retrieval metrics to compare a recommended list against a gold ranked list.
label: concur

sentence: These metrics are meaningful in our case, for instance, Reciprocal Rank tells us how many tasks we need to consider as per our recommendation before we hit the highest performing candidate task.
label: concur

sentence: Figure 3 presents the accuracy boost using the best task till now in the produced recommendations for the candidate tasks using different methods.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding missing values:
label: concur

sentence: As we explain in the paper, classifier weight difference metric is only applicable in cases
label: concur

sentence: where the number of features between the tasks are of the same size.
label: concur

sentence: Thus, 2 sentence input tasks and 1 sentence input tasks cannot be compared using the metric.
label: concur

sentence: Re: (W5) Multi-task learning
label: concur

sentence: > Our goal is somewhat orthogonal to the multitask learning setting where all the tasks are jointly trained.
label: concur

sentence: We, instead, focus on how the task-specific information is present in popular sentence representations, and how this could be used to assess transfer potential among tasks.
label: concur

sentence: Re: (W6) Motivation for CFS
label: concur

sentence: > There is a rich literature concerning what information is captured in the representations.
label: concur

sentence: Further, there are a few initial works that show that certain characteristics like length [1][2], sentiment [3], presence and absence of tokens like brackets [4] are densely captured in a single dimension of the representation space.
label: concur

sentence: In a similar spirit, we wanted to quantitatively study this surprising phenomenon, and we were curious about how densely is information encoded in representations.
label: concur

sentence: Re: (W7) Alternatives to CFS / Computational concerns
label: concur

sentence: > We agree that LARS/LASSO could act as potential ways to attain reduced dimensions.
label: concur

sentence: For our use case, we found the greedy forward selection computationally fast enough (of the order of a few minutes), and we observed a significant portion of accuracy captured in a very few dimensions.
label: concur

sentence: We would definitely explore this further, and add a detailed analysis on computational efficiency of different methods to reduce dimensions.
label: concur

sentence: Re: (W8) The proposed  CLF weight difference method has some concerning aspects as well. For example say we had two task with exact opposite labels.
label: concur

sentence: They would have a very low weight difference score though they are ideal representations for each other
label: concur

sentence: > You are right. For the very same reason, we take the inverse of the difference of normalized absolute classifier weights (Section 4.2).
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for your comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: Please refer to the joint response in regards to training stability and mode collapse.
label: nonarg

sentence: Hello,
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to thank you for reviewing our paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: Also, thank you for your comment about the clarity of the writing, we spent a lot of effort ensuring the paper was easy to read.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding the suggested ablation,
label: nonarg

sentence: This comment was also made in the official blind review #2.
label: nonarg

sentence: We also responded to this suggestion in the public comment. For your convenience, we have copied our response here:
label: nonarg

sentence: In our model, BERT is more than a source of contextual word embeddings as we fine-tune all of its ~110M parameters during training.
label: nonarg

sentence: Simply replacing BERT with distributed embeddings and a character-CNN or LSTM wouldn’t allow us to determine the effect of contextualized embeddings because we would simultaneously be removing the majority of our model’s trainable parameters.
label: nonarg

sentence: Nevertheless, we performed the suggested ablation by swapping BERT for GloVe embeddings (300 dimensional) and found that NER performance dropped from 89.46% to 40.33% and RE performance fell from 66.83% to 14.44% on the test set of the ConLL04 corpus (note that we had to increase the learning rate by 10X to get the model to converge).
label: concur

sentence: If you were to somehow control for this drop in model capacity, say by adding in an LSTM network, the ablated model would closely match this paper [1], whom we outperform by ~3% overall on the CoNLL04 corpus.
label: nonarg

sentence: This paper is not cited in Table 1 as they report macro-averaged F1 scores, while most other papers (including the current state-of-the-art [2]) report micro-averaged F1 scores, as we did.
label: nonarg

sentence: Finally, it is well known that contextual embeddings outperform distributed embeddings on a wide range of NLP tasks, including NER [3].
label: nonarg

sentence: The aim of our study wasn’t to compare contextual vs. distributed embeddings but on how to successfully integrate BERT into a state-of-the-art joint NER and RE architecture.
label: nonarg

sentence: Regarding your comments:
label: nonarg

sentence: “I think the main source of improvement comes from the BERT representations used as input.”
label: nonarg

sentence: “[...] the contributions of this paper are to show that using BERT representations as input […]”
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to clarify that we are not simply using BERT representations as input.
label: dispute

sentence: We are integrating BERT as part of our model architecture and fine-tuning it along with the task-specific parameters (as stated in the second to last paragraph of the introduction).
label: dispute

sentence: For the particular problem of joint NER and RE, we found this to be critical.
label: dispute

sentence: For example, early on in our experiments we tested using BERT as a feature extractor vs. fine-tuning the entire architecture and found that performance dropped to ~42.82% (from 78.15%) on the CoNLL04 corpus.
label: nonarg

sentence: Integrating BERT as part of our model (as opposed to simply using its embeddings as inputs) allowed us to swap recurrent architectures common in joint NER and RE models in favour of simple and shallow task-specific architectures composed of feed forward neural networks.
label: dispute

sentence: This reduced training times while improving performance (see our response to official review #1 for more details).
label: dispute

sentence: Again, thanks for your constructive comments!
label: nonarg

label: nonarg

sentence: Generative model assumptions: our model is an expansion of the original RAND-WALK model of Arora et. al., with the purpose of accounting for syntactic dependencies.
label: dispute

sentence: The additional assumptions we include and the concentration phenomena we prove theoretically are verified empirically in section 5, so our results do hold up on real data.
label: dispute

sentence: Use on downstream tasks: we believe that capturing syntactic relationships using a tensor can be useful for some downstream tasks, since our results in the paper suggest that it captures additional information above and beyond the standard additive composition.
label: dispute

sentence: However, as the main goal of this paper is to introduce and analyze the model, we defer more application-focused analysis to future work.
label: concur

sentence: Interaction between arbitrary word pairs: our model introduces the tensor in order to capture syntactic relationships between pairs of words, such as adjective-noun and verb-object pairs.
label: concur

sentence: While it might be interesting to try to capture interactions between all pairs of words, that is not justified by our model and we didn't explore it.
label: concur

sentence: However, we also trained our model using verb-object pairs, and we have updated section 5 as well as the appendix to include these additional results.
label: concur

sentence: Comparison to Arora, Liang, Ma ICLR 2017: we appreciate the suggestion to include a comparison with the SIF embedding method of Arora et. al., as this method is also obtained from a variant of the original RAND-WALK paper.
label: concur

sentence: We have updated Table 2 and the discussion in section 5 to include these additional results.
label: concur

sentence: As reported in their paper, the SIF embeddings yield a strong baseline for sentence embedding tasks, and we find the same to be true in the phrase similarity task for adjective-noun phrases (not so for verb-object phrases).
label: concur

sentence: However, we find that we can improve upon the SIF performance by addition of the tensor component from our model. (We note that we have just used the tensors trained in our original model; it is possible that combining the model in SIF and syntactic RAND-WALK more carefully could give even better results.)
label: concur

sentence: Additional citations: we have updated the paper to include both additional citations.
label: concur

sentence: We thank Reviewer 1 for their insightful questions and suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree that Product Quantization (PQ) is key to get “impressive compression ratio” while maintaining competitive accuracy, provided that there is some special structure and redundancy in the weights and the way we quantize them.
label: concur

sentence: Which kind of redundancy does our method capture?
label: concur

sentence: As rightfully stated by Reviewer 1, choosing which elementary blocks to quantize in the weight matrices is crucial for the success of the method (what the Reviewer calls “horizontal/vertical/other” correlation)
label: concur

sentence: In what follows, let us focus on the case of convolutional weights (of size C_out x C_in x K x K).
label: concur

sentence: As we state in our paper: “There are many ways to split a 4D matrix in a set of vectors and we are aiming for one that maximizes the correlation between the vectors since vector quantization-based methods work the best when the vectors are highly correlated
label: concur

sentence: We build on previous work that have documented the *spatial redundancy* in the convolutional filters [1], hence we use blocks of size K x K. Therefore, we rely on the particular nature of convolutional filters to exploit their spatial redundancy.
label: concur

sentence: We have tried other ways to split the 4D weights into a set of vectors to in preliminary experiments, but none was on par with the proposed choice.
label: concur

sentence: We agree with Reviewer 1 that the method would probably not yield as good a performance for arbitrary matrices.
label: concur

sentence: Using row permutations to improve the compressibility?
label: concur

sentence: This is a very good remark.
label: nonarg

sentence: Indeed, redundancy can be artificially created by finding the *right* permutation of rows (when we quantize using column blocks for a 2D matrix).
label: concur

sentence: Yet in our preliminary experiments, we observed that PQ performs systematically worse both in terms of reconstruction error and accuracy of the network that when applying a random permutation to a convolutional filter.
label: concur

sentence: This confirms that our method captures the spatial redundancy of the convolutional filters as stated in the first point.
label: concur

sentence: [1] Exploiting linear structure within convolutional networks for efficient evaluation, Denton et al.
label: nonarg

sentence: Due to the overlap between reviewer comments, we decided to address all concerns in a single response (please see above).
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to thank Reivewer 1 for your time and the review.
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree that more experiments based on other types of dataset will make the result stronger which we hope to perform in a follow up work.
label: concur

sentence: However, we believe that the current results already give substantial evidences that the method successfully disentangle local and global structure.
label: dispute

sentence: While the performance of VAE+Auxiliary in digit identity clustering is not higher than two of the other methods, we found that the grouping can corresponds to other global features such as how many digits are in the image and the global-colour style.
label: dispute

sentence: Therefore, the lower clustering accuracy does not mean that the method poorly disentangle local and global information but rather suggesting that the digit identity clustering is an incomplete evaluation metric for unsupervised clustering.
label: dispute

sentence: We hope that reviewer 1 see that, in the context of this paper, the experiments have substantially fulfilled their proposed of showing that the method can disentangle global and local information as intended.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for your review.
label: nonarg

sentence: We believe it captures the essence of what we are proposing and are delighted with the overall very positive assessment.
label: concur

sentence: As regards the weakness mentioned, we accept the characterisation of our work as incremental in the sense that it draws together a number of known techniques from areas such as multi-task and adversarial learning.
label: dispute

sentence: We argue, however, that the contribution of our submission lies exactly in the unification of these approaches into the stethoscope framework, which lends itself to targeted representation analysis and modification.
label: dispute

sentence: We showcase stethoscopes to provide insights into a particular application domain, stability prediction in intuitive physics, but believe that the methods presented here will provide a ready toolkit for researchers addressing a variety of challenges in network interpretability and (de)biasing.
label: dispute

sentence: We thank the reviewer for taking the time to consider our paper and appreciate that you are excited to use our counterfactually-augmented dataset.
label: nonarg

sentence: While degrees of novelty and the relevant sorts of novelty are a matter of opinion we respectfully assert our view that new ideas, the new resource that we present, and the scientific insights derived from our experiments, are precisely the sorts of novelty that should be sought by conferences.
label: dispute

sentence: We respectfully disagree with the reviewer’s suggestion that a fundamentally distinct resource warrants only a whitepaper.
label: dispute

sentence: We politely point out that many conferences have entire dedicated tracks, and even best paper awards for resources, and that many seminal papers of pivotal importance to the field make precisely this sort of contribution (e.g. ImageNet).
label: dispute

sentence: Additionally we point out that the resource is not the only novel idea here.

sentence: We thank the reviewer for pointing out papers [1] and [2].

sentence: We will definitely cite them in the paper and include a discussion in related work on how our scheme compares to that proposed in the two papers.
label: concur

sentence: In essence, our scheme is different than [1] in two key aspects: (1) we pipeline both the forward and backward passes of the backpropagation while [1] pipelines only the backward pass.
label: concur

sentence: Further, equation (9) in [1] suggests that while weight updates use delayed gradients, the delayed weights (W^(t-K+k)) are used for the weight gradient calculation.
label: concur

sentence: This is essentially similar to weight stashing used in PipeDream, which we compared to in our paper.
label: concur

sentence: Thus, our scheme has the advantage of a smaller memory footprint.
label: concur

sentence: The follow up work in [2] attempts to reduce the memory footprint through feature replay (i.e., re-computing activations during backward pass, similar to GPipe).
label: concur

sentence: Our scheme saves the activations instead of re-computing them to eliminate pipeline bubble, thus achieving better utilization of the accelerators (GPUs).
label: concur

sentence: We will edit the related work section to include the above discussion.

sentence: The speedup obtained is 1.73X, slightly higher than the 1.71X obtained in our paper, which could be caused by the batch size increase that makes the GPU process more efficient.

sentence: The exact inference accuracy of the model is somewhat orthogonal to our study.

sentence: Nonetheless, it is relatively easy for us to update the results in the paper with these new hyperparameters.

sentence: We can justify PDR theoretically as an inductive bias on the language model.
label: concur

sentence: The observed bigrams in a language are not random and the distribution of the second word given the first word in a bigram is not uniform.
label: concur

sentence: Similarly, the distribution of the first word given the second word will be far from uniform.
label: concur

sentence: A RNN based language model models the first dependence (and more long range ones) and our proposed PDR tries to model the second one.
label: concur

sentence: In a unidirectional language model, we cannot look into the future tokens and hence we use the output distribution as a proxy for the "true second word" and decode the distribution of the first word.
label: concur

sentence: Thus the PDR term can be thought of as biasing the language model to retain more information about the distribution of the first word given the second word in a bigram.
label: concur

sentence: We believe language modeling is a fundamental problem in NLP and our work continues a long stream of papers that have achieved steadily lower perplexities over the past few years.

sentence: -- “proposed method demonstrates that an instance of one class of problems, Fractional Adwords, can be learned to solve without domain expertise, however fails to prove that the approach would be beneficial for any other instances of the same problem.”
label: nonarg

sentence: Please refer to our overall comments on this question (and also a few more details in reply to Reviewer#1’s similar question).
label: concur

sentence: -- Comment on scale / speed for large instances of combinatorial optimization:
label: nonarg

sentence: The point of this work is only to see if ML can find optimal algorithms, and not about doing it faster than the known theoretical algorithms.
label: dispute

sentence: Note that this is not similar to the case of solving an offline combinatorial problem via integer programming or other solvers, since our problems are online, i.e., the instance is not known beforehand, so there is no comparison to such “general-purpose” solvers.
label: dispute

sentence: Thus we don't compare to the running time of offline solvers, but to the worst-case competitive ratio of the optimal online algorithms.
label: dispute

sentence: As mentioned in the comment, this approach may eventually lead to finding optimal or near-optimal algorithms for a problem (not an instance of a problem) for which no algorithm is known -- but this is outside the scope of this work future work.
label: dispute

sentence: Again drawing the analogy of playing Go, the objective is mostly on training an agent that can make competitive moves rather than very fast moves, and there is no known “general-purpose” strategy to accomplish this.
label: dispute

sentence: *Please also see reply to reviewer #2 on a similar question of evaluating against other methods*
label: dispute

sentence: -- “Ski Rental problem can also be learned to solve though it is trivial and does not even use the framework the authors propose in its full extent, i.e. problem instances are not generated by use of a machine learning model, which is one of the main claims the authors are making.”
label: nonarg

sentence: (4) We agree with the reviewer that in many cases there is a gap between solving the discrete problem and the fractional problem.
label: concur

sentence: In general it is an established approach to solve the fractional problem and use additional techniques such as rounding to fill the gap.
label: concur

sentence: As to AdWords, although the discrete problem naturally corresponds to the real world scenario, we do not consider fractional AdWords below the bar
label: dispute

sentence: compared to discrete AdWords in terms of difficulty
label: dispute

sentence: The optimal CR bound and the adversarial distribution are the same for both cases, and the optimal algorithms basically have the same structure.
label: dispute

sentence: One may arguably say that the optimal algorithm for the fractional problem has richer structure as in the fractional problem the action space is much larger as we can fractionally assign each ad to many advertisers.
label: dispute

sentence: As to the shortcomings of our techniques and why we pick the fractional problem, note that the GAN framework needs the computation of the discriminator network (i.e. the algorithm agent in our context) to be differentiable in order to update the generator network (i.e. the adversary in our context) during training.
label: concur

sentence: This poses difficulties if we ask the algorithm agent to make discrete decisions via sampling or rounding since it will not be differentiable.
label: concur

sentence: This doesn’t mean that our high-level framework (i.e. training the algorithm and adversary networks simultaneously) is doomed, since we can use other ML techniques (e.g. reinforcement learning) to implement our framework, but in general sampling and rounding will lead to much more work during training, so we pick the GAN structure in this work.
label: concur

sentence: (5) We know from theory that if the algorithm player runs a no-regret dynamic (e.g. MWU) and the adversary player responds with the worst input for the algorithm in each round, then the algorithm player converges to the optimal algorithm, and the uniform distribution over the adversary player’s responses gives the adversarial distribution.
label: dispute

sentence: However, we cannot really follow this approach as the space of algorithms is infinite and we cannot run a MWU on this space, and in general it is also hard or impossible to find the absolute worst input in each round.
label: dispute

sentence: In the practical framework, the algorithm player uses a neural network, and the adversary network tries its best to come up with a bad (but not necessarily worst) input each round.
label: dispute

sentence: Thus we don’t have all the clean theoretical guarantees anymore, but the intuition should still largely hold (as our empirical result suggests).
label: dispute

sentence: (Q1) Thank you very much for the suggestion.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have included experimental results evaluating pGAN on CIFAR-10.
label: concur

sentence: The results are shown in Figure 4 in the updated version of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: (Q2) Following your recommendation, we have structured the section with the experimental results in different subsections.
label: concur

sentence: (Q3) The observation from the reviewer is correct: pGAN aims to inject poisoning points in regions that are close to the decision boundary, especially in those where the data distributions overlap more.
label: nonarg

sentence: Points that are far away from the decision boundary may be detected by the discriminator, outlier detection or other defensive algorithms that could be used.
label: nonarg

sentence: Defences aiming to remove points that are close to the decision boundary could be effective to remove poisoning points generated with pGAN, but these defences will suffer from a significant loss in performance, especially when the algorithm is not under attack.
label: nonarg

sentence: For example, in SVMs, support vectors are points that are close to the decision boundary.
label: nonarg

sentence: If we remove these points, as suggested by the reviewer, we would obtain different support vectors that would lead to suboptimal solutions with significantly degraded performance.
label: nonarg

sentence: With regards to addressing the more general point of the performance of pGAN when state-of-the-art defences are used, we have updated the paper to include a new section (4.3) where we show that pGAN is capable of bypassing 4 different defence mechanisms.
label: concur

sentence: This supports the effectiveness of our attack.
label: nonarg

sentence: (Q4) Munoz-Gonzalez et al. (2017) showed an experiment using a Convolutional neural network with 450,000 parameters, trained with 1,000 training points and injecting 10 poisoning points.
label: nonarg

sentence: In our case, for the experiment with MNIST in Figure 2, we used a deep neural network with more than 40,000,000 parameters, 1,000 training points, injecting up to 400 poisoning points.
label: nonarg

sentence: As the reviewer can observe the scale of the experimental evaluation is significantly different.
label: nonarg

sentence: The computational complexity of the attack in Munoz-Gonzalez et al. (2017) makes the experimental evaluation intractable for the settings considered in our experiments.
label: dispute

sentence: On the other side, Paudice et al. (2018a) showed that, in many cases, if we don’t consider appropriate detectability constraints, the attack points generated by optimal attack strategies formulated as bilevel optimization problems can be effectively filtered out with appropriate outlier detection, resulting in blunt attacks.
label: nonarg

sentence: This is not the case for pGAN, which is capable of bypassing different defences, including the outlier detection scheme proposed by Paudice et al. (2018a).
label: nonarg

sentence: Although defences based on outlier detection can be bypassed, as shown by Koh et al. (2017) (Stronger poisoning attacks break data sanitization defences), the complexity of the bilevel problem significantly increases compared to Munoz-Gonzalez et al. (2017).
label: nonarg

sentence: Thus, applying the attack strategy proposed by Koh et al. (2017) is also computationally intractable in our experimental settings.
label: dispute

sentence: One of the main advantages of pGAN is the possibility of generating poisoning attacks at scale with detectability constraints capable of targeting large deep networks, where strategies relying on bilevel optimization have a limited applicability.
label: nonarg

sentence: In our paper the goal is to introduce a framework to output a set using neural networks and we used the detection task as one of the set prediction examples.
label: dispute

sentence: We would like to add few comment about these two works:
label: nonarg

sentence: These approaches try to learn a pairwise relationship between the boxes outputted using the conventional proposal based detection approaches.
label: dispute

sentence: First a) they need to introduce extra pairwise network or heavier computation to learn these pairwise relationship b) they assume the relationship is pairwise between bounding boxes.
label: dispute

sentence: Out framework is a single stage approach which uses a conventional convnet backbones with no extra computation.
label: dispute

sentence: Since it is end-to-end prediction of boxes, we don’t enforce any pairwise or higher order relationships between the outputs.
label: dispute

sentence: We all rely on the layer of neural nets to capture high level relationship between outputs before predicting them.
label: dispute

sentence: We thank the reviewer for pointing out the potential similarity between our pipelined approach and the asynchronous update approach.
label: nonarg

sentence: Pipelined backpropagation is similar to model parallelism but it addresses the resource underutilization issue in model parallelism.
label: dispute

sentence: However, asynchronous update (e.g., asycn-SGD in Dean et al. [1]) usually utilizes a parameter server to keep track of model parameters (weights) while our pipelined method does not use any parameter server.
label: dispute

sentence: Furthermore, each accelerator obtains a replica of a full model in asycn-SGD training while each accelerator contains only a part of the model in our pipelined method, on the assumption that the full model does not fit into the memory of a single accelerator.
label: dispute

sentence: The async-SGD in Dean et al. [1] still falls into data parallelism because each accelerator has a replica of the full model.
label: dispute

sentence: On the other hand, our approach falls into pipelined parallelism.
label: concur

sentence: Thus, we focused our comparison to related work on two similar approaches: PipeDream and GPipe, both utilizing pipelined parallelism.
label: concur

sentence: Nonetheless, we will expand the related work section to more explicitly compare to data parallelism and non-pipelined approaches to model parallelism (i.e., expand on the first paragraph of related work).
label: concur

sentence: 3. What about enforcing the marginal distribution on the annotated data and the marginal distribution of the model to be similar with KL divergence?
label: nonarg

sentence: Using the KL loss also introduces a scalar multiplier hyperparameter for this loss term.
label: concur

sentence: Please find our detailed response below:
label: nonarg

sentence: [R4: First, the proposed attack method can yield adversarial perturbations to images that are large in the \ell_p norm.
label: nonarg

sentence: Therefore, the authors claim that the method can attack certified systems.
label: nonarg

sentence: However, attack in Wasserstein distance and some other methods can also do so.
label: concur

sentence: They can generate adversarial examples whose \ell_p norm is large.
label: concur

sentence: I think the author should have some discussions about these related methods.]
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for pointing us out to the missing related work which we have included in the revision.
label: concur

sentence: Indeed, the Wasserstein attack and the other previously mentioned non-$\ell_p$ bounded attacks are alternatives for producing quasi-imperceptible non-$\ell_p$ bounded adversarial examples.
label: concur

sentence: Any of these methods can alternatively be used for generating non $\ell_p$ bounded attacks.
label: concur

sentence: However, one major advantage of our attack method over the Wasserstein attack may be its simplicity and scalability.
label: concur

sentence: Per your suggestion, we ran experiments using the Wasserstein attack.
label: concur

sentence: The authors of [1] suggest that the Wasserstein PGD attack works best when the attacker takes PGD steps in $ell_p$-norm directions and then project the noise back onto the Wasserstein ball.
label: concur

sentence: We used their official implementation and adapted it to attack the Randomized Smoothed classifier.
label: concur

sentence: Based on the official implementation, after every 10 iterations, if the attack is not successful, we increase the radius of the wasserstein ball in which the noise is projected back onto.
label: concur

sentence: Consequently, the attack is always able to reach a comparable, but slightly weaker, spoofed certified radii (~ 67% that of the shadow attack) at the cost of slightly more perceptible adversarial noise in difficult cases.
label: concur

sentence: Note that the reason that the examples are more perceptible than those from [1] is that they are made to produce large certified radii and not only cause misclassification (i.e., the entire Gaussian augmented batch needs to get misclassified.) A comparison of the resulting images and average certified radii of those images can be found in the following anonymized link:
label: concur

sentence: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1F0P8aOD_5aiVjW3CrR49fudz4EgrORz7v4t0ZIJEBAo/edit?usp=sharing.
label: nonarg

sentence: [1] Wong et al., “Wasserstein Adversarial Examples via Projected Sinkhorn Iterations”.
label: nonarg

sentence: [R4: Second, I notice that compared to the result in Table 1, PGD attack can yield better results [1].
label: nonarg

sentence: I hope to see some discussions about this. Also, Table 1 is really confused. I would not understand the meaning if I am not familiar with the experiment settings.]
label: nonarg

sentence: Per your request, we have attacked the work of [2] and reported results of attacking the pre-trained SmoothAdv classifiers (available in [3]) in Appendix B.
label: concur

sentence: Similar to the non-adversarially trained smooth classifier included in the original submission, we can produce adversarial examples for the SmoothAdv classifier which on average produce larger certified radii than their natural example counterpart.
label: concur

sentence: Also, in the revised document, we have expanded the caption of Table 1 to make sure that it is clear what a certified is and that a larger radii is better.
label: concur

sentence: [2]. Salman et al., “Provably Robust Deep Learning via Adversarially Trained Smoothed Classifiers”, NeurIPS 2019
label: nonarg

sentence: [3]. https://github.com/Hadisalman/smoothing-adversarial
label: nonarg

sentence: Thanks for the detailed and encouraging feedback! We reply all comments below (relevant ones are put together):
