sentence: >> Comments #1, #11
label: concur

sentence: We mainly account the success of this simple training strategy to the simplicity of the model, the relatively low dimensionality of our input features, and the simplified action space (though all  three suffice to obtain a good controller in the current settings).
label: concur

sentence: They make the training of the controller much easier compared to other RL tasks with higher dimensional features or larger output space.
label: concur

sentence: We have added the detailed PPO-based training algorithm in Appendix A.1.
label: concur

sentence: While AutoLoss is amenable to different policy optimization algorithms, we empirically find PPO performs better on NMT, but REINFORCE performs better on GANs.
label: concur

sentence: As to the online setting, thanks for pointing us to the “short-horizon bias” paper.
label: concur

sentence: We have indicated in the revision the existence of this bias -- this bias was observed on the GAN task -- overtraining G can increase IS in a short term, but may lead to divergence in a long term as G becomes too strong.
label: concur

sentence: On the other hand, we didn’t observe it harms on NMT task noticeably.
label: concur

sentence: We hypothesize the tradeoff is insignificant on NMT, as in our multi-task setting, slightly over-optimizing one task objective usually does not have irreversible negative impact on the MT model (as long as the other objectives are optimized appropriately later on).
label: concur

sentence: >> Comments #2, #3
label: concur

sentence: We’d like to clarify that S=1 is consistent in the overhead section and Algorithm.1.
label: concur

sentence: S controls how many sequences to generate to perform a (batched) policy update (i.e. S is the batch size), and we set S=1 for all tasks.
label: concur

sentence: Only T differs across tasks, but we always update \phi whenever a reward is generated.
label: concur

sentence: Back to comment #2: for regression and classification, we have experimented with larger S and found the improvement marginal.
label: concur

sentence: As each reward is generated via an independent experiment, the correlations among gradients are unobvious.
label: concur

sentence: For large-scale tasks, we use memory replay to alleviate correlations in online settings (please see Algorithm 2 in Appendix A.1 in our revised version).
label: concur

sentence: Performing batched update with a larger S might help reduce correlations; However, a large S, as a major drawback, requires performing ST (S>>1) steps of task model training, in order to perform one step of controller update.
label: concur

sentence: This yields better per-step convergence, but longer overall training (wallclock) time for the controller to converge.
label: concur

sentence: There might exist sweet spots for S where one can achieve both good per-step convergence and short training time, but we skip the search of S and simply use S=1 as it performs well.
label: concur

sentence: It is worth noting that some recent literature uses a stochastic estimation of the policy gradient with batch size 1 as well, and report strong empirical results [1].
label: concur

sentence: [1] Efficient Neural Architecture Search via Parameter Sharing.
label: concur

sentence: ICML 2018
label: concur

sentence: Q: “ADP and ADP-T runtimes were very close on WikiText-103 dataset but very different on Billion Word corpus (Table 3 and 4)”
label: nonarg

sentence: The differences in training time are due to the size of the models: Weight tying saves a lot more parameters for the Billion Word model due to the larger vocab compared to the WikiText-103 models which have a smaller vocab.
label: concur

sentence: On WikiText-103, tying saves 15% of parameters (Table 3, ADP vs ADP-T, 291M vs 247M) and training time is reduced by about 13%.
label: concur

sentence: On Billion Word, tying saves 27% of parameters (Table 4) and training time is reduced by about 34%.
label: concur

sentence: The slight discrepancy may be due to multi-machine training for Billion Word compared to the single machine setup for WikiText-103.
label: concur

sentence: Q1: "I am curious about what would you get if you use ADP on BPE vocab set?"
label: nonarg

sentence: We tried adaptive input embeddings with BPE but the results were worse than softmax.
label: concur

sentence: This is likely because 'rare' BPE units are in some sense not rare enough compared to a word vocabulary.
label: concur

sentence: In that case, the regularization effect of assigning less capacity to 'rare' BPE tokens through adaptive input embeddings is actually harmful.
label: concur

sentence: Q2: "How much of the perplexity reduction of 8.7 actually come from ADP instead of the transformer and optimization?"
label: nonarg

sentence: For WikiText-103 (Table 3) we measured 24.92 on test with a full softmax model (a 5.2 PPL improvement over the previous SOTA).
label: concur

sentence: This corresponds to a Transformer model including our tuned optimization scheme.
label: concur

sentence: Adding tied adaptive input embeddings (ADP-T) to this configuration reduces this perplexity to 20.51, which is another reduction of 4.4 PPL.
label: concur

sentence: * “The DFW linearizes the loss function into a smooth one, and also adopts Nesterov momentum to accelerate the training.”

sentence: We would like to clarify this statement: one of the key ideas of the DFW algorithm is not to linearize the loss function $\mathcal{L}$, but only the model $f$.

sentence: We wish to clarify the main technical contributions of this paper, since the SVM smoothing and the application of Nesterov acceleration are not the main novelty of this work.
label: dispute

sentence: We discuss the summary of contributions (available at the end of section 1 of the paper) in the context of technical novelty.
label: dispute

sentence: - Employing a composite framework allows us to use an efficient primal-dual algorithm.
label: dispute

sentence: As stated by Reviewer 1, this is novel in the context of deep neural networks: “To my knowledge, the submission is the first sound attempt to adapt this type of Dual-based algorithm for optimization of Deep Neural Network [..]”.
label: dispute

sentence: - Crucially, our approach yields an update at the same computational cost per iteration as SGD and with the same level of parallelization.
label: dispute

sentence: In contrast, in the closest approach to ours, the algorithm of Singh & Shawe-Taylor (2018) can only process a single sample at a time.
label: dispute

sentence: This results in an approach whose runtime is virtually multiplied by the batch-size (it would be slower by two orders of magnitude in typical classification settings, including for the experiments of this paper).
label: dispute

sentence: - We do not mean to claim that the application of Nesterov acceleration is a technical novelty in itself.
label: dispute

sentence: However, its use is subtle in our case (see appendix A.7) and it is empirically crucial for good performance, hence its mention in the paper.
label: dispute

sentence: - To the best of our knowledge, the hyper-parameter free smoothing approach that we propose in this work is novel (but is not the main contribution).
label: dispute

sentence: We have adapted the abstract and summary of contributions to focus on the main novelty, which is an optimization algorithm for deep neural networks with an optimal step-size at the same computational cost per iteration as SGD.
label: concur

sentence: If the reviewer remains concerned by a lack of novelty, we would be grateful if he/she could provide specific references so that we can compare them in detail with the DFW algorithm.

sentence: 1) Novelty of the convergence analysis: The paper by Yuan et al. did not present proof of convergence in the discrete-time setting.

sentence: Appropriate use of some sharp estimates allowed us to obtain concise bounds on convergence of the entire class of PoweredSGD methods for $\gamma\in[0,1]$ and the bounds continuously depend on parameters $\gamma$ and $\beta$. In the special cases ($\gamma=0,1$, $\beta=0$), these bounds matches the best known bounds for GD/SGD/SGDM in the non-convex setting.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for the comments, please find our responses to specific points below.
label: nonarg

sentence: [Q] “As far as I can see the most important take home message of the paper can be summarized in "one should consider non-saturating GAN loss and spectral normalization as default choices [...] Given additional computational budget, we suggest adding the gradient penalty [...] and train the model until convergence."
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] While we want this study to be approachable by non-experts, some level of formalism is required as our main audience are researchers working on or interested in GANs.
label: concur

sentence: The summary you provided is indeed correct -- coupled with our open-sourced code, it allows a non-expert to train a GAN with state-of-the-art methods without needing to understand the details.
label: dispute

sentence: On the other hand, for more experienced researchers, we provide more details on which design choices generalize to new settings and identify the biggest obstacles towards fair and unbiased quantitative evaluation of generative models.
label: dispute

sentence: [Q] Limited amount of new insight.
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] Our paper presents many useful insights, namely: NS-GAN performs well, spectral norm is a good default normalization technique, gradient penalty should also be considered, even in combination with spectral norm but will cost substantially more in terms of computational resources, popular metrics such as KID and FID result in the same relative ordering of the models so there is no point in computing both, most Resnet tricks do not matter, etc.
label: dispute

sentence: All of these insights are supported by a fair and unbiased rigorous experimental process.
label: dispute

sentence: On top of that, our experiments are reproducible (as already reported by other works), we shared the resulting code and the pre-trained models.
label: dispute

sentence: [Q] Clarification and exposition of plots.
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] Say that you had access to a GPU and had to train a model (loss+penalty+architecture).
label: concur

sentence: How many hyperparameter settings would you need to consider to achieve a certain quality?
label: concur

sentence: The FID from the plot is the estimate of the min FID computed by bootstrap estimation and the line-plots show this relationship.
label: concur

sentence: In other words, given a computing budget, which model should you pick?
label: concur

sentence: We will provide additional details in the caption of the plot.
label: concur

sentence: [Q] Bayesian optimization and variance.
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] We agree and will provide more details.
label: concur

sentence: When the sequential Bayesian optimization chooses the next set of hyperparameter combinations to test we run the model once (per hyperparameter combination) and report the scores to the optimizer.
label: concur

sentence: Then, the optimization algorithm takes these scores into account when selecting the next set of hyperparameters.
label: concur

sentence: The algorithm itself trades-off exploration and exploitation and it can explore hyperparameters "close" to the existing ones if they seem promising.
label: concur

sentence: Hence, the averaging happens implicitly during the search.
label: concur

sentence: [Q]: Studies and experiments. Stating that lower is better in the plots.
label: nonarg

sentence: [A]: Study is a set of experiments (say a study on the impact of the loss).
label: concur

sentence: Experiment is a concrete run with certain hyperparameters.
label: concur

sentence: Stating lower is better is a good idea, we will add this to the captions.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the detailed and thoughtful review.
label: nonarg

sentence: We address the reviewers main concerns.

sentence: “A more general function is $P(X)_i=Ax_i+\sum_{j\in N(x_i,X)} B(x_j,x_i) x_j + c$, where $N(x_n,X)$ is the set of index of neighbors within the set… Then, can the function family the authors used in the paper approximate this function?
label: nonarg

sentence: No.“
label: nonarg

sentence: >> We respectfully disagree.
label: dispute

sentence: The function P(X) described by the reviewer can be approximated arbitrarily well using a continuous equivariant function (by using bump functions to approximate indicators functions of neighbors).
label: dispute

sentence: As such it can be approximated with the universal models considered in this paper.
label: dispute

sentence: (e.g. PointNetST, DeepSets etc.)
label: dispute

sentence: Reiterating the main result of this paper: *Every* continuous equivariant function defined solely on a set of feature vectors can be approximated with PointnetST over a compact domain.
label: dispute

sentence: We are happy to include a discussion about this in the revised paper.
label: concur

sentence: “On the Knapsack test, the metric of interest is not the accuracy of individual prediction. Rather, whether the network has successfully predicted the optimal solution, or how close the prediction is to the solution.”

sentence: Response: We thank the reviewer for their comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to clarify one of the central points of this paper, as the cons presented are built upon a misunderstanding of this point.
label: nonarg

sentence: We are not proposing a new transfer learning model -- we are demonstrating the transferrability of the atomic features we have learned.
label: dispute

sentence: We train our structural features on C_r and show that with no re-training they can achieve state-of-the-art results of C_p.
label: concur

sentence: Applying a classical transfer learning algorithm might improve performance even further, as then we could fine-tune results on C_p.
label: concur

sentence: Though this is an interesting direction, it is outside the scope of the work we present here, which concerns itself with the learned representations themselves.
label: dispute

sentence: Thus, instead of comparing transfer learning methods, we evaluate the transferrability of both our own structural features as well as those of competitors.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer very much for reading the paper carefully and providing us with constructive comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have conducted further experiments applying our Past Decode Regularization (PDR) to the mixture-of-softmax (AWD-LSTM-MoS) model of (Yang et al. 2017).
label: concur

sentence: We use the same model sizes as in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Even with the very limited hyperparameter search in the vicinity of those used in the paper and fixing the PDR loss coefficient to 0.001 (as used in the other models in our paper), we see consistent gains on the Penn Treebank and WikiText-2 datasets.
label: concur

sentence: The validation/test perplexities are as follows -
label: concur

sentence: AWD-LSTM-MoS+PDR  || AWD-LSTM-MoS (Yang et al. 2017)
label: concur

sentence: Penn Treebank with finetuning -
label: concur

label: concur

sentence: WikiText-2 with finetuning -
label: concur

sentence: WikiText-2 with dynamic evaluation -
label: concur

sentence: Thus we observe gains of 0.6 and 1.0 points in test perplexity for PTB and WT2.
label: concur

sentence: With dynamic evaluation, the gains for both datasets is 0.4 points.
label: concur

sentence: Note again that we did a very limited hyperparameter search and more exhaustive experiments will likely lead to even better gains by using PDR.
label: concur

sentence: We will update and reorganize the experiments section in the paper accordingly.
label: concur

sentence: The updated manuscript will be posted shortly.
label: concur

sentence: Yang et al. 2017. Breaking the softmax bottleneck: A high-rank RNN language model. arXiv:1711.03953.
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank the review for their positive comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree that our main contribution is to cast a graph convolution network as a binary classifier learning to discriminate clean from noisy data and show its excellent results for few-shot learning.
label: concur

sentence: Q1: In future, I would like to see a joint approach to such training, where the function g(), the nearest neighbour graph loss and the classification loss are all tied in the same objective function and are optimized jointly.
label: nonarg

sentence: R1: We fully agree that this is an interesting direction for future research, which should result in a further increase in performance.
label: concur

sentence: It would be interesting to see if the feature extractor can benefit from the cleaning of noisy images during learning, resulting in more robust feature descriptors.
label: concur

sentence: Thanks for your efforts in reviewing our paper and the valuable comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We attempt to address your concerns using the following points and hope they can help you better understand our work.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. the number of benchmark datasets
label: nonarg

sentence: Currently, there are 5 datasets in our experiments.
label: concur

sentence: Actually, we have evaluated the proposed methods by conducting experiments in many datasets and observed the similar results.
label: dispute

sentence: Due to the space restriction, however, we cannot present them all in the paper.
label: dispute

sentence: We can provide more experiment results in appendix to eliminate this concern.
label: concur

sentence: 2. XGBoost
label: nonarg

sentence: We use LightGBM to learn GBDT model in the experiment part.
label: dispute

sentence: LightGBM is proven comparable (even better) with XGBoost in many Kaggle competitions (refer to https://www.kaggle.com/shivamb/data-science-trends-on-kaggle and https://github.com/Microsoft/LightGBM/tree/master/examples).
label: dispute

sentence: Therefore, we think using LightGBM is sufficient for comparison.
label: dispute

sentence: 3. Two shortages of tree-based models
label: nonarg

sentence: Let us describe these two shortages with more details here.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1) Hard to be integrated into complex end-to-end frameworks.
label: nonarg

sentence: In such framework, there are many modules, each of which may correspond to one sub-task with a global optimization goal.
label: concur

sentence: The outputs of modules can serve as the inputs of other modules.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, to train such a framework in an end-to-end way, the module should be able to propagate the errors from its outputs to its inputs.
label: concur

sentence: NN can naturally support this, as its learning algorithm is the back-propagation.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast, tree-based models do not support this as the tree learning process is not differentiable and therefore cannot propagate the errors to its inputs.
label: dispute

sentence: As stated in the Section 2, although there are some works targeting to address this problem, these solutions will lose the automatic feature selection ability and cannot work well on the tabular data.
label: dispute

sentence: 2) Hard to learn from streaming data.
label: nonarg

sentence: For NN's learning, we can use Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) or mini-batch SGD to naturally learn from streaming data, since the NN model could be updated per data sample or per mini-batch of samples.
label: concur

sentence: However, it is not effective for tree-based model to support this as its learning needs the global statistical information.
label: concur

sentence: Using the partial statistical information may produce the sub-optimal split points and results in worse models.
label: concur

sentence: There are some works addressed this problem, like Hoeffding trees, which stores the statistical histograms into leaf nodes.
label: concur

sentence: However, most of these solutions are designed for the single decision tree.
label: concur

sentence: Although there are ensemble versions of them, most of them are based on bagging (like Random Forest), which is proven not as good as GBDT.
label: concur

sentence: In short, NN does not suffer from these two problems due to its mini-batch back-propagation learning process.
label: dispute

sentence: In contrast, tree-based model is hard to solve these two problems due to its learning algorithm is based on global statistical information.
label: dispute

sentence: Therefore, TabNN is a better general solution for tabular data.
label: dispute

sentence: 4. "The experiments of this paper lack comparisons to certified verification
label: concur

sentence: methods. There are some scalable property verification methods that can give a
label: concur

sentence: lower bound on the input perturbation (see [1][2][3])
label: concur

sentence: These methods can
label: concur

sentence: guarantee that when epsilon is smaller than a threshold, no violations can be
label: concur

sentence: found.
label: concur

sentence: On the other hand, adversarial attacks give an upper bound of input
label: concur

sentence: perturbation by providing a counter-example (violation).
label: concur

sentence: The authors should
label: concur

sentence: compare the sampling based method with these lower and upper bounds.
label: concur

sentence: For
label: concur

sentence: example, what is log(I) for epsilon larger than upper bound?"
label: concur

sentence: The three references and the follow-up work that you cite give different methods for obtaining a certificate-of-guarantee that a datapoint is robust in a fixed epsilon l_\infty ball, with varying levels of scalability/generality/ease-of-implementation.
label: concur

sentence: For those datapoints where they can produce such a certificate
label: concur

sentence: , the minimal adversarial distortion is lower-bounded by that fixed epsilon.
label: concur

sentence: This is important work to be sure, but we view it as predominantly orthogonal to ours, for which we define robustness differently, as the “volume” of adversarial examples rather than the distance to a single adversarial example.
label: dispute

sentence: We actively argue that the minimal adversarial distortion is not a reliable measure of neural network robustness in many scenarios, as it is dictated by the position of a single violation, and conveys nothing about the amount of violations present.
label: dispute

sentence: Despite these being two different definitions of robustness, to try and demonstrate some comparisons between the two, we extended experiment 6.4 (already using Wong and Kolter (ICML 2018) [3]) and compared the fraction of samples for which I = P_min to the fraction that could be certified by Wong and Kolter for epsilon in {0.1, 0.2, 0.3}. We found that it wasn’t possible to calculate the certificate of Wong and Kolter for epsilon = 0.2/0.3 for all epochs, or epsilon = 0.1 before a certain epoch, due to its exorbitant memory usage.
label: concur

sentence: This significant memory gain thus indicates that our approach may still have advantages when used as a method for approximately doing more classical verification, even though this was not our aim.
label: concur

sentence: Please see the updated paper for full details.
label: concur

sentence: 5. "Additionally, in section 6.4, the results in Figure 2 also does not look very
label: concur

sentence: positive - it unlikely to be true that an undefended network is predominantly
label: concur

sentence: robust to perturbation of size epsilon = 0.1. Without any adversarial training,
label: concur

sentence: adversarial examples (or counter-examples for property verification) with L_inf
label: concur

sentence: distortion less than 0.1 (at least on some images) should be able to find."
label: concur

sentence: You are correct that without any robustness training it is possible to find adversarial examples with distortion less than 0.1 for some inputs.
label: concur

sentence: This is indeed what our results show in Figure 5 in the appendices, illustrating our metric for individual samples.
label: concur

sentence: You can see for several samples that were not initially robustness to eps=0.1 perturbations (log(I) > log(P_min)), the value of log(I) decreases steadily as the robust training procedure is applied.
label: concur

sentence: It does appear, however, that the network is predominantly robust to perturbations smaller than 0.1 before robustness training.
label: dispute

sentence: The curves in Figure 3 plot the values of our measure log(I) between the 25th and 75th percentile for a number of samples.
label: dispute

sentence: This shows that the network is already robust to perturbations of size eps=0.1 for more than about 75% of samples before the training procedure of Kolter and Wong is applied.
label: dispute

sentence: All the same, we agree that the original Figure 3 was confusing in this respect, and have rerun this experiment with a lower minimum threshold for log(I) to make the point clearer in the graph.
label: concur

sentence: With this lower value of log(P_min), we see the 75 percentile of log(I) over the samples quickly decrease as robustness training proceeds for eps=0.2.
label: concur

sentence: Notably, however, log(I) is incredibly small before any of this training for eps=0.1, demonstrating how it is important to not only think in terms of whether any violations are present, but also how many: here less the proportion of violating samples is less than 10^-100 at eps=0.1 for most of the datapoints.
label: concur

sentence: We thank Reviewer 1 for their critical appraisal and helpful suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thanks for your efforts in reviewing our paper and the valuable comments, but we have different opinions about your comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. Comments about the contributions and novelty
label: nonarg

sentence: As we emphasized many times in our paper, the success of DNN in domains such as image, speech and text, is built on the comprehensive exploration of the locality-based patterns, which motivates us to first find such patterns of features in tabular data automatically and then build up NN architecture based on these discovered patterns.
label: dispute

sentence: This is the core idea of this paper.
label: dispute

sentence: Thus, GBDT is just a tool we adopt to mine the patterns and do feature grouping since GBDT is an efficient and convenient method for these pre-processing tasks: 1) GBDT is very fast.
label: dispute

sentence: In most experiments, the total time cost of GBDT part in TabNN is about several minutes, while the NN part often needs several hours for training.
label: dispute

sentence: 2) the learning of GBDT is just based on statistical information over full dataset.
label: dispute

sentence: Thus, GBDT can learn the stable and robust feature combinations.
label: dispute

sentence: We can definitively replace GBDT with other methods, such as feature correlations, as long as they can achieve better performance then GBDT.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding the comments asking for the comparison with GBDT, we consider that they are not comparable since we are not inventing a model to beat GBDT, instead, we are developing a model to cover the scenarios not suitable for GBDT such as some applications need online updating.
label: dispute

sentence: This point has also been emphasized in our paper.
label: concur

sentence: 2. Heavy feature engineering and ad-hoc practical steps
label: nonarg

sentence: We are not sure why you conclude this point.
label: dispute

sentence: TabNN is a fully end-to-end learning approach with no need of an extra feature engineering step.
label: dispute

sentence: And as stated in the paper, the design of TabNN follows two principles: \emph{to explicitly leverages expressive feature combinations} and \emph{to reduce model complexity}. We cannot agree there are ad-hoc parts in the proposed model. Could you explain this with more details?
label: dispute

sentence: 3. Benchmark Dataset and Compared with Deep and Wide (D&W) NNs
label: nonarg

sentence: As stated in Section 2, D&W NNs and many related models can work well with high dimensional sparse features, which are usually in the form of one-hot encoding converted from categorical features.
label: concur

sentence: Actually, these NNs perform very well in such datasets, even better than GBDT.
label: dispute

sentence: In contrast, the proposed TabNN works better on another kinds of tabular data, with numerical features and low-cardinality categorical features.
label: dispute

sentence: Since there are many dummy dimensions in one-hot encoding, TabNN is hard to learn the useful features combinations from them.
label: dispute

sentence: Therefore, TabNN and D&W NNs are orthogonal with each other.
label: dispute

sentence: We can use them independently according to the feature types of data. And they can be used together for the data with mixed feature types.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, we did not conduct any experiment on data with high-cardinality categorical features.
label: dispute

sentence: We will state this clearer in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for your comments and suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: We respond to your questions and concerns as follows.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. Connection with principal-agent problems.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for pointing this out.
label: nonarg

sentence: We really appreciate it.
label: nonarg

sentence: The problem we address is indeed closely connected to principal-agent problems, or moral hazard problems in economics, which considers whether the agent makes the best choice for what the principal delegates (e.g., a plumber might make more money by suggesting an overhaul rather than a short-term fix).
label: concur

sentence: In this setting, there are a lot of issues to be modeled, e.g., information asymmetry between principals and agents, how to setup incentive cost, how to infer agents’ types and how to monitor their behaviors, etc.
label: concur

sentence: Traditional approaches [1] in economics build mathematical models to address these issues separately, leading to complicated models with many tunable parameters.
label: concur

sentence: In comparison, our paper provides a practical end-to-end computational framework to address this problem in a data-driven way, once the agents’ utility function is written down as a combination of principal’s request and its own preference (Eqn. 1).
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, this framework is adaptive to changes of agents’ preferences and capabilities, which very few papers in economics have addressed.
label: concur

sentence: Because of the connection to principal-agent problems and the data-driven nature of the proposed method, there could be a broad number of practical applications.
label: concur

sentence: We will incorporate a more thorough literature reviews in the next revision.
label: concur

sentence: [1] The theory of incentives: the principal-agent model, Jean-Jacques Laffont, 2001
label: nonarg

sentence: 2. More details should be given on the mind tracker module.
label: nonarg

sentence: We will explain more implementation details in the appendix in the next revision.
label: concur

sentence: We will also release the code.
label: concur

sentence: 3. Is it necessary to use deep reinforcement learning for contract generation?
label: nonarg

sentence: As stated in the introduction, one of the main points of this work is about incomplete information.
label: concur

sentence: I.e., we do not know the true agent models and their mental states, and also do not assume that the task dependency is known.
label: concur

sentence: In real world problems, we indeed can not assume that a manager knows the exact nature of other agents.
label: concur

sentence: So we want to train a manager that can quickly model worker agents through observations and simultaneously generate optimal contracts.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast, traditional methods do not consider task dependency, and usually assume agent types are either known or follow a given distribution.
label: concur

sentence: Also, deep models are flexible enough to handle complicated interactions between agents and changes of settings.
label: concur

sentence: Thus, deep RL is a more suitable approach than traditional methods under the incomplete information setting.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their detailed review and for their suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: We answer point by point:
label: nonarg

sentence: *FW vs BCFW*
label: nonarg

sentence: The (primal) proximal problem is created for a mini-batch of samples, and not for the entire data set (details in section 3.2).
label: dispute

sentence: In other words, the primal problem consists of the proximal term which encourages proximity to the current iterate, the linearized regularization, and the average over the mini-batch of the losses applied to the linearized model.
label: dispute

sentence: As a result, we can compute the Frank-Wolfe update for all dual coordinates simultaneously, and we do not need to operate in a block-coordinate fashion.
label: dispute

sentence: We have included this clarification in the new version of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Batch-Size*
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank the reviewer for this suggestion.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have adapted the description of Algorithm 1 accordingly.
label: concur

sentence: *Convex-Conjugate Loss*
label: nonarg

sentence: In order to compare the DFW algorithm to the strongest possible baselines, we choose the baselines to use the CE loss in the CIFAR experiments.
label: concur

sentence: Indeed we have generally found CE to help the baselines in this setting.
label: concur

sentence: In addition, the hand-designed learning rate schedule of SGD and the l2 regularization were originally tuned for CE.
label: concur

sentence: In the case of the SNLI data set, we allow the baseline to use either CE or SVM because using the hinge loss can increase their performance.
label: concur

sentence: Finally, we choose to always employ the multi-class hinge loss for DFW because it gives an optimal step-size in closed form for the dual, which is a key strength of the formulation.
label: concur

sentence: *BCFW vs BCD*
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank the reviewer for this recommendation.
label: nonarg

sentence: It would be interesting indeed to explore how to exploit such updates in the context of the composite minimization framework for deep neural networks.
label: concur

sentence: In our case, we emphasize that for speed reasons, it is crucial to process the samples within a mini-batch in parallel, and this does not look straightforward with the algorithm in [3, E.3].
label: concur

sentence: Therefore we believe that for this setting the FW algorithm permits faster updates thanks to an easy parallelization over the mini-batch on GPU.
label: concur

sentence: *Hyper-parameter*
label: nonarg

sentence: Counting a single hyper-parameter for SGD implicitly assumes that SGD can employ a constant step-size.
label: dispute

sentence: Using such a constant step-size for SGD would incur a significant loss of performance (e.g. at least a few percents on the CIFAR data set).
label: dispute

sentence: Therefore in order to obtain good performance, SGD requires a manual schedule of the learning rate, which involves many hyper-parameters to tune in practice.
label: dispute

sentence: Thanks for your insightful comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. How or why is the benefit.
label: nonarg

sentence: This comment is insightful and we also considered about it.
label: nonarg

sentence: Intuitively, we would easily fall into the connections between each sentence and image.
label: nonarg

sentence: However, it is nearly impossible to pair sentence with images with completely the same meaning all the time.
label: nonarg

sentence: According to our investigation, we conclude that the major contribution would be more effective contextualized sentence encoding for better representation from the visual clue combination instead of single image enhancement for encoding each individual sentence or word.
label: nonarg

sentence: According to Distributional Hypothesis (Harris et al., 1954) which states that “words that occur in similar contexts tend to have similar meanings”, we are inspired to extend the concept in multimodal world, “the sentences with similar meanings would be likely to pair with similar even the same images”, where the consistent images (with similar topic) could play the role of topic or type clues for similar sentence modeling.
label: nonarg

sentence: For your example, the topic words are {private, courts, table}, which can be paired with relevant images and other sentences with the same (similar) topics will be paired with the same (similar) group of images.
label: nonarg

sentence: This is also very similar to the idea of word embedding by taking each image as a “word”.
label: nonarg

sentence: Because we use the average pooled output of ResNet, each image is represented as 2400d vector.
label: nonarg

sentence: For all the 29,000 images, we have an embedding layer with size (29000, 2400).
label: nonarg

sentence: The “content” of the image is just like the embedding initialization.
label: nonarg

sentence: It indeed makes effects, but the capacity of the neural network is not up to it.
label: nonarg

sentence: In contrast, the mapping from text word to the index in the word embedding is critical.
label: nonarg

sentence: Similarly, the mapping of sentence to image in image embedding would be essential, i.e., the similar sentences (with the same topic words) tend to map the similar images.
label: nonarg

sentence: To verify the hypothesis, we shuffle the image embeddings but keep the lookup table, to only exchange the features of each image but maintain the sentence-image mapping.
label: nonarg

sentence: Unsurprisingly, the BLEU score (EN-RO) is 33.53, which is very close to the reported one (33.78).
label: nonarg

sentence: In addition, we randomly initialize the image embedding instead of ResNet, the result is 33.28.
label: nonarg

sentence: In comparison, if we randomly retrieve unrelated images to break the lookup, the result is 32.14.
label: nonarg

sentence: These results verify the necessity of the lookup table.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have added a detailed discussion in the paper (please see Analysis 6.1).
label: concur

sentence: We believe this finding would be suggestive for the future research since most previous work focused on the content of the image itself.
label: concur

sentence: As a different research line, we highlight the consistency among the mono-modality to bridge the gap of language and image modeling.
label: concur

sentence: 2. Why stop words are ignored.
label: nonarg

sentence: According to the explanation above, we think the spatial relations or grammatical nuances would not be so important in this task if we take the images as topic guidance.
label: nonarg

sentence: Ignoring the stopwords can help us get rid of the disturbance of unnecessary high-frequency words (such as function words) being the topic, as the standard practice for TF-IDF topic extraction.
label: nonarg

label: nonarg

sentence: We want to emphasize one point that we perhaps did not highlight enough in our paper: there are other existing algorithms that fall into the marginal policy gradients framework.
label: concur

sentence: Specifically, researchers and practitioners both almost always clip actions for use in robotics control environments (read: MuJoCo tasks).
label: concur

sentence: Recently, a reduced variance method was introduced by Fujita and Maeda (2018) for clipped action spaces.
label: concur

sentence: Their algorithm is also a member of the marginal policy gradients family and our theoretical results for MPG significantly tighten existing analyses of variance reduction that can be achieved for clipped actions.
label: concur

sentence: To respond to your question, yes it is possible (e.g. the example given above), but their is no general procedure that we know of to derive such methods.
label: concur

sentence: Rather, this would be done on an action space by action space basis

sentence: * models that get scores in the ~80 ppl range for Penn Treebank are important.

sentence: we agree with the advice but not with the justification.
label: dispute

sentence: We explain why in the general response: our goal is not to get good language models, but to use language modelling as a setting to test a property of a mechanism that is proposed.
label: dispute

sentence: The perplexity becomes a way to observer the effect of a mechanism and not the goal itself.
label: dispute

sentence: Moreover, (not in this case but) the architectures used to achieve better scores on given datasets are so over-parametrized that it's hardly reasonable to assume that the improvement justifies the cost of accommodating huge models overfitted to a particular dataset (and sometimes to a particular dataset configuration)
label: dispute

sentence: That said, we agree that using different architectures would strengthen our point and make the paper more convincing.
label: concur

sentence: Also, using different datasets would help us demonstrate that the effect of the proposed mechanism is data-independent.
label: concur

sentence: We are also considering it's application to a different set of tasks in the future.
label: concur

sentence: We did follow reviewer recommendations and performed experiments with LSTMs and QRNN (slightly faster) along with WikiText (which is larger but not intractable), unfortunately we couldn't accommodate all the analysis and changes in time.
label: concur

sentence: * its parameter-reduction approaches against other compression and hyperparameter optimization techniques.
label: nonarg

sentence: We recognize that the focus on parameter reduction was perhaps counter productive to making the goal or this work clear.
label: concur

sentence: It is a byproduct of the technique, but modelling discrete distributions without prior knowledge of how many classes one might encounter is the main issue we are trying to solve. We could do that by using character-level or sub-word tokens, but again, the goal is not --solely-- language modelling as a task.
label: dispute

sentence: The mechanism is applicable to settings where the number of possible input patterns is too large to instantiate as a parameter table (embeddings), but where the number of patterns that actually occur could actually more "reasonable". Meaning that as long as the "world" is not random uniform, we can make predictions.
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their time and comments on the work.
label: nonarg

sentence: Concerning including more comparison and ablations in the paper, we have performed an extended analysis of our method to the baselines across many environments.
label: concur

sentence: See Figures 2,3,5 for more learning curve results and baseline comparisons and Figure 6 for qualitative metric analysis.
label: concur

sentence: We show that our method outperforms the baselines across multiple environments.
label: concur

sentence: In the paper, we include many details on the environment rewards and design as we consider these simulation tasks part of the contribution of the work.
label: concur

sentence: The simulation tasks contain robotic humanoid characters that need to learn how to navigate given egocentric vision.
label: dispute

sentence: No other simulation is available that combines these challenges.
label: dispute

sentence: The simulation will be released with the work for others to use and build on multi-agent learning methods.
label: concur

sentence: We have reviewed the provided references and have included them in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: We thank Reviewer 3 for raising important questions.
label: nonarg

sentence: We answer them below.
label: nonarg

sentence: Using \tilde x in the E- and M-steps.
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree with Reviewer 3 that “the error arising from quantizing v into c is only affected by a subset of rows of \tilde x”.
label: dispute

sentence: However, we solve Equation (2) with this proxy algorithm for two reasons.
label: dispute

sentence: First, using the full \tilde x matrix allows to factor the computation of the pseudo-inverse of \tilde x and thus allows for a much faster algorithm, see answer to Reviewer 2 and the details of the M-step in the paper (as well as footnote 2).
label: dispute

sentence: Second, early (and slow) experiments suggested that the gains were not significant when using the right subsets of \tilde x in this particular context.
label: dispute

sentence: Minimizing the reconstruction error
label: nonarg

sentence: Our method results in both better reconstruction error and better training loss than naïve PQ *before* any finetuning.
label: concur

sentence: As we state in the paper, applying naive PQ without any finetuning to a ResNet-18 leads to accuracies below 18% for all operating points, whereas our method (without any finetuning) gives accuracy around 50% (not reported in the paper, we will add it in the next version of our paper).
label: concur

sentence: Choosing the optimal number of centroids/blocks size
label: nonarg

sentence: There is some rationale for the block size, related to the way the information is structured and redundant in the weight matrices (see in particular point 1 of answer to Reviewer 1).
label: concur

sentence: For instance, for convolutional weight filters with a kernel size of 3x3, the natural block size is 9, as we wish to exploit the spatial redundancy in the convolutional filters.
label: concur

sentence: For the fully-connected classifier matrices and 1x1 convolutions however, the only constraint on the block size if to be a divisor of the column size.
label: concur

sentence: Early experiments when trying to quantize such matrices in the row or column direction gave similar results.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding the number of centroids, we expect byte-aligned schemes (256 centroids indexed over 1 byte) to be more friendly for an efficient implementation of the forward in the compressed domain.
label: concur

sentence: Otherwise, as can be seen in Figure 3, doubling the number of centroids results in better performance, even if the curve tends to saturate around k=2048 centroids.
label: concur

sentence: As a side note, there exists some strategies that automatically adjust for those two parameters (see HAQ for example).
label: concur

sentence: Comparison with pruning and low-rank approximation
label: nonarg

sentence: We argue that both pruning and low-rank approximation are orthogonal and complementary approaches to our method, akin to what happens in image compression where the transform stage (e.g., DCT or wavelet) is complementary with quantization. See “Deep neural network compression by in-parallel pruning-quantization”, Tung and Mori for some works investigating this direction.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for raising useful points which helped us a lot improving the paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: The main point of the reviewer is that the novelty of our approach is limited with respect to the Evolutionary RL (ERL) algorithm, and that improvement is sometimes small.
label: nonarg

sentence: These remarks helped us realize that we had to better highlight the differences between our approach and ERL, both in terms of concepts and performance.
label: concur

sentence: We did so by replacing Figure 1, which was contrasting CEM-RL to CEM, with a figure directly contrasting CEM-RL to ERL.
label: concur

sentence: We also added Figure 6 which better highlights the properties of the algorithms and we performed several additional studies, described either in the main text or in appendices.
label: concur

sentence: By the way, the ERL paper is now published at NIPS, but it was not the case yet when we submitted ours. We updated the corresponding reference.
label: concur

sentence: The reviewer seems to consider that each actor in our CEM-RL algorithm comes with its own critic (the reviewer says value function), which would raise a value function initialization issue.
label: dispute

sentence: Actually, this is not the case: there is a single TD3 critic over the whole process, and gradient steps are applied to all the selected actors from that single critic.
label: dispute

sentence: This has been clarified in the text by insisting on the unicity of this critic.
label: concur

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that the importance mixing did not provide the sample efficiency improvement we expected, and we can only provide putative explanations of why so far.
label: concur

sentence: Nevertheless, we believe this mechanism still has some potential and is currently overlooked by most deep neuroevolution researchers, so we decided to keep the importance mixing study in Appendix B rather than just removing it.
label: dispute

sentence: Thank you for the time. We would like to take this opportunity to correct some factually incorrect statements below.
label: nonarg

sentence: [Q] The results of the paper do not give major insights into what are the preferred techniques for training GANs, and certainly not why and under what circumstances they'll work.
label: nonarg

sentence: [A]  We respectfully disagree.
label: dispute

sentence: To our knowledge, this is only the second work which attempts to fairly and systematically compare GANs in a large-scale setting.
label: dispute

sentence: The main conclusions of our work (about NS-GAN, spectral normalization, and gradient penalty) hold across several datasets and architectures.
label: dispute

sentence: [Q] But there is no attempt to generalize the findings (e.g. new datasets not from original study, changing other parameters and then evaluating again if these techniques help etc.),
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] We again respectfully disagree -- both LSUN and CelebaHQ are used for the first time in such a large-scale evaluation.
label: dispute

sentence: In fact, none of the techniques were previously evaluated on CelebaHQ.
label: dispute

sentence: Furthermore, even if some data sets, such as LSUN, were used previously, the comparison to other works was always done by the authors of the new method usually with additional changes, such as architectural decisions and optimization tricks.
label: dispute

sentence: [Q] Not clear if the improvement in performance is statistically significant, how robust it is to changes in other parameters etc.
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] In this we take care of systematically evaluating various design decisions.
label: concur

sentence: While the space of design decisions is too large to search over, we focus on the main design choices and provide some conclusions in this context.
label: concur

sentence: Performance improvements obtained by both spectral norm and gradient penalty are statistically significant as seen in the plots -- the performance with respect to the baseline is far outside of the two standard errors of the median in most settings.
label: concur

sentence: [Q] The authors also rely mostly on the FID metric, but do not show if and how there is improvement upon visual inspection of the generated images (i.e. is resolution improved, is fraction of images that look clearly 'unnatural' reduced etc.)
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] FID was shown to correlate well with perceived image quality (e.g. precision) and mode coverage (recall).
label: concur

sentence: The evidence can be found in [1], and [2].
label: concur

sentence: As such, a reduction in FID corresponds both to improved image quality, as well as improved mode coverage.
label: concur

sentence: IN practice, a 10% drop in FID is visible to a human, and samples can be seen in the Appendix.
label: concur

sentence: While it is not a perfect metric, it is arguably useful for sample-based relative comparison of generative models.
label: concur

sentence: [1] https://arxiv.org/abs/1711.10337
label: nonarg

sentence: [2] https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.00035
label: nonarg

sentence: [Q] The authors use numerous jargon words to describe the techniques studied (e.g. dragon penalty, gradient penalty, spectral normalization, Gaussian process regression in the bandit setting) but they do not explain them, give mathematical formulations, making it hard to the non-expert reader to understand what are these techniques and why are they introduced.
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] Most of these are described in Section 2 (in particular, discussion on regularization and penalties is in Section 2.2).
label: concur

sentence: Describing all aspects of these techniques would require substantially more space and hence we refer to the original work for precise formulation.
label: concur

sentence: [Q] With lack of clear novel insights, or at least more systematic study on additional datasets of the 'winning' techniques and a sensitivity analysis, the paper does not give a valuable enough contribution to the field to merit publication.
label: nonarg

sentence: [A] We respectfully disagree: we believe that for GAN practitioners our paper presents many useful insights, namely: NS-GAN performs well, spectral norm is a good default normalization technique, gradient penalty should also be considered, even in combination with spectral norm but will cost substantially more in terms of computational resources, popular metrics such as KID and FID result in the same relative ordering of the models so there is no point in computing both, most resnet tricks do not matter, etc.
label: dispute

sentence: All of these insights are supported by a fair and unbiased rigorous experimental process.
label: dispute

sentence: On top of that, our experiments are reproducible (as already reported by other works), we shared the resulting code and the pre-trained models.
label: dispute

sentence: Thanks again, Reviewer #1, for your thoughtful comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We respond to your other comments below.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1.  “It seems like one could detect most SVHN samples just by the virtue that there likelihoods are much higher than even the max threshold determined by the CIFAR-train histogram?”
label: nonarg

sentence: This is an interesting idea, but we are not sure it is applicable.
label: dispute

sentence: If one looks closely at Figure 2 (b), there are still blue and black histogram bars (denoting CIFAR-10 train and test instances) covering the entirety of SVHN’s support (red bars).
label: dispute

sentence: 2.  “[The constant input]’s mean (=0 trivially) is clearly different from the means of the CIFAR-10 images (Figure 6a) so the second order analysis of Section 5 doesn’t seem applicable.”
label: concur

sentence: See general response #2.
label: concur

sentence: 3.  “How much of this phenomena do you think is characteristic for images specifically? Would be interesting to test anomaly detection using deep generative models trained on modalities other than images.”
label: nonarg

sentence: We have not tested non-image data, since images are the primary focus of work on generative models, but this is an interesting area for future work.
label: concur

sentence: 4.  “Samples from a CIFAR model look nothing like SVHN. This seems to call the validity of the anomalous into question. Curious what the authors have to say about this.”
label: nonarg

sentence: This is a very good point.
label: concur

sentence: See our response to Shengyang Sun’s comment below.
label: concur

sentence: We see think this phenomenon has to do with concentration of measure and typical sets, but we do not yet have a rigorous explanation.
label: concur

sentence: 5.  “There seems to be some space crunching going on via Latex margin and spacing hacks that the authors should ideally avoid :)”
label: nonarg

sentence: We have fixed the spacing in the latest draft :)
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their encouraging feedback and thoughtful comments on our work.
label: nonarg

sentence: Regarding the permutation learning experiment, in response to the feedback, we have revised the main text to clarify the setup.
label: concur

sentence: The core of the experiment is the ability to denoise permuted images using some representation of the permutation set.
label: concur

sentence: In order to do this successfully, it is necessary for such a representation to have certain properties such as inducing a distribution over permutations.
label: concur

sentence: We have implemented and added a comparison to the Gumbel-Sinkhorn method (Mena et al., 2018), which is a customized representation for permutations with these properties, and requires similar techniques (unsupervised objective, permutation sampling, etc.) in order to learn the latent structure.
label: concur

sentence: The ResNet classifier on top can be viewed primarily as a way to evaluate the quality of the learned permutation; both of these representations are capable of learning the right latent structure, with test accuracies of 93.6 (Kaleidoscope) and 92.9 (Gumbel-Sinkhorn) respectively.
label: concur

sentence: The highlight of this experiment is that the K-matrix representation also comes with the requisite properties for this learning pipeline, despite not being explicitly designed for permutation learning.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding comparison to a dense matrix for the speech experiment, in Table 5 (Appendix B.1.2), we compare the use of K-matrices in the raw-features speech model with several other classes of matrices, including dense matrices.
label: concur

sentence: For instance, we find that, while using a trainable dense matrix slightly outperforms just using the fixed FFT (0.3% drop in test phoneme error rate), using a K-matrix instead of a dense matrix yields a further improvement of 0.8% in the phoneme error rate.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding ease of training and hyperparameter tuning, we would like to re-emphasize that for all experiments, all hyperparameters for training were kept the same as those for training the default model architecture, other than those we explicitly mentioned as being tuned.
label: concur

sentence: In particular, we did not modify any hyperparameters (such as number of epochs, optimizer, or learning rate) for the ShuffleNet and DynamicConv experiments.
label: concur

sentence: For the TIMIT speech experiment, we tune only the “preprocessing layer” learning rate.
label: concur

sentence: This is because the default speech pipeline already uses different learning rates for different portions of the network, so there is no clear choice a priori for the learning rate of the “preprocessing layer” (note that most methods, including K-matrices, do not seem to be overly sensitive to the choice of this learning rate).
label: concur

sentence: Thus, in these experiments, K-matrices can be used as a drop-in replacement for linear layers without significant tuning effort.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding structure and sparsity: We use “structure” in the context of structured matrices to mean matrices with a fast (subquadratic) multiplication algorithm.
label: concur

sentence: Structured matrices have a sparse factorization with total NNZ on the order of the number of operations required in the multiplication.
label: concur

sentence: This connection was known in the algebraic complexity community, and formalized by De Sa et al. (2018).
label: concur

sentence: Regarding the inductive bias encoded by K-matrices: the building block of K-matrices is a butterfly matrix, which encodes the recursive divide-and-conquer structure of many fast algorithms such as the FFT.
label: concur

sentence: Analyzing the precise effects of the inductive bias imposed by K-matrices is an exciting question for future work.
label: concur

sentence: We thank you for your useful feedback and suggestions for additional experiments, and are glad you found the connection we draw between verification and rare event estimation to be an interesting idea.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. "How does the performance of the proposed method scale wrt scalability? It will be useful to do an ablation study, i.e. keep the input model fixed and slowly increase the dimension."
label: nonarg

sentence: This is a great question and something we have been looking into.
label: nonarg

sentence: As a first step, we have run a new experiment at a higher scale with the CIFAR-100 dataset and a far larger DenseNet-40/40 architecture as discussed in the response to Reviewer 1.
label: concur

sentence: We see our approach still performs very effectively on this larger problem, for which most existing verification approaches would struggle due to memory requirements (see also our new comparisons in Section 6.4).
label: concur

sentence: We are now working on doing an ablation study on the size of the input dimension x, but it is unlikely we will be finished with this before the end of the rebuttal period due to the fact that it will require a very large number of runs to generate.
label: concur

sentence: 2. "Did you experiment with other MH proposal beyond a random walk proposal?"
label: nonarg

sentence: That’s an excellent idea and a topic for future research.
label: concur

sentence: We didn’t experiment with a MH proposal beyond a random walk because this was the simplest thing to try and it already worked well in practice.
label: concur

sentence: As well as different proposals, we have also been thinking about the possibility to instead use a more advanced Langevin Monte Carlo approach to replace the MH, which we expect to mix more quickly as the chains are guided by the gradient information.
label: concur

sentence: 3. "What is the performance of the proposed method against 'universal adversarial examples'?"
label: nonarg

sentence: “Universal adversarial examples” refers to a method for constructing adversarial perturbations that generalize across data points for a given model, often generalizing across models too.
label: concur

sentence: Our method does not give a measure of robustness with respect to a particular attack method - it is attack agnostic.
label: dispute

sentence: It measures in a sense the “volume” of adversarial examples around a given input, and so if this is negligible then the network is robustness to any attack for that subset of the input space, whether by a universal adversarial example or another method.
label: dispute

sentence: All the same, investigating the use of our approach in a more explicitly adversarial example setting presents an interesting opportunity for future work.
label: concur

sentence: 4. "The most interesting question is whether this method gives reasonable robustness estimates even for large networks such as AlexNet?"
label: nonarg

sentence: This is an important point to address.
label: concur

sentence: As previously mentioned, we have extended the experiment of section 6.3 to use the much larger DenseNet-40/40 architecture on CIFAR-100 and we see that our method still performs admirably.
label: concur

sentence: See the updated paper and our response to Reviewer 1 above.
label: nonarg

sentence: 5. "Please provide some intuition for this line in Figure 3: 'while the robustness to perturbations of size epsilon=0.3 actually starts to decrease after around 20 epochs.'"
label: nonarg

sentence: The epsilon used during the training method of Wong and Kolter (ICML 2018) is annealed from 0.01 at epoch 0 to 0.1 at epoch 50.
label: concur

sentence: It’s interesting from Figure 5 that the network is made robust to epsilon = 0.1 and 0.2 by training to be robust using a much smaller epsilon.
label: concur

sentence: The network appears to become less robust for epsilon = 0.3 as the training epsilon reaches 0.1.
label: concur

sentence: So this a counterintuitive result that training using a smaller epsilon may be better for overall robustness.
label: concur

sentence: One hypothesis for this is that the convex outer adversarial polytope is insufficiently tight for larger epsilon.
label: concur

sentence: Another hypothesis may be that training with a lower epsilon has a greater effect on the adversarial gradient at an input, as the training happens on a perturbation closer to that input.
label: concur

sentence: 6. "A number of attack and defense strategies have been proposed in the literature.
label: nonarg

sentence: Isn't it possible to use the proposed method to quantify the increase in the robustness towards an attack model using a particular defense strategy? If it is possible to show that the results of the proposed method match the conclusions from these papers, then this will be an important contribution."
label: nonarg

sentence: It is possible to quantify the increase in robustness using a particular defense strategy, as we do in section 6.4 for the robust training method of Wong and Kolter (ICML 2018).
label: dispute

sentence: We find that our method is in agreement with theirs.
label: dispute

sentence: To quantify the increase in “robustness” with respect to a particular attack method, you can simply record the success of the attack method over samples from the test set as the training proceeds.
label: concur

sentence: This will not, however, be a reliable measure of robustness as the network can be trained to be resistant to the attack method in question while not being resistant to attack methods yet-to-be devised (the adversarial “arms race”).
label: concur

sentence: We believe that what we really desire is an attack agnostic robustness measure, such as the method in our work.
label: dispute

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We address their comments individually below.
label: nonarg

sentence: > The work is more suitable for a bioinformatics audience though, as the bigger contribution is on the particular application, rather than the model / method itself.
label: nonarg

sentence: The main contribution of this paper is the representation of the protein interaction data in the input layer of the CNN
label: nonarg

sentence: Response: The main contribution and novelty of this paper is the demonstration of the transferrability and power of the learned representation, and thus is a good fit for ICLR.
label: nonarg

sentence: We use the application of protein interface prediction as a test case for this, but applications can range widely from drug discovery, to RNA folding, to small molecule quantum mechanical calculations.
label: nonarg

sentence: As many of these tasks are very data-poor, this demonstrated transferrability opens up novel avenues through which these problems can be tackled.
label: nonarg

sentence: > - Their method improves over prior deep learning approaches to this problem.
label: nonarg

sentence: However, the results are a bit misleading in their reporting of the std error.
label: nonarg

sentence: They should try different train/test splits and report the performance.
label: nonarg

sentence: Response: We do use different subsets of the train set for different replicates.
label: dispute

sentence: However, the train and test sets cannot be mixed as they come from different data distributions (P_r and P_p) and we are trying to show we can transfer with no retraining from P_r to P_p.
label: dispute

sentence: Thus our reported metrics are correct and justified for this problem, though we have clarified the exact nature of the replicates in the text to ensure this is not misleading.
label: concur

sentence: > - The authors should include citations and motivation for some of their choices (what sequence identity is used, what cut-offs are used etc)
label: nonarg

sentence: Response: We do provide citations for these choices.
label: dispute

sentence: See the second and third paragraphs of section 3 on page 4 for motivation/citations for sequence identity and cut-offs used, respectively.
label: dispute

sentence: The authors should compare to at least some popular previous approaches that use a feature engineering based methodology such as - IntPred
label: nonarg

sentence: Response: Fout et al. and Sanchez-Garcia et al. are feature engineering approaches -- they both use high-level features as inputs to their models (not atomic coordinates).
label: nonarg

sentence: Sanchez-Garcia et al. use a tree ensemble model that has no end-to-end learning aspects at all.
label: nonarg

sentence: Another popular pure feature engineering approach is PAIRPred (Minhas et al., Protein 2014), which uses an SVM trained on high-level features.
label: nonarg

sentence: However, we do not compare to them as their performance on C_p^{test} (0.863)  was already superseded in Fout et al.’s work.
label: dispute

sentence: IntPred [Northey et al., Bioinformatics 2017] addresses the binding site prediction problem (given one protein, which residues can be interfacial with any other protein), which is different than the problem we present.
label: dispute

sentence: > - The authors use a balanced ratio of positive and negative examples.
label: nonarg

sentence: The true distribution of interacting residues is not balanced -- there are several orders of magnitude more non-interacting residues than interacting ones.
label: nonarg

sentence: Can they show performance at various ratios of positive:negative examples?
label: nonarg

sentence: In case there is a consistent improvement over prior methods, then this would be a clear winner
label: nonarg

sentence: Response: We can demonstrate consistent performance at different ratios of positive:negative examples.
label: nonarg

sentence: Running tests on C_p^{test} at 1:3, 1:5, and 1:10 ratios demonstrate no significant impact on performance (0.889 [0.882 +/- 0.012], 0.889 [0.882 +/- 0.011], and 0.895 [0.886 +/- 0.015], respectively).
label: concur

sentence: The AUROC metric we use is insensitive to class imbalance, and thus is a good measure to use when evaluating on datasets with varying amounts of imbalance.
label: nonarg

sentence: Many thanks for the valuable feedback! We uploaded a revised version of the paper, and in the following address the weaknesses you pointed out:
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for your reviews.
label: nonarg

sentence: Here are our responses to your questions:
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. Clarify how the skills of agents play a role in the problem setup
label: nonarg

sentence: We clarify the definition of skills and how it influences the manager’s decision as follows.
label: concur

sentence: i) As defined in Section 3, an agent’s skill depends on its state transition probabilities and its policy.
label: concur

sentence: The state transition probabilities define if a resource can be collected by an agent (i.e., whether the “collect” action executed by this agent will have real effect), and it is equivalent to a binary value for each resource in Resource Collection.
label: concur

sentence: The agent’s skill also depends on its policy because it affects how fast an agent can achieve a goal.
label: concur

sentence: E.g., when the agent has a suboptimal policy, it may not be able to reach a goal within the time limit even though it actually can collect the resource if given more time.
label: concur

sentence: ii) The skills are completely hidden from the manager.
label: concur

sentence: It can be inferred by the manager based on the performance history, and also on the estimated worker policies by IL.
label: concur

sentence: However, only checking whether a goal is reached is not sufficient to determine skills.
label: concur

sentence: Failing to reach a goal may be a result of several reasons -- it may be because i) the bonus in the contract is too low, ii) the contract terminates prematurely before the agent can reach the goal, or iii) the assigned task depends on another task which has not been finished yet.
label: concur

sentence: So the manager needs to infer agents’ skills, preferences, and the task dependency jointly through multiple trials.
label: concur

sentence: 2. Is maximizing utility justified?
label: nonarg

sentence: Maximizing utility is actually the setup in similar problems in economics.
label: concur

sentence: Just like those problems (e.g., mechanism design), this paper focuses on scenarios where agents won’t truthfully or clearly reveal its skills and preferences to the manager, and do not always behave optimally.
label: concur

sentence: As we stated in the paper, maximizing utility is more realistic, and typically the span of the decision making process of the manager is much shorter than the time needed for improving worker agents.
label: concur

sentence: Let’s consider a simple scenario.
label: concur

sentence: An agent is unable to collect a certain kind of resource.
label: concur

sentence: By maximizing its utility, it may still accept the contract and go to that resource.
label: concur

sentence: Once a resource is occupied by this agent, other agents can no longer collect it according to our setting.
label: concur

sentence: This means that the resource will never be really collected.
label: concur

sentence: As an empirical evidence,  you may compare the S2 and S3 settings with S1 in Resource Collection.
label: concur

sentence: In S2 and S3, workers may prefer a task that it can not perform, which should never happen in the case of maximizing return.
label: concur

sentence: As a result (shown in Figure 4b and Figure 4c), the training difficult significantly increases.
label: concur

sentence: 3. Are there alternate ways to overcome maintaining the UCB explicitly, especially for the number of time-steps?
label: nonarg

sentence: Yes, there are ways to overcome this.
label: concur

sentence: First, we can define small time intervals instead of maintaining statistics for each step (i.e., combining statistics in every dT consecutive steps will reduce the complexity to 1 / dT of the original size).
label: concur

sentence: Note that this has been done in results shown in Appendix C.1, where dT also means that for every dT steps, the manager can only change the contracts once.
label: concur

sentence: Second, we may define a maximum number of steps to be considered in the performance history, which can be determined by the upper bound of the execution time for a subtask, and can be smaller than the step limit of the whole episode.
label: concur

sentence: 4. What are the units for rewards in the plots?
label: nonarg

sentence: It is the average per episode.
label: concur

sentence: The reward is defined as in Section 5.1.1 and Section 5.1.2 without any rescaling.
label: concur

sentence: We have added this in the caption.
label: concur

sentence: 5. Typos
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for pointing out these typos. We will fix them in the next revision.
label: concur

sentence: However, although the proposed method achieves good performance over various (smaller) benchmarks, the method seems ad-hoc and complicated.
label: nonarg

sentence: As pointed out in the weakness section, many design choices are not well motivated, and the effects of those designs are not well studied.
label: nonarg

sentence: A: While ReMixMatch comprises many components (some of which are new), we believe our ablation study justifies the reason why each component exists. If there are additional ablation experiments that you think would be helpful for us to run, please let us know.
label: dispute

sentence: 2. The objective of the update equation of CTAugment’s learned weights seems contradicted with the purpose of how data augmentation is used
label: nonarg

sentence: A: It is true that CTAugment at any point in time will only perform augmentations that the model correctly predicts.
label: concur

sentence: However, we select augmentations where the probability the model output will change is less than 1.
label: dispute

sentence: As such, the augmentation boundary will grow progressively as the training process converges.
label: dispute

sentence: (We experimentally observe this fact: for example, rotation is initially only invariant up to +/- 13 degrees but throughout training becomes invariant to +/- 30 degrees.)
label: concur

sentence: We don’t aim to maximize the output variation at any instant, but instead ensure that by the end of training the model is invariant to large perturbations.
label: concur

sentence: 3. The authors should provide ablation study and analysis of their CTAugment.
label: nonarg

sentence: A: As also discussed with reviewer 2, for space reasons we provided only a short description of CTAugment, and how it differs from AutoAugment.
label: concur

sentence: We updated the draft to include a longer treatment in the appendix.
label: concur

sentence: Although we were not able to provide theoretical analysis in this paper, our proposed attacks are very effective on state-of-the-art adversarial training methods, and we believe our conclusions
