sentence: * We included a table showing accuracy numbers for different values of beta and M (see p. 6, Table 1) for the latent bottleneck sizes K=256 (Figure 2) and K=2 (Figure 3).
label: concur

sentence: In relation to the figures, we have improved these in the revision.
label: concur

sentence: We are added a figure tracing the mutual information between representation and output I(Z;Y) vs. the minimality term I(Z;X) for different values of beta (see Figure 2, lower right panel), when training with our loss function.
label: concur

sentence: This is the usual information bottleneck curve.
label: concur

sentence: This contrasts with the deficiency bottleneck curve (Figure 2, upper right panel) which traces the corresponding sufficiency term J(Z;Y) (which is just the entropy of the labels minus our loss) vs. I(Z;X) for different values of beta.
label: concur

sentence: Note that for M=1, J(Z;Y) = I(Z;Y).
label: concur

sentence: We apologize for the confusion.
label: concur

sentence: The text now makes this more explicit (see p.7, first paragraph).
label: concur

sentence: In response to your question about how we estimate the mutual information
label: nonarg

sentence: Yes, we minimize an upper bound on both the deficiency and the rate term (see p.3, equation 3 and discussion leading up to the VDB objective in equation 4).
label: concur

sentence: The estimation of this upper bound is simplified by our choice of the prior and the encoding distribution which are diagonal Gaussians.
label: concur

sentence: The KL term can be computed and differentiated without estimation.
label: concur

sentence: We estimate the expected loss term using Monte Carlo sampling.
label: concur

sentence: We draw samples from the encoder using the reparameterization trick and leverage automatic differentiation (in Tensorflow) to compute the gradients.
label: concur

sentence: Since the expectation is inside the log, gradient updates may have higher variance for larger values of M.
label: concur

sentence: Our model is a classifier and our loss term is a tighter bound on the misclassification error (bias) than the usual cross-entropy loss as in the VIB (see p. 12, equation 13).
label: concur

sentence: Trading bias for variance has been investigated in some recent works (see, e.g., Bamler, Robert, et al. "Perturbative black box variational inference." NIPS 2017).
label: nonarg

sentence: See last paragraph in p. 18 for the related discussion in the unsupervised setting.
label: nonarg

sentence: * In relation to the connection to IWAE, we have included a detailed discussion in Appendix E.1.
label: concur

sentence: The method is different from ours, except in the limiting case where M = 1 and beta =1, in which case it coincides with the beta-VAE and also with our method.
label: concur

sentence: After taking a close look, we make the following observations:
label: concur

sentence: For M > 1, the IWAE bound does not admit a decomposition like the standard ELBO (see equation 29 and 36) into a reconstruction loss term and a regularization term.
label: concur

sentence: In particular, this implies we cannot trade-off reconstruction fidelity for learning more meaningful representations by incorporating bottleneck constraints.
label: concur

sentence: See ensuing discussion in p.18 following equation 36.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast, our method has a tuning parameter beta.
label: nonarg

sentence: The IWAE bound is known to be equivalent to the ELBO in expectation with a more complex approximate posterior qIW (see p.17, equation 34 and 35 and references therein in Appendix E.1).
label: concur

sentence: For beta values other than 1, a naive trick would be to plant qIW in liue of qphi in equation 37 (p. 18) to get a beta-IWAE of sorts.
label: concur

sentence: It is not entirely clear however, why we would want to do so when modulating beta already suffices to tune the VAE towards autoencoding (low beta) or autodecoding behavior (high beta) depending on the requirement at hand.
label: concur

sentence: A similar argument goes in the direction of an "Importance weighted Variational Information Bottleneck".
label: concur

sentence: We have not explored if and how using more expressive posteriors such as the qIW (p. 17, equation 35) can help the supervised bottleneck formulations in VDB or VIB.
label: concur

sentence: This remains a scope for future study.
label: concur

sentence: We are now also citing the paper Yuri Burda, Roger Grosse, Ruslan Salakhutdinov. Importance Weighted Autoencoders. ICLR 2016.
label: concur

sentence: - Indeed there are a huge number of papers on adversarial examples, but specifically only a small fraction  of them are
label: dispute

sentence: about the  transferability of adversarial examples .

sentence: Indeed we do not provide a perfect explanation in this submission, however the factors we have considered and the well-designed numerical investigations could be helpful for future studies on this topic.

sentence: In addition, the works Fawzi'15 and Athalye'18 did not talk about the issue of adversarial transferability.

sentence: 1.  “Why investigate a component specific to just flow-based models (the volume term)? It seems reasonable to suspect that the phenomenon may be due to a common cause in all three model types.”
label: nonarg

sentence: See general response #3.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2.  “For instance, the experiments seem to indicate that generalizing density estimation from CIFAR training set to CIFAR test set is likely challenging and thus the models underfit the true data distribution, resulting in the simpler dataset (SVHN) having higher likelihood.“
label: nonarg

sentence: We do not believe our models are necessarily underfit.
label: dispute

sentence: In fact, we found that Glow had a tendency to *overfit,* and that one must carefully set Glow’s l2 penalty and choose its scale parametrization (exp vs sigmoid, see Appendix D) in order to prevent it from doing so.
label: dispute

sentence: We thought this overfitting to the training data could be a reason for the phenomenon and therefore we tuned our implementations to have reasonable generalization.
label: dispute

sentence: 3.  “It would have been nice if this paper explored more than just MNIST vs NotMNIST and SVHN vs CIFAR10, so that the readers can gain a better feel for when generative models will be able to detect outliers.
label: nonarg

sentence: For instance, a scenario where the data statistics (pixel means and variances) are nearly equivalent for both datasets would be interesting.”
label: nonarg

sentence: See general response #1 in regards to data sets and additional results.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for the suggestion of looking at data sets with similar statistics.
label: concur

sentence: We do this, in a way, with our second order analysis and the ‘gray-ing’ experiment in Figure 5 (b) (formerly Figure 6 (b) in the original draft).
label: concur

sentence: Gray CIFAR-10 (blue dotted line) nearly overlaps with original SVHN (red solid line) in terms of their log p(x) evaluations.
label: concur

sentence: Figure 12 (formerly Figure 13) then shows the latent (empirical) distribution of the gray images, and we see that the gray CIFAR-10 latent variables nearly overlap with the SVHN latent variables.
label: concur

sentence: This is to be expected though, given the overlapping p(x) histograms, since the probability assigned by CV-Glow (in comparison to other inputs) is fully determined by the position in latent space.
label: concur

sentence: 4.  “The second order analysis is good but it seems to come down to just a measure of the empirical variances of the datasets.”
label: nonarg

sentence: See general response #2.

sentence: Many thanks for the valuable feedback! We uploaded a revised version of the paper, and in the following address the weaknesses you pointed out:
label: nonarg

sentence: - We added a few sentences to the end of section 2.4 on our speculative intuition regarding what strategy a model may prefer, and we do indeed think that a pairing-based strategy is plausible for convolution-based networks.
label: concur

sentence: When talking in more general terms about "deep learning models", we refer to the proposed methodology for "investigating deep learning models", and don't want to claim that we actually evaluate a representative number of models.
label: concur

sentence: We see this methodology, as illustrated by our experiments for one model, as the central part of our contribution.
label: concur

sentence: The first paragraph of section 3.2 describes this FiLM model and, given the focus on methodology, we considered the description (plus reference to the paper) sufficient here.
label: concur

sentence: - There are a few points here:
label: nonarg

sentence: Since it was shown that humans seem to follow a cardinality-based strategy, the pairing-based one would be not human-like, but nonetheless cognitively plausible.
label: concur

sentence: We use "cognitively" in the sense of "algorithmically" plausible, so a procedure that makes sense for solving the problem.
label: concur

sentence: An example for an implausible method would be to rely on color/shape cues to solve instances involving "most", which doesn't make sense for the abstract meaning of "most".
label: concur

sentence: Regarding the question whether comparability to human behavior is indispensable: On the one hand, acceptance of and reliance on systems which follow vastly different principles can be problematic; on the other hand, if the information a system uses to arrive at its conclusion doesn't make any sense to humans (in cases where humans have an intuition what is relevant, like the above example of "most" and color/shape cues), we doubt that good performance alone will justify using such a model, as opposed to instead doubting the quality of the underlying benchmark data.
label: concur

sentence: * The question whether we want a VQA system which returns approximate answers is an interesting one, but we don't intend to claim that this is a desired property, just that it is desirable to know whether (and how exactly) our systems currently solve such tasks approximately.
label: concur

sentence: A conclusion from our findings may well be that it is worth improving VQA models with respect to their counting capability, as they seem to rely on an approximate as opposed to an exact number system.
label: concur

sentence: - We added a longer footnote to section 2.4 about the "one-glance feed-forward-style networks" for clarification.
label: concur

sentence: In summary, general precise counting is an inherently recursive ability, and models which don't have an architectural module for recursive computations are not expected to be able to learn this capability, while they may stil learn to subitize or represent numbers approximately (which doesn't require recursion).
label: concur

sentence: - You're right, this sentence was a bit vague, we rephrased it to: "these models can indeed learn and utilize more abstract concepts (approximate numbers) than mere superficial pattern matching ("red square" etc)".
label: concur

sentence: The differences we want to point out is that, on the one hand, (approximate) numbers are a more abstract concept than, for instance, object types like "cat", "chair", etc as they can be combined with any object type. On the other hand, being able to utilize such representations to answer practical questions like whether "most" applies is more interesting than just being able to classify which representation applies.
label: concur

sentence: - Good point, our reasoning here was mostly influenced by Pietroski et al.'s work and our intuition about the ability of convolutions to learn a local pairing strategy (see addition at the end of section 2.4).
label: concur

sentence: Presumably, it could be possible to observe the behavior in our paper based on a pairing-based mechanism which works approximately, independent of clustering, as predicted by Weber's Law.
label: concur

sentence: It's probably impossible to ultimately rule out a pairing-based strategy via experiments evaluating extrinsic behavior only, but we note that there is evidence for Weber's Law in other approximate systems where pairing-based strategies are no alternative, thus suggesting that similar mechanisms are at work here.
label: concur

sentence: We added a footnote on this to section 2.4.
label: concur

sentence: - There are a few papers focusing solely on "most" in psycholinguistics (like the ones cited) and linguistics in general (e.g., formal semantics), many of which talk about cardinality as a "core concept" of human cognition, and many of which contrast a more subconscious concept of cardinality (like the approximate number system) with the conscious algorithmic ability for precise and infinite counting.
label: concur

sentence: - We consistently use "interpretation" in the new version.
label: concur

sentence: - Fixed.
label: concur

sentence: - We think that our approach and particularly its inspiration by experiments from psychology are a substantial contribution to evaluation methodology in the context of powerful deep learning models, which are not infrequently described by anthropomorphizing words like "understand" and compared to "human-level" performance (added a sentence to the introduction).
label: dispute

sentence: The reason for exceeding 8 pages in length is likely due to the more elaborate introduction of the various concepts from Pietroski et al.'s work and experimental methodology in psychology in general, which we assume the audience of this conference is not very familiar with.
label: dispute

sentence: i) We visualize the latent vectors obtained from demonstrations with probing and without probing.
label: concur

label: concur

sentence: ii) We also show the correlation between the distance of two consecutive latent vectors m^{t-1} and m^t and, the KL divergence between the two corresponding policies KL(\pi(a|s^{t+1},m^t) || \pi(a|s^{t+1},m^{t-1})), i.e., how different the policy would have been if m^t didn’t change.
label: concur

sentence: The correlation is significant, and thus validates the idea.
label: concur

sentence: 4. 1) how well will this method work with a human acting as the demonstrator? and 2) how can this method work if you are not able to have access to a demonstrator long periods of time (or even at all)?
label: nonarg

sentence: We focus on improving modeling machine agents, and applying the improved agent models for multi-agent tasks.
label: concur

sentence: The current form of our approach is not designed for learning from human demonstrations.
label: concur

sentence: However, there are ways to modify our approach towards that direction: i) learning probing policy with model-based RL; ii) incorporating inductive bias from humans (e.g., the learner knows a specific set of possible goals of the demonstrator and probes the demonstrator to test which goal it has).
label: concur

sentence: This seems to be a good direction for future work, but we also think that the current research has provided promising results in simpler domains, and hopefully incites more research where human demonstrators are also involved by introducing this problem to the community.
label: concur

sentence: 5. I think this method demonstrates a method for improved collaborative and/or competitive performances given the fact that you already have a single agent with a learned policy.
label: nonarg

sentence: Yes, in our experiment, we do assume that the opponent has a learned policy which is unknown to us.
label: nonarg

sentence: We think that this is a quite general setting where multiple machine agents are interacting with each other but do not know each other’s true policies and intentions.
label: nonarg

sentence: Indeed, GPipe [2] incurs less memory footprint than our pipelining scheme and PipeDream [1] because it only saves the activations at the boundary of each model partition and re-computes the activations of the model during the backward pass.
label: concur

sentence: However, the re-computation still incurs pipeline bubbles during training.
label: concur

sentence: Our scheme saves all activations instead of re-computing them to eliminate pipeline bubble, thus achieving better utilization for the accelerators (GPUs).
label: concur

sentence: Our scheme has less memory footprint than PipeDream because it does not stash weights.
label: concur

sentence: The main goal of our submission is to experimentally show that our pipelined training, using stale weights without weight stashing [1] or micro-batching [2], is simpler and does converge.
label: concur

sentence: The paper does achieve this goal, on a number of networks.
label: concur

sentence: It would be difficult fit a detailed convergence analysis in our paper given the limited space provided.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for pointing out paper [3].

sentence: Thank you for your comments.

label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their helpful feedback on our work.
label: nonarg

sentence: Regarding the IWSLT translation result, the key claim we aim to validate is that the theoretical efficiency of K-matrices translates to practical speedups on real models as well.
label: concur

sentence: We agree that there are other approaches that may offer different model quality vs. inference speed tradeoffs; we simply highlight that K-matrices are one promising method, especially given their important theoretical properties.
label: concur

sentence: We have added a performance comparison of K-matrices with other structured replacements such as circulant, Fastfood, ACDC, and Toeplitz-like in Appendix B.4.3, showing that K-matrices yield faster inference with similar BLEU score.
label: concur

sentence: We also point out that our DynamicConv model with K-matrices in the decoder attains a comparable BLEU score with the state-of-the-art from two years ago – the Transformer model, which continues to enjoy widespread use today – while having over 60% higher sentence throughput and 30% fewer parameters than this model.
label: concur

sentence: As mentioned in the shared response, we believe that the speed-quality tradeoff of K-matrices could be further improved with more extensively tuned and optimized implementations.
label: concur

sentence: Exploring how to continue to improve these structured compression approaches, while retaining the efficiency and theoretical benefits of K-matrices, is an exciting question for future investigation.
label: concur

sentence: [InfoGAN] Compared to InfoGAN, our method is novel in two ways: First, we use separate networks to obtain the image embeddings, which enables us to guide some of these networks with simple functions.

sentence: Second, we use pairwise similarity/dissimilarity in order to perform disentangling, which is different from InfoGAN's approach of maximizing the label likelihood.

sentence: The main purpose of this paper is to introduce a new method to solve global optimization problem via replica exchange Langevin diffusion.
label: nonarg

sentence: We quantify the acceleration effect from the viewpoint of continuous time process.
label: nonarg

sentence: Although this work is inspired from Dupuis's work, their setting is MCMC and they only investigate by large deviation.
label: dispute

sentence: We quantify the acceleration effect by both large deviation and chi^2 divergence.
label: dispute

sentence: Besides, the large deviation rate function in our paper is different with that of Dupuis's since we use an alternative approach.
label: dispute

sentence: We choose such a form of rate function because it is connected to the Dirichlet form, and hence, the convergence of chi^2 divergence.
label: dispute

sentence: We acknowledge that our analysis tools is standard and not fancy in mathematics.
label: concur

sentence: However, this is not a mathematics conference after all.
label: dispute

sentence: One of our contribution is applying standard mathematical tools to a specific machine learning problem.
label: concur

sentence: Finally, another contribution is that we propose a discretized algorithm.
label: concur

sentence: Although Dupuis& et.al's work establishes beautiful and complicated mathematical theory for replica exchange Langevin diffusions, they does not consider the discretization at all.
label: concur

sentence: In practice, we can only use the discretized one instead of the ideal continuous process to solve problems.
label: concur

sentence: Our theory quantifies the discretization error and convergence rate and hence, ensures the validity to use the discretized algorithm.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We address their comments individually below.
label: nonarg

sentence: > My overall concern is that the experiment result doesn’t really fully support the claim in the two aspects: 1) the SASNet takes the enriched dataset as input to the neural net but it also uses the complex (validation set) to train the optimal parameters, so strictly it doesn’t really fit in the “transfer” learning scenario.
label: nonarg

sentence: Response: Our work is indeed not classical transfer learning -- it is in fact an even stricter variant.
label: nonarg

sentence: We do not re-train the parameters of the neural network at all using C_p, which is typically done as a “fine-tuning” step in the transfer learning scenario.
label: nonarg

sentence: So while we do use C_p^{val} for model selection (i.e., hyperparameter tuning), this is still much less use of the data-poor dataset than in the common transfer learning setting of actually fine-tuning the parameters of the neural network using a subset of the data from the data-poor dataset.
label: nonarg

sentence: The use of C_p^{val} for hyperparameter tuning was incidental and not a central point of our paper.
label: dispute

sentence: To really make this clear, we have updated the paper to demonstrate that even if we do not use C_p^{val} for model selection, and instead select from the same class of models we previously generated by using a randomly selected held-out set C_r^{val}, we still obtain state-of-the-art performance (0.892 [0.885 +/- 0.009]).
label: concur

sentence: In this formulation, C_p is not used at all by our method until test time.
label: nonarg

sentence: > Also, the compared methods don’t really use the validation set from the complex data for training at all.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thus the experiment comparison is not really fair.
label: nonarg

sentence: The competing models do make use of validation set C_p^{val} from the complex data to select amongst the most important hyperparameters of their model -- which is equivalent to what we did in our initial formulation, and favors the competing methods compared to if we use C_r^{val} for hyperparameter search instead.
label: dispute

sentence: > 2) The experiment results include standard errors for different replicates where such replicates correspond to different training random seeds (or different samples from the enriched set?), however, it doesn’t include any significance of the sampling.
label: nonarg

sentence: Specifically, the testing dataset is fixed.
label: nonarg

sentence: A more rigorous setting is to, for N runs, each run splitting the validation and testing set differently.
label: nonarg

sentence: Response: The replicates correspond to different training and validation samples of the enriched set -- we have clarified this in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: While it is true that the hyperparameter validation set was initially fixed, the switch to use C_r^{val} as above resolves this.
label: nonarg

sentence: The testing data C_p^{test} is that which has been used in the prior works we compare to (Fout et al. 2017; Sanchez-Garcia et al. 2018).
label: nonarg

sentence: Furthermore, use of this subset for performance evaluation is justified as as C_p^{test} corresponds to latest released structures in C_p, leading to a more accurate assessment of how such methods would perform on unreleased structures (as they do no sequence identity pruning).
label: nonarg

sentence: Thus our experimental set up
label: dispute

sentence: is rigorous and justified.
label: dispute

sentence: > Since this paper is an application paper, rather than a theoretical paper that bears theoretical findings, I would expect much more thorough experimental setup and analysis.
label: nonarg

sentence: Currently it is still missing discussion such as, when SASNet would perform better and when it would perform worse, what it is that the state of the art features can’t capture while SASNet can.
label: nonarg

sentence: Response: As we discuss above, we believe our experimental setup and analysis is sufficient to demonstrate that our atomic representation transfers much better across atomic tasks.
label: dispute

sentence: We have also added to our discussion, making clear that our method represents a significant advantage over competing methods when detailed atomic information is available.
label: dispute

sentence: Competitors rely on amino acid-level features that fail to capture specific atomic positions but can be better when the structural is less detailed or accurate.
label: dispute

sentence: > Moreover, it is the prediction performance that matters to such task, but the authors remove the non-structure features from the compared methods.
label: nonarg

sentence: Results and discussion about how the previous methods with full features perform compared to SASNet, and also how we can include those features into SASNet should complete the paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: Response:
label: nonarg

sentence: As our paper is primarily about the power and transferrability of our structural features for atomic tasks, we believe a detailed investigation of non-structural features is mostly outside of the scope of this work.
label: dispute

sentence: To show that we can easily include these features, we have included in our appendix some results including non-structural features.
label: concur

sentence: When adding in the sequence features used by Fout et al. via a simple linear model combining our final hidden layer and the additional sequence features, we are able to achieve a superior performance of 0.921 (0.914 +/- 0.009) versus their performance of 0.896 (0.894 +/- 0.004).
label: nonarg

sentence: While BIPSPI (Sanchez-Garcia et al. 2018) does achieve the best combined performance at 0.942, they also use additional sequence correlation features (note their structure-only performance is comparable to that of Fout et al).
label: nonarg

sentence: > Some discussion on why the “SASNet ensemble” would yield better performance would be good; could it be overfitting?
label: nonarg

sentence: Response: We have removed the SASNet ensemble from the paper, as it was based on C_p^{val} and confuses the point we are making about minimally relying on C_p for training and validation.
label: concur

sentence: We could definitely investigate further why this mild ensembling yields a small performance increase, but we see this as tangential to the overarching points of the paper.
label: dispute

sentence: Many thanks for the valuable feedback! We uploaded a revised version of the paper, and in the following address the weaknesses you pointed out:
label: nonarg

sentence: Note that the training data is not constrained with respect to ratios and number of objects addressed by the caption, so the learned behavior should be independent of these aspects.
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, note that for most ratios there is only one combination of numbers with at most 15 objects in total, but larger images fitting a greater total number of objects would definitely be an option here.
label: concur

sentence: For the less close-to-balanced ratios 1:2, 2:3, 3:4 where there are multiple possibilities, performance generally is (close-to-)perfect, indicating that there is no increased difficulty of learning multiples in the presence of more close-to-balanced ratios (for instance, 6:9 vs 7:8).
label: concur

sentence: We hope this clarifies your concern.
label: nonarg

sentence: 5. We fully agree that it would be very interesting to investigate these models.
label: concur

sentence: For this paper, we decided to focus on the methodology of investigating such questions in detail (the evaluation for FiLM alone comprises around 100 experiments) as opposed to focusing on the comparison of behavior of different models, and leave the latter to future work.
label: concur

sentence: We added a few additional sentences to section 3.2 regarding that.
label: dispute

sentence: 6. We added a few sentences to the end of section 2.4 on our speculative intuition regarding what strategy a model may prefer.
label: concur

sentence: We didn't think about the fact that one may want to control which strategy is learned, which would indeed be interesting, but that's why we considered FiLM as is and didn't experiment with changing architecture details.
label: concur

sentence: At the same time, considering that understanding "most" is only one of many capabilities a VQA model is supposed to learn, these results are unlikely to be an important influencing factor for architecture choice, while at least knowing about the properties of a model is nonetheless interesting.
label: concur

sentence: 7. The evaluation is supposed to show what an architecture is capable of learning under "ideal" conditions.
label: dispute

sentence: It's an interesting question whether/how this changes when gradually shifting towards "less ideal" setups.
label: dispute

sentence: An advantage of using a controlled setup like ours is that this is possible to investigate, to some degree at least (for instance, add more types of captions to the training data, not just quantifier statements).
label: dispute

sentence: At some point we may be interested in actually investigating the same for real-world data, but we think it's unclear right now what exactly such evaluation data should ideally look like, what problems are most interesting, what details to pay attention to. Artificial data allows us to investigate these questions while avoiding the elaborate and expensive process of obtaining real-world data.
label: concur

sentence: 8. Note that the training data is far less constrained than the evaluation data, including various distracting aspects like additional shapes/colors.
label: concur

sentence: The evaluation data doesn't contain such distractors, but it would of course be possible (and potentially interesting) to add such.
label: concur

sentence: We didn't do so since we considered instances with only "relevant" attributes to be the most difficult setup, like a minimal pair, where a model is required to focus on all objects and both their shape and color attribute to decide correctly.
label: concur

sentence: 9. We incorporated the changes as you suggested.
label: concur

sentence: Thanks!
label: nonarg

sentence: 10. We didn't think about this interpretation -- our intention was to signal that we take the "The Meaning of 'Most'" setup and methodology of Pietroski et al. from psychology, and implement a deep learning version for visual question answering models.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for a careful reading of the paper and the constructive comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: Although we proposed Past Decode Regularization (PDR) with language modeling in mind to exploit the symmetry between the input and output vocabulary (and the corresponding word embedding and softmax layer), any model/task that has this symmetry can potentially use a PDR term.
label: concur

sentence: As suggested by the reviewer, models for tasks like text summarization and neural machine translation (using a byte-pair encoding vocabulary as in Ofir & Wolf 2016) that use an encoder/decoder seq2seq architecture can benefit from PDR and is a topic of future research.
label: concur

sentence: We will incorporate this discussion in the updated version of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: We can justify PDR theoretically as an inductive bias on the language model.
label: concur

sentence: The observed bigrams in a language are not random and the distribution of the second word given the first word in a bigram is not uniform.
label: concur

sentence: Similarly, the distribution of the first word given the second word will be far from uniform.
label: concur

sentence: A RNN based language model models the first dependence (and more long range ones) and our proposed PDR tries to model the second one.
label: concur

sentence: In a unidirectional language model, we cannot look into the future tokens and hence we use the output distribution as a proxy for the "true second word" and decode the distribution of the first word.
label: concur

sentence: Thus the PDR term can be thought of as biasing the language model to retain more information about the distribution of the first word given the second word in a bigram.
label: concur

sentence: Finally, we have conducted further experiments on larger corpora, specifically the Gigaword corpus.
label: concur

sentence: We use a 2-layer LSTM with a word embedding dimension of 1024 and hidden dimension of 1024.
label: nonarg

sentence: We truncated the vocabulary by keeping approximately 100k words with the highest frequency.
label: concur

sentence: We compare the performance of the model with and without PDR and using no other regularization.
label: concur

sentence: We used the same validation and test sets as (Yang et al. 2017).
label: concur

sentence: We obtained a valid/test perplexity of 44.0/42.5 for the model with PDR and 44.3/43.1 for the model without PDR, showing a gain of 0.6 in the test perplexity by using PDR.
label: concur

sentence: We will incorporate these results in the experiments section and post the updated manuscript shortly.
label: concur

sentence: Press, Ofir, and Lior Wolf. "Using the output embedding to improve language models." arXiv preprint arXiv:1608.05859 (2016).
label: nonarg

sentence: Yang, Zhilin, et al. "Breaking the softmax bottleneck: A high-rank RNN language model." arXiv preprint arXiv:1711.03953 (2017).
label: nonarg

sentence: *All or at least some of these decisions would need to be relaxed to make a convincing paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: you are right, even if the focus of the paper is not on getting the best possible score on language modelling, different settings would make this point not only more convincing, but clearer.
label: concur

sentence: *The reasons for the use of the energy-based formulation are not clear to me.
label: nonarg

sentence: Is the energy-based model particularly well-suited to the random-projection setup, or are there other reasons for using it, independent of the use of random projections?
label: nonarg

sentence: This formulation is fundamental for the next step of the work in which we are removing the restrictions from the output layer and learning word probability distributions without prior knowledge of the vocabulary size.
label: concur

sentence: That said, the formulation is just the re-use of the embedding layer transposed.
label: concur

sentence: It removed an entire set of m x V parameters and got us better results in all our experiments so we decided to use it.
label: concur

sentence: * It looks like all the results are given on the test set. Did you not do any tuning on the validation data?
label: nonarg

sentence: Yes, all the parameters were tuned on the validation data.
label: concur

sentence: All the models were selected according to their validation data evaluation.
label: concur

sentence: The early stop criterion is also based on the validation data evaluation.
label: concur

sentence: We consider the model to converge when it cannot improve further on validation data.
label: concur

sentence: The models never saw the test set during training or tuning, otherwise we would be cheating and these scores would be irrelevant to compare different settings.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for the detailed review and constructive remarks.
label: nonarg

sentence: Below are answers to the main points that were commented as well as updates on the current work.
label: nonarg

sentence: * Sound quality is disappointing and with artifacts:
label: nonarg

sentence: We are working on Fast Spectrogram Inversion using Multi-head Convolutional Neural Networks, arXiv:1808.06719, Sercan O. Arik et al. to replace Griffin-Lim inversion ; two possible improvements we expect are much faster (towards real-time) sound rendering and better audio quality.
label: concur

sentence: We are also working on mini-batch MMD latent regularization (Wasserstein-AE) instead of per-sample KLD regularization (VAE) which may result in improved generalization power and generative quality.
label: nonarg

sentence: * Not suited to transfer from audio without label:
label: nonarg

sentence: If the audio carries a note information, it can be easily/automatically extracted in the form of pitch tracks as we did for transferring on instrument solos.
label: dispute

sentence: Some audio data do not have note qualities, which are out of the current training setting.
label: dispute

sentence: For that we have been training unconditioned one-to-one models or solely instrument conditional many-to-many models that do not require any note information.
label: dispute

sentence: But we are working on models which incorporate an unconditioned processing option (eg. training while zeroing the one-hot conditioning or adding an entry in the input embedding of FiLM which is the unconditional state) to be trained on a dataset that mixes conditional and non conditional audio (eg. adding instrument solo sections which in parts have a clear pitch track and in others none).
label: nonarg

sentence: * A fully convolutional model would process arbitrary length of audio:
label: nonarg

sentence: We use the linear layers to set the latent space dimensionality, when processing various length audio sequences, each encoding amounts to about 120ms context and we resynthesize with overlap-ad that mirrors the short-term input analysis ; this process was used when transferring on the instrument solos (a task that was beyond the training setting).
label: concur

sentence: * Insufficient justification of the 3D latent space:
label: nonarg

sentence: At first we validated that our models could perform well in term of training/test spectrogram reconstructions with only 3 latent dimensions, some reasons that we found interesting to enforce this are more related to a possible music/creative application of the model: less synthesis/control parameters for the user (and controls which may then be more expressive), direct visualization of the latent space which is turned into a 3D synthesis space from which users may draw and decode sound paths or create other interaction schemes, a denser latent space that may be better suited for random sampling/interpolations.
label: concur

sentence: The direct interaction with 3D latent space becomes even more interesting when we pipeline our model with fast-spectrogram inversion.
label: concur

sentence: * Interesting incremental comparison in one-to-one transfers:
label: nonarg

sentence: We keep working on more detailed benchmarks/comparisons that would equally cover one-to-one and many-to-many model variations and that would integrate the new features we are testing.
label: nonarg

sentence: * All claims about running time should be corroborated by controlled experiments:
label: nonarg

sentence: Indeed we didn’t benchmark yet our models on Nsyth and our approach differs from others such as Mor et al. that report using « eight Tesla V100 GPUs for a total of 6 days
label: concur

sentence: From the beginning of our experiment we aim at a much lighter-weight system that could be trained/used more broadly (eg. with a single mid-range GPU).
label: nonarg

sentence: The computational cost difference is not rigorously estimated on a same given dataset/task to learn but still we think it is relevent to point that the results we report can be achieved in less that a day on a single Tesla V100 GPU.
label: nonarg

sentence: * Why does the MMD version constitute an improvement? Or is it simply more stable to train?
label: nonarg

sentence: It is more stable to train, it does not require the extra ‘cost’ of an auxiliary network training and it can generalize to many-to-many transfer without requiring as many adversarial networks.
label: concur

sentence: About the significance of score differences, we agree that it needs more details and comparisons, it was also noted by "AnonReviewer1" and we should make alternative tests to scale or give a few more references to the benchmark.
label: concur

sentence: * "FILM-poi" .. is this a typo ?
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for pointing this as well as your other remarks on the writing and use of precise terms/phrases.
label: concur

sentence: Indeed this is right, we mixed poi/pod but both refer to many-to-many conditioning on pitch+octave+instrument/domain classes.
label: concur

sentence: We also thank you for pointing more literature to improve our references and discussions to related works.

sentence: Thank you for approving our contribution to understanding the transferability of adversarial examples.
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree with that the smoothing gradient idea, especially the Gaussian smoothing technique, is not new, since the smoothing strategy could be used in many different scenarios.
label: concur

sentence: However, we motivate and derive the idea of smoothing the gradient based on our novel understanding on the transferability of adversarial examples between two models.

sentence: We provide our reply to your questions below:
label: nonarg

sentence: (1) In equation (3) we are using scalarization, a well-known technique to solve multi-objective optimization problems (see for example Boyd’s book “Convex optimization” Ch. 4).
label: concur

sentence: In this case, the maximization problem is a multi-objective optimization problem including both the parameters of the discriminator and of the classifier.
label: concur

sentence: The parameter alpha controls the importance/priority of each of the objectives.
label: concur

sentence: The parameter alpha also allows to control the detectability constraints for the attack, which allows us to test the robustness of learning algorithms and defences in different settings, considering more or less aggressive adversaries.
label: concur

sentence: This is common in most security settings to test system’s robustness and resilience in different attack scenarios.
label: concur

sentence: (2) In pGAN the discriminator allows to model detectability constraints for the poisoning points.
label: concur

sentence: In other words, to evade detection or removal of points by algorithms that defend against poisoning attacks, such as the defences we used in our experiment, we want our attack points to be close to the distribution of the genuine data.
label: concur

sentence: However, please, note that the discriminator’s loss is decoupled from the classifier’s loss.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast, the generator is the element that competes with both the discriminator and the classifier.
label: concur

sentence: On the other side, the discriminator does not exclude poisoning data or select any data point but helps to guide the generator to craft poisoning points that are difficult to detect.
label: concur

sentence: In other words, the discriminator does not filter out the points that are used to train the classifier during the training of pGAN.
label: concur

sentence: It is not clear to us what the reviewer refers to when mentioning measuring the classification error from the data the discriminator selects, as the discriminator does not “select” any data point, but just aim to classify genuine from fake data points.
label: dispute

sentence: We would be happy to provide further clarifications on this point if needed.
label: nonarg

sentence: (3)-(4) To some extent pGAN can control the specific errors produced in the system, as shown both in Figures 5 and 6.
label: concur

sentence: But the changes produced in the system may also depend on the characteristics of the dataset and the learning algorithms used.
label: concur

sentence: pGAN produces poisoning attack points that are close to the decision boundary, “pushing the decision boundary away” from the source class (i.e. the same class as the labels of the poisoning points) towards the samples of the target class.
label: concur

sentence: Then, we can expect an increase of the false positive rate, which is shown in Figure 6 (centre).
label: concur

sentence: At some point, when the fraction of poisoning points increases significantly the decision boundary starts to change in a different (and possibly more abrupt way), so that the false negatives also start to increase.
label: concur

sentence: In Figure 6 (right) this happens when the fraction of poisoning points is larger than 25%.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast, the label flipping attack is less subtle as it does not consider detectability constraints.
label: concur

sentence: The attack points are therefore not necessarily close to the decision boundary, and thus, the changes produced in the algorithm are more unpredictable and affect the errors for the two classes.
label: concur

sentence: If there are points that, in your view, require further clarification, please let us know.
label: nonarg

sentence: In particular, we are delighted that you see the potential of the stethoscope framework lending itself to much broader applications.
label: concur

sentence: We have opted, in this submission, to focus on our primary application domain, which is intuitive physics.
label: dispute

sentence: In particular, we demonstrate the efficacy of neural stethoscopes in interpreting, promoting and suppressing specific information in the context of the complex interplay between visual clues and physical properties in stability prediction.
label: dispute

sentence: Our work is primarily motivated by the question as to what extent neural networks learn about physical principles or whether they merely follow visual clues and how we can guide the learning process.
label: dispute

sentence: We showcase the stethoscope framework here to that effect and, based on its application, provide some interesting and novel [according to Reviewer 1] insights into representations for visual stability prediction.
label: dispute

sentence: As regards the implications of the paper, we would like to address this in the context of the reviewer’s comment that increased performance is not surprising given the additional supervision provided.
label: nonarg

sentence: Our submission argues that the manner in which this information is provided really does matter.
label: dispute

sentence: Figure 6 addresses this point in that multi-task learning fails to leverage the potential of the additional training labels (and, indeed, leads to a detrimental effect, Fig 6b) whereas the stethoscope framework allows the specification of whether the information considered should be promoted or suppressed.
label: dispute

sentence: This leads to the performance gains shown in Fig 6a.
